The park entrance fee was $10/car (which i think pretty cheap). Do bring snacks and water along. We got hungry driving around. Definitely worth the visit. And oh the park is super senior friendly (my mom was with us and she was able to enjoy the park without doing lots of hiking while having a bad knee).

We stayed in Bend the previous night and approached the park from the northern entrance - park fee at the time of writing was $10 per vehicle. The road climbed to the rim and we caught sight of the lake from the first lookout there. he colour was a deep blue, lighter green in the shallows and it was magnificent. We travelled down the western rim and took the walk up the the Watchman - another fine view. The other spot we visited was Sun Notch and the view over the Phantom Ship - the water seemed its darkest here. Crater Lake sure is a lovely spot - a little out of the way, but lovely nonetheless.

We camped at Diamond Lake which is only about 14 miles from Carter Lake with our 10 year old twins. The bugs there were horrible but I will save that for another review. We went to Crater Lake on a Monday so it wasn’t too crowed. I have been to several national parks and would have to say this was the most accessible park yet. They charge a $10 entrance fee per car. The view points are not far from each other and very easy to get to. The parking was easy also. I would not recommend traveling with an RV since there isn’t really any RV parking at the view points. They do have a trolley you can take if you don’t want to drive. If you are travelling during the summer all the roads Should be open and you can drive all the way around the crater which I would definitely recommend. If you get nervous with driving near cliffs be aware for a good portion of the drive around the lake there are cliffs right at the edge of the pavement. I was very nervous but made it through. We drove very slowly on those parts. One day is plenty of time to spend at the crater if you don’t plan to take long hikes. The mosquitoes were pretty bad so bring plenty of spray and wear long sleeves and pants. We ended up eating our picnic lunch in the car because of the bugs. We decided to take a boat tour. Since we didn’t book tickets in advance we were able to go to a kiosk at the lodge to purchase tickets. We weren’t sure if we could get tickets, but they did still have some for the same day on a late afternoon tour. The hike to the boat launch is 2.2 miles round trip with a 700 ft. elevation and is marked strenuous. This is very similar to the hike for Multnomah Falls in the Columbia Gorge, OR. You need to take into consideration the elevation and the weather for this hike at Crater Lake. I get pretty nervous with heights. Three out of four of us slipped on the way down. The trail is dirt and small rocks which makes it very slippery and dusty. We held the hands of our kids the whole way. It took us about 25 minutes to get down and about 45 to get back up. The tour cost $108 for the four of us. It was two hours long and drove very slowly around the perimeter of the lake. They have a park ranger who tells the different theories of how the lake formed on board of the tour. Most of these facts you will read at the view points and you can see nearly everything from the view points. It was a very slow tour. The kids and I were bored and ready to go after about an hour of it. You must bring plenty of water and food for this tour. The bathrooms were disgusting (out houses). I would bring some TP with you just in case. I could have lived without this tour. I would not recommend this excursion to families with children 10 or younger. Driving around the crater and stopping at the view points was good enough for me. The lake is beautiful and I was able to get some gorgeous pictures.

I went to beautiful and scenic crater lake to camp in June. It was very sunny but the temperature was just above freezing and the campground had three feet of snow, and i arrived at 830pm, so I decided not to camp and stayed in the $170 (overpriced, but it is a national park and someone has to pay to plow the roads) manassas village lodge. It was clean and very basic with no tv, radio, coffee, candy, water, magazines, or anything to suggest hospitality or comfort. Like a large outhouse with a bed in it. There was a ticking baseboard heater that was welcome on the cool evening in June that i stayed there. Unfortunately the smoke detector outside the room beeped and alarmed every 5 minutes all night, and i was unarmed. I decided to walk to the beautiful log cabin village restaurant for breakfast as a treat to start my day. I ordered a poached egg and it came on a white plate, all alone, cold and slimey and raw. After I gagged that down I ordered a nice warm "home made" cinnamon bun from the huge open gourmet kitchen that i could see and hear was staffed by a whole line of blue ribbon chefs. Over the banter of the line chefs and orders I heard the beeping of a microwave oven, but tried to remain optimistic. Eventually a plate arrived bearing a microwaved "heat and eat" premade bun that was dry outside, cold an dgoopy inside, and coated with weepy white icing from a tube. I was saddened, but even more so when I got my bill and saw the bun alone was $7. Tv chef ramsay would have asked them to turn in their aprons.

Before our recent trip to Crater Lake I tried to find reviews online to determine if the boat tour was worth the effort and expense (adults $32, kids $22). I couldn't find much info, so I decided to add my own here now that we did it. Crater Lake itself is an amazing natural wonder of course, but the boat tour itself is a mixed bag. Overall, I'd rate it a 6 on scale of 1 to 10. Here's what you need to know.

I was on the last days on june 2012 and almost all the trails were closed. We just see the lake of the park. It was beautiful.We stay in the hotel of diamond lake, 30 minutes aprox. away from the entrance of the park. The cost for a room for two person was US$100. I was an average hotel with a nice view. Close by there is road with very nice waterfall. you find brochure in the park

Heading North on Hwy 97 between Klamath Falls and Bend, detouring to Crater Lake (via Hwy 62) adds about 40 minutes of travel time. The drive was easy, even while hauling our travel trailer. There are several viewpoints to stop and overlook impressive deep canyons. We stopped at the Visitor Centre after paying the $10 park entrance fee, but didn’t find it was really necessary. Continuing to drive up to Rim Village was where everything convenes. (Café, gift shop, information, tours, etc.)

I've been to many stunning National Parks in the US, as well as amazing destinations all over the world. Cuyahoga Valley NP is beautiful in its own way and worth a visit. You can enjoy it in 3 hours or 3 days and anything in between. I did just a 3 hour visit on my most recent trip and I loved it. I rented a bike in Peninsula, hopped on the train (only $3 for cyclists!), got off, and enjoyed solitude on the trails. I stopped for an Italian ice at Trail Mix, and continued back to Peninsula. I saw wildlife like chipmunks, turtles, and heron. The train is scenic, though I can only speak for a portion of the route that I was on. Sit on the river side of the train! Don't expect it to be high speed; I think it moves around 30 MPH. After that, I went to Brandywine Falls. Parking is available close to the falls. The walk is less than 0.5 miles, with the option of stairs or a ramp. I went on a weekday during the afternoon and I highly recommend it if you want to avoid the crowds. Every person I met was incredibly nice - not just polite but went out of their way to help me - from the bike rental shop, to the train assistants, to the shopkeeper. If you like trains, biking, hiking, neat bridges, and/or Ohio countryside, I think you'll love the park. The park was very clean and there are bathrooms and water fountains at the train stations. The towpath trail is a little narrow in places and has light gravel, so research that if it impacts your biking plans. I went at a leisurely pace.

First off, you can't drive very far into this park. The only way to see anything is to pay for a bus tour (about 4 hrs, 6 hrs, or 8 hrs). Our bus was so noisy, we couldn't hear our driver, Scott (who was very nice). I felt bad for the guy sitting directly in front of the ramp that rattled loudly next to his head. Second, we hardly saw any animals. I know Denali isn't a zoo, but I have to say that perhaps August is not an ideal time to visit the park. One can only look at mountains for so many hours before falling asleep. We paid around $32 USD each. I'm glad we did this tour, but only because we couldn't drive in on our own. Every other National Park I've been to, you can drive and walk around more freely. Third, there was a rude older man working at the tent/gift store who angrily asked me to leave because I was holding a covered beverage that I made no attempts to open. He could have asked me to set it on the bench, but instead told me to go outside. Bizarre.

Denali National Park is a special place with wondrous sights. We went on a tour bus, the only way into the depths of the park to Kantishna, a privately owned enclave. On the way we drove on extreme roads with drop offs that made your hair curl, but scenery that made up for it. We saw many grizzly and black bears, moose with huge 'racks' in full velvet, caribou and Dall Sheep. We were also privileged to view Mt McKinley in full sun with fluffy clouds around her peaks. It was a real WOW moment. We enjoyed an excellent lunch and an hours recreation, including panning for gold or a walking tour of the area. The cost for the 13 hour day was over $100 each but worth every cent. Sublime.

We took the park bus up to Toklat River, which cost us $27 (bus fare) + $10 (entrance & reservation) per person. The driver had a rough, monotonic (like in a robotic recording) voice. The bus stopped for viewing of animals only when some sharp-eyed passenger shouted out to announce their presence. Even then, the animals were so far away that, if you didn't have binoculars, you'd be lucky to espy them in the few minutes that the bus remained stationary. You see images so tiny that you have to leave it to your imagination to conjure up the images of the animals they were purported to be - not my idea of viewing animals in the wild. The $7 extra we paid to visit the Wildlife Center on the Narrated Wildlife Tour offered by the Whittier to Anchorage Cruise Transportation service provided a much better opportunity to see many of Alaska's wildlife at close range even if they were in enclosures. Although, there was one overlook point (to view Mt. McKinley), the driver never pulled into it. When I questioned him about it, his respone was that the peak wasn't visible, the skies being cloudy that day. There was nothing to be seen at Toklat River terminus either. We were glad that we didn't spend the extra $10 to go up to the Eielson Visitor Center. We'd have wasted another 1 hour only to see nothing more than some pictures at the Visitor Center. On our return trip to Anchorage the next day, we had a fantastic view of Mt. McKinley from the front yard of a restaurant/motel just south of the South View Point (I believe its name is Mary's Cafe or something like that - which also served some decent coffee) about half way to Anchorage - you cannot miss it if you're driving; it's the only restaurant on the west side of the highway standing all by its lonesome self out in the vastness of Alaska's wilderness. Even though man's last frontier has a certain allure of its own, to my mind, it cannot be compared to the resplendent beauty of the Canadian Rockies.

Very rude to paying customers. Small rental company, with staff that has no knowledge about their equipment and service provided while there. People were told they better be back in the four hours aloted as if you are five minutes late the 100.00 Charge is applicable. A flat tire while on excursion, staff stated Don't you know how to change a tire and You better call Triple A. No compensation offered for the hour delay while they had to find someone to come and change the tire.

Denali State Park is the only national park in the USA that sold itself to a private company for profit, yet operates under the guise of a taxpayer sponsored national park. You are not allowed to enter the park with your own car. You can walk , but that would be impossible. You are required to use Aramark industries as a private consultant, and they will drive you in on a packed old school bus for $45-$120 per person per day. But, you must also pay the park entrance fee on top of this to the park service of $10 per person. A complete scam. No other park, specifically Yellowstone, the grand park, does such a terrible thing. You pay $25 at Yellowstone for a 3 day unlimited pass for one car to the entire park, as a taxpayer should. On top of all of this, the wildlife is very limited and is certainly not compared to Yellowstone. The people are scammer types that charge $30 for a baseball cap and $15 for a hot dog type, if you know what I mean. What a huge disappointment.

A week pass for the Joshua Tree National Park is $15. You still need to purchase the week pass even when you're there for a couple of hours. If you visit lot of national parks, it's better to purchase an annual pass for $80. Even if you have to pay $15, it's worth going in and see inside of the park. Rock formation is so beautiful. The park has several camp grounds, and we definitely would like to camp out at our next visit.
park: Desert Institute at Joshua Tree National Park

text: We knew that the were huge numbers of fossils in this area and that one canyon had yielded a massive number and quality. What we hadn't realised that part of the canyon wall had been enclosed in a building so you could see the site. This is a little away from the main visitor centre but a shuttle runs you there every 15 minutes. The canyon wall is breathtaking and the displays in the building are superb. We were lucky that a palaeontologist was there working and happy to answer questions. This is a National Monument so admission is $20 but is really cheap for what you get to see. Kids love anything to do with dinosaurs so they are happy too. 100% recommend.

As a UK citizen I do so wish that we presented our parks and monuments they way the Americans do. Even more so the charges that we seem to make but they don't. We were there for about 2 hours, 4 of us in the car and parking was $10. No admittance fee was charged. A free shuttle bus to the 'wall' about every 20 minutes. The wall and exhibits were incredible. A quite enjoyable 2 hours. Teenagers in the party thoroughly enjoyed it to.

This is a sensational sight in the sense that the dinosaur quarry is a fascinating repository of finds left in situ and there's no place like it. BUT given the huge amount of money spent to restore the building it's a real shame the standard of presentation is so weak. When we last came ten years there was a coloured panel that helped you pick out the jumbled bones of each animal by using a different colour for each one. Now there's very little to help you understand what's going on - just a couple of well-intentioned rangers, a few basic information panels, a $1 kids' booklet, and very little else. The truth is that you are looking at a large grey cliff face scattered with a large number of disarticulated grey bones, some of which are quite a long way above you and it's very hard to make sense of, especially for kids who are probably expecting something far more dramatic. None of the skeletons is complete which means you are looking at a stack of vertebrae here, a bit of tail there, a couple of leg bones over there and so on. This is a place that is screaming out for a presentation video, better labelling of the bones and so on. Ironically, the wall displays of skeleton plaster casts are considerably more informative and easier to understand. We came a long way to see this and we were in and out of the cover building in about 30 minutes and that was stretching it. In some respects the 1.5-mile trail back to the parking lot (you have to come up to the quarry by shuttle) which takes you past an open-air section of the quarry with bones in place was more evocative. So, it's undeniably worth visiting and very memorable but I had the feeling it could with some time, trouble, and money, be a lot better.

The Wall of Bones at the Quarry is spectacular. We watched the short movie at the Visitor's Center first...well done and informative. The auto tour was good. Spring the $1 for the tour guide brochure; it really enhances the drive.
Passed through on route to Bryce Canyon. Fabulous rock formations. ..great for taking pictures. A must when travelling to Bryce Canyon.

This place is absolutely stunning for it's remoteness. We have to go back because we snorkeled and walked around which split the time for each into too little for either before the boat wants you back on board. The waters and beaches are beautiful both above and below and the Fort is a sight that has some stunning views and great places for photo's. We will try a night or two camping as it seems like that would allow the best use of the parks beauty to explore the Fort, snorkel the waters and bird watch followed by what I am sure is a beautiful star filled sky at night. The boat ride is very comfortable and the 2.5 hours goes by quick if you meet some new people and chat. The food is good for this type of excursion but we did find $175.00 each a bit pricey for the time you actually spend in the park. We will go back camping and see if the value/price then meets the criteria, we assume it will.

Interesting, but expensive 150/person, 2.5 hours travel on boat each way. Historical and very interesting site, a nice daylong outing. Sea was a little rough!get the anti-nausea medication at the service counter... $1 per pack! Worth it. If your main interest is the snorkeling, this is not the tour for you, but if you are interested in history, this is a great opportunity. Breakfast and lunch provided, food is ok.

The trip is fine if you don't mind spending 5 hours on a boat. The fort itself is well....just a fort. Not much to see and you can only get onto a small section of it. The snorkelling was much promoted but I took my own gear but didn't use it because owing to the wind the water was opaque and anyway you could only snorkel in a couple of areas. The outward journey was horrendous going through the "channel". The boat was nice as was the breakfast and buffet lunch but apart from that it is difficult to find things to do for the remaining 4 1/2 hours. Although the return journey was smoother one couple summed up the day as "enough is enough". The price of almost $300 for two people should also be a slight disincentive. So overall not something I would want to repeat.

I have visited Tortugas Park with local agency on Key West. Main reason was to swim with turtles so we paid for this trip almost 200$ /pp but on the place there were no 1 turtle!! Agency had lie to us. They didn't tell truth. I was very disapointed. We spent a lot of money and time for this trip and wasn't worth it. If you want to see turtles go to Acumal in Mexico and you will see during snurkling big turtles for free

This was billed as an excursion with interesting historical sites and great snorkeling. It was neither. It's a long (2.5 hr.) boat ride to get there from Key West (and another 2.5 hr. to get back) that costs about $170 per person. The fort on the island might be interesting if you've never seen one from that period, but it's pretty similar to other forts from the period. The snorkeling was really poor -- murky water, dead coral and very few fish. (I visited the two top snorkeling locations and snorkeled the entire circumference of the island.)

What a great day out, one that must be done when in Key West. Went to the Dry Tortugas on the Yankee Express ferry. It takes two and a half hours to get there and oh my god is it worth it. You land on this island in the middle of nowhere. Pristine water and snow white sand. Went snorkelling for the first time and it was amazing. Fort Jefferson is built on this island and adds a bit of history to the visit. After 4 hours on the island, you return to Key West arriving back at 5.30p.m. You get your breakfast and lunch on the ferry. Everything is so well organised. It's not cheap, $170 per person but it's a one off. A trip never to be forgotten. Recommend it without hesitation. Thanks to all concerned.

We flew out on the seaplane. Our expensive treat of the holiday. Worth every dollar. The Otter is ver noisy, but comfortable. Great views of the reefs with an excellent commentary from the pilot. The fort itself was worth a look round, but the birds were fantastic. The beaches are small, superb to swim off, but get the early flight as when the ferry arrives it gets were busy. A very different day out.

Amazing adventure of a lifetime! Pay the extra money and take the seaplane, you won't regret it! There are people who came on the ferry and they were feeling seasick, not to mention that the ferry took 3 hours and the seaplane was a beautiful, smooth 45 minute flight, 500 feet above the beautiful, turquoise water.
At $170 (£110) per person for this day trip, it not cheap but on the whole, a light breakfast and lunch included, we felt it was worth it.

We took a plane which was nice and quick. Got there at around 8:45am, the water was freezing. I went snorkeling because after spending almost $600 for 2 of us, I was going to see some fish. I saw exactly ONE fish even though I went in where the pilot recommended. There were two planes and I think there was 24 people and only four of us had the guts to get in. The visitors bureau and Best of Key West assured me that the water would be nice even in the morning and that the snorkeling would be good. Neither was true. I have heard Dry Tortugas is amazing at other times of the year, specifically summer.

We have decided to spend a night in Dry Tortugas. Although the camp operates on a "first come, first served" basis and reservation is not needed, but the parks authorities require prior reservation on the ferry that runs between Key West and Garden Keys at Dry Tortugas. Number places in the campground is limited to 10, so we have made reservation four months in advance. Ferry ticket for the people staying on the island costs $190 or $170 for those who want to spend on it only a few hours.
At $170 per person, it is costly but we were able to spend most of day there and it was gorgeous!

best $170 bucks spent, your day starts at 7 am when you board the ferry to the park 70 miles due west later you land on a incredible island with a fortress made from bricks that were all shipped there.Some great snorkeling within 50 feet of the beaches and plenty of time to look around the fort.The ferry also gives you breakfast and lunch, also you can buy snacks and a drink on the way home, arrive back in Key West around 5.30pm tired but happy.

I had waited a long time for this tour, paid my $170 which included my $5 park pass and got on the Yankee Freedom 2 at 8AM and powered our way out 120Kms into the Gulf of Mexico. The fee included breakfast, lunch, and complimentary beverage. The trip took 2 and a half hours to reach our destination, and we where there for about 4 hours. On the trip over to Tortuga, all guests where privy to very informative videos on snorkeling, eg. how to fit your free supplied gear, where to snorkel, what not to do, and where to return it after use. There was a video on the history of the fort, the land, and the waters around it. Swimming is permitted to swimmers at the north and south beaches. For those who wish to get in the water, there are warm fresh water hoses on the stern of the boat to rinse the salt water off your body, and a hose on the dock to wash the sand off your feet, and change rooms on the dock. There are guided tours of the fort, or you can tour at your own leisure, the fort is in the process of being restored, so there are areas that the public has no access to, but don't worry, there is plenty of area to explore, including walking the mote wall around the outside of the fort. There are three levels of the walls to walk, observe the restored 25 ton canons, enjoy the view from the top level, stair wells are in the corners of the fort. Over night camping is also permitted, so bring a tent, if that's your fancy. There is a small gift store to purchase souvenirs on the property. On the return trip, all names of passengers are accounted for before the ferry leaves, and the bar is open for those passengers who are over 21 years of age, and have the cash to purchase beer, wine, and mixed drinks. The crew was very friendly, and informative. This is a must see tour for all ages, and I highly recommend it.

Get a good tan on the boat to Tortuga. When you are there you can snorkel and swim in the rief. You can also take a tour in the fort and learn some history, or Watch birds and beach Life. If you want you can camp on Tortuga for 3 dollar a night

The fort is very well taken care of. It has a lot of interesting things to look at on land. The snorkeling isn't that great because there aren't that many areas for fish to hide. The beach is beautiful. There were a few people camping but there are only 4-5 spots where you can set up and have tree cover; some were set up in direct sun, I couldn't imagine staying there without tree cover in the summer. We took a seaplane to get there; it cost $280.00 pp and took 40 minutes. The boat cost in the mid hundreds but takes over 1.5 hours each way. It was worth the xtra money to not spend half the day on a boat. The airplane service we used was seaplane adventures; they provided drinks and snorkel equipment for free.

We booked our 150$ per person, 2 1/2 hour trip to the Dry Tortugas with great anticipation. We purchades the tickets 2 days before the sailing. The morning of, we were informed that the seas were a bit rough and choppy and we were offered Dramamine for sale. We asked about the snorkelling and were told it was still a go. If we cancelled there would be no refund. After an extremely unpleasant 2 hours (people were throwing up all over the ship - luckily we did not) we arrived at the Park, were given an interesting tour of the Fort (30 Mins) and then sat there for the rest of the day as the snorkelling was a bust because of the wind and waves. The organisers new this before we left Key West and I feel it was dishonest of them to not allow refunds. If you plan on going check conditions carefully before purchasing your tickets.

For $160 you get breakfast, lunch, refreshments and great service as you enjoy a comfortable 2 and a half hour cruise out to the park. Beautiful beaches, good snorkeling and an interesting old fort to explore make this a truly unique day. The Yankee Clipper is a great boat for the trip and it sails back into town just before sunset. To top off the day you can take a quick walk over to Mallory Square where you can join the daily sunset celebration. I would highly recommend this trip!

Even though the weather was uncooperative it was an interesting day to say the least. A bit on the cool side and a little rough near the end on the way out but plenty of breakfast and a great ride. At the fort Brian did a great job giving the tour. An incredible building. The water was too rough for snorkeling but wasn't going to do that anyway and the cooler weather was probably better than the extensive heat than a day or two earlier would have been. On the way back the water was really rough. The crew was handing out plenty of little white bags but fortunately had taken a Dramamine which they have available on board for $1. (Well worth it!) But everybody stayed in good humor and it was an exciting ride and much more authentic than Disney World! All in all a very interesting day!

We are from Vancouver Canada ,love to go exploring and last weekend on a beautiful sunny day we came across Ebey's Landing State Park. What a great find! We came in from the Ebey Prairie trail (which takes you to Jacob ebeys house), and decided to take the trail down to the bluff. So glad we did! We noticed a sign for a loop hike along the ridge down to the beach and then back up. The loop is about 3.5miles( 5.5km) i am guessing here but add about another 1mile (1.5km) to get back to the car. We never rush so the whole trip took us about 3 hours. It is an easy hike expect for the climb in the beginning to get up to the ridge. The trail travels beside some pretty steep drop offs and I am not a fan off heights so my knees were shacking a few times. Not sure if I would take young children up there. One wrong step could end up in disaster. But the views are absolutely stunning so even being afraid of heights it was absolutely worth it, You will be walking along a narrow sandy path but the loop part along the beach is quite rocky so I would still suggest hikers or sturdy shoes. Bring your camera, pack yourself a lunch and enjoy the breathtaking views! This is a State Park so a usage fee is required. 10 $US or an annual Discover Pass for30$US

Absolutely amazing views starting from the beach, up the grassy trail to the top of the high bluff. Enjoy the view of Ebey's Prairie farmland on one side & the ocean on the other. You do need a Discover Pass to park at the beach parking lot. We bought one at Fort Casey prior to coming to here. Highly recommend a visit!

If you are from way of out town/state,you will likely miss Ebey as the Deception Pass Nat Park and the towns are where most visitors head to if they only got a day to spend en route to Seattle from BC or vice versa.
Sadly, a $10.00 permit is required to park at the site. We were fortunate to come on a free weekend. The rangers on site were friendly and helpful.

If you want to meet aligators, exotic birds and get a good understanding of the florida everglades ecosystem you have to take the 2 hours tram tour worth every penny (25$ adult). The guides are exemplary. You can also rent bikes on site. Super photo ops here!! About 1 hour from Miami it is a must.

We popped in here for two hours on our way to Orlando, it never fails to impress, lots of wildlife which was great. Only not so happy about the extortionate fee to enter $25! Thought this was rather excessive, especially as it only allowed one weeks entry, surely for that amount of money two weeks would be more like it?
This place is massive but great if you like wildlife. There are plenty of places offering airboat rides but we chose the Everglades Safari Park as rides were $25 and free parking.

I've been to the Shark Valley entrance to the Everglades many times! I love the park; its truly beautiful and I always see plenty of alligators and birds; some alligators so close you could almost touch them! BUT DON'T! On 4 occasions I have rented the park bikes, most recently over the Thanksgiving weekend and every time they are just horrible! While its the best way to enjoy the park if you enjoy biking the 15 miles round trip; the bikes are in such poor shape, it can be unpleasant! Knowing this, I always get an early start and arrive in the park no later than one hour after opening, so I can test drive a few bikes. The bikes are OLD, in poor repair, although they have a staff always working on them. The day we were there (November 25th) there seemed to be more bikes awaiting repairs than there were for rent! They don't have hand breaks, only pedal breaks,very uncomfortable seats and some are very difficult to pedal or make noise all the time while pedaling. TRY ridding several! To make matters worse, they are EXPENSIVE to rent at $9 hour on top of the $25 entrance fee to the park! If you have your own bike, you can use it in the park; highly recommended!

Entered the National Park at the Ernest Coe Visitor Centre. The staff were superb. Friendly, helpful and informed. Carmen, a volunteer, was particularly patient with my numerous questions and was an absolute treasure and fountain of knowledge. There are wonderful displays in the Centre, a movie theatre where they show material on the Everglades and of course a gift shop and bathroom facilities. Maps and other educational materials are readily available. It's $25 per car to enter the park and that pass is good for 7 days. You pay at the park entrance not at the visitor centre.

We visited the park in late October and it rained for two out of three days. On the first day we followed the tradition route from Homestead to the Ernest Coe Visitor Center and eventually reached Flamingo Visitor Center, which was closed. We went on a ranger led walk through the Anhinga Trail but saw no wildlife and we had pouring rain at the end. I guess the park is quite wet at the end of the rainy season and alligators could hide anywhere, on top of that they just finished renovating the trail and it will take a little longer for the wildlife to come back. The next day we woke up early trying to catch the sunrise at Pa-hay-okee Overlook but again the weather was not very cooperative and we ended up finding some birds around the West Lake area. The third morning we woke up early again and the weather was reasonable, we drove west on the Tamiami Trail and reached the Shark Valley Visitor Center before 9, we found out there is a tram running at 9:30, the ride is around 2 hours for $24. What an amazing ride, because it was in the morning, bird and wildlife were amazingly active and we had many BIF and alligator shots, it is indeed a wildlife photographer's dream. We will definitely go back to explore further, but will take a little more time to plan ahead. This quick stopover was the beginning of our trip to Machu Picchu and Galapagos Islands.

Hard to give a fair review as the park was preparing for the possible arrival of hurricane Matthew. However, we were not really told that we would just be paying $28 for the privilege of driving 38 miles to flamingo, to see a closed visitor centre & empty car parks...& then drive 38 miles back again.
we didn't rent a car, just $10 taxi to go there from hotel. there were feeding crocodile show and snake show, riding airboat. we held REAL snake and small Crocodile, just like a dream.
We drove up to the park just after 5pm and we didnt have to pay the $20 in. The park people were gone home so the park entrance stays open for people to drive through.

$20 entrance fee per car, helpful staff, lots of places to walk and boat. Views do change as you travel 34 miles through park. We saw lots of birds including Ospreys, vultures, herons etc also saw a Large owl, 3 manatees, 2 crocodiles, 1 alligator and several turtles. Food at Flamingo point was good and reasonable. Rangers were very helpful and knowledgeable. A good day out, well worth the money.

I was not in a good mood when we started out to the Everglades National Park. It was rainy again, and not a good day to be doing outside things. But when you are on vacation, you don't get to choose your weather, you have to work with it. So we set out in our car for the park, and bought a $2 rain park in plastic, to guard against the rain. I recommend the bug spray as well. We took the back country boat tour. The Captain and boat hand were incredibly knowledgeable. The smell, the sounds and the sights of this ancient place are something that must be experienced. And it is only here that you can experience this unique ecosystem, this river of grass. If you come to Florida, you should come here. In this state of unnatural wonders (Disney world, a man-made fantasy world) the natural wonders and far more amazing. You will leave thankful for the foresight of those who fought to save this area of Florida from the rampages of development, and hopefully, ready to help fight for the continued protection of this environment. I'll be there with you.
A fabulous National Park. $10 for car access for 7 days. Loads of wildlife, very tranquil. Free ranger talks and walks and great boat trips.

Spent some time here and walked a couple of trails,was glad to see that no airboats are allowed in the national park.our trip was cut short by some heavy rain,but could have spent all day here,.factor in a lot of time if you want to see it all,as it is nearly 50 miles by road from end to end,oh yeah bring mosquito spray by the bucket full,but don't let that put you off,it is beautiful,only ten dollars to get in and a very good visitor centre to organise your day,highly recommend

You can`t miss this Park when you travel to Florida. To see alligators don`t choose cold weather, `cause the alligators come up just with sun light. You just pay $20 per car for 6 days. You can go from Homestead to Everglade City in a inside road (61 km) Amazing view!!!

We visited this side of the Everglades National Park twice from our base in Florida City. The day we arrived we were lucky enough to get to the visitor centre in Flamingo just before it closed and found out about the ranger-led canoe trips at 8am. We rang the following day to book in for Day 3 only to find they were fully booked and starting a wait list. We went on the wait list, turned up at 7.45 and ended up on a stunning 3-hour canoe trip on the '9 mile pond' canoe trail. For zero dollars! The ranger (Sarah) was a superb guide and the scenery was wonderful.

I absolutely loved this place. The wildlife, the trails, the lush greenery, The Everglades is not like anywhere else I've ever been! Paying a small entrance fee just after the visitors centre, the park opens up to all its beauty. Unfortunately, due to the effects of Hurricane Irma, sections of the park were still closed. This included the Gumbo Limbo trail and Flamingo but luckily, the Anhinga trail was still open and we followed it. Our first stop was Royal Palm, which was a beautiful place to stop for your first trail. Lily pads for as far as the eye can see, with alligators, fish and birds. We followed the road all the way to Flamingo, even though we knew that the visitor centre was closed. But the drive was incredible with many stops along the way. This is a truly magical place.

This is a great venue for gay people and friends. Probably good to point that out at the start to avoid feeling out of place! The route to get there with the LIRR train/shuttle/ferry package is fantastic and works so seamlessly ($36 each, return included). I was really impressed.

There are 2 loops to walk, one is half a mile, the other a mile. It is flat, easy walking. However, the main fossils you see are of tree stumps and the best examples are right outside the visitor Centre doors. $5 adult entry is about right.

Apache Pass separates the Chiricahua and Dos Cabezas Mountains in South East Arizona, not far from Willcox. The US Army built Fort Bowie to protect the pass when they were struggling against the Chiricahua Apaches for control of the region. There is a 3 mile round trip hike to see the remains of the Fort and it is very interesting with markers and explanatory signs along the way, past a cemetery, the ruins of the Butterfield Stage Station and the vital Apache Spring with its constant supply of water in a very dry area.

Visited with our 3 boys (15,13,11) and spent a couple of hours checking out the fort, museum, movie and the trail to the canoe landing. Really cool stuff to explore and very knowledgeable rangers. Great way to learn about Lewis and Clark's expedition. Costs $5 per adult to get in (15 and under are free) but we had bought a 5 day Oregon Coast Park Pass at a state park further south and it covered our entrance fee foe both adults! Awesome deal :)

The staff was really friendly, we bought an Oregon State Park Pass and watched the video of the trip west. We walked the short trail to the fort and enjoyed the great outdoors similar to the times of when the explorers were there.

If you like history and hiking this is the place. Learn about the end of Lewis & Clark's voyage and their winter camp from 1805 into 1806. The video was a little corny but the indoor exhibit (maps, tools, canoe, etc.) were terrific and the costumed interpreters surrounding the reconstructed fort were very knowledgeable and entertaining. They brought to life the daily experience for the members of the Corps of Discovery. It rained all by 12 days over 3 months!! Then, take short (or long) hike on some of the nearby trails and imagine yourself trying to hunt in the mud and thick forests. Another great National Park. Can easily do in a day along with Ft. Stevens, or a trip to Seaside or Cannon Beach. Fee was $3 but very worth it. They also take the National Park Pass.

We stopped here during spring break and enjoyed our visit. The staff were really friendly and helpful. We decided to fork over $80 to get an annual national parks pass otherwise it costs $3 per adult to get in. The movie is good and there is a nice exhibition of artifacts from the time of Lewis and Clark in the visitors center. There are also nice walking trails around the visitors center which were good. But, this whole area is interesting - Astoria and the mouth of the Columbia River plus Cannon Beach so the whole area is worth going to as well as the visit to Fort Clatsop.

If you love history (especially Lewis & Clark) this is a great place to visit. The park is very clean & well maintained & has a wonderful visitor center with lots of helpful rangers & staff. They were awesome with our grandson who had completed is Jr Ranger booklet & with other kids who had earned their, too. They have a gift shop & a nice museum with some wonderful artifacts & of course the fort itself which is like stepping back in time. It's furnished as though the corps are living there & they have volunteers who are dressed in period clothes & will gladly answer all your questions & are very knowledgeable. They also have daily demonstrations on life in the L&C days at the fort. We watched the musket presentation & it was GREAT! Fun for old & young alike, especially kids learning about L&C or NW history. There are hiking trails & they even have free canoe trips each day during the summer. We had a very enjoyable time here. Fee is minimal & well worth it.

The audio tour $3 was excellent using clips from former residents set in context. Allow. Enough time to amble round and chat to the knowledgable volunteers. A great start to our American Rockies tour.
The fort is a delight to see. Because a boat is needed to get over to the fort, make sure you are there early. The place was busier than I thought it would be. Tickets are free but they are timed.

This park is run by the US National Park Service and is actually free admission unlike the larger fort in St Augustine where you will pay $10 plus parking. Fort Matanzas was built by the Spanish to guard the inlet there from the Atlantic Ocean south of St Augustine. The area is quite beautiful and a great estuary with lots of birds, dolphins and other wild life. Every hour (at the half hour) a boat takes you on a short ride from the main park to the fort. You will need to get free tickets from the Welcome Center for the boat. Within the main park there is a nice nature trail with an elevated boardwalk OK for wheelchair access. The small parking area gets really crowded on weekends. It is about a 15-20 drive south from St Augustine on A1A. If you would like to have free and easy access to the Matanzas River for in-shore fishing this is a good spot.

A nice educational side trip to this outpost. And cheap. Old Spanish outpost rebuilt by the park services. Your tax dollars at work so you may as well check it out. Goes nicely with the big fort in the bay.

Passed this by chance on the way to St Augustine and, since National Monuments are usually excellent, decided to stop and look. As we drove in saw a sign 'Boats leave on the half hour'. Picked up tickets in Visitors' Centre with moments to spare for short boat ride to fort. Excellent birdlife.

So quaint. You're ferried across the inland waterway via a little pontoon boat. not too crowded because the boat acn only hold so many people at a time. Up close and personal guides are there to answer questions. great wildlife, great phtos and got to explore the fort and hear the history. It's a mini version of the big fort in town but that one costs a small fortune to get into. This one was just a couple of $. Way prefferred.

A visit to Baltimore has to include a trip to Fort McHenry. The staff do a great job of explaining the history and importance of this fort. Pay for the pass that allows access to the museum and fort. There is a good balanced presentation about the War of 1812. The best way to get to Fort McHenry is via water taxi from Fells Point.

Wonderful place to learn more about the war of 1812 and the night that inspired Francis Scott Key's national anthem for the United States. It only costs $7 and you are welcomed with a video which provides the backdrop of Fort McHenry's historical significance. This a must see if you are in Baltimore. If you're lucky, you'll catch the changing of the flags and possibly be a part of it too! Plus there's lots of open space for young ones to run.

I-95 exit 55. Take McComas to key Highway, N on Key Hwy to E Fort St. E Fort St. East into the Locust Point neighbourhood and the Fort. Fine example of a Star-type fort, built for Harbor protection on the site of former Fort Whetstone during the 1790s, and named after Revolutionary War surgeon and Secretary of War James McHenry. Easy parking. Open 9-5. Flag raising and lowering at 10:15 and 5:15. $7 to get into the actual fort area. A must to check the website due to seasonal changes. Site of the writing of the poem 'Star Spangled Banner', set almost immediately to the tune of 'To Anacreon in Heaven' - a popular English drinking song. Francis Scott Key wrote it from the deck of HMS Tonnant as a prisoner. He had gone aboard the British vessel to negotiate a prisoner release/exchange, but while aboard became too familiar with the strength of the British fleet and their intention to attack Baltimore. Therefore he himself was seized and held prisoner! Most of the remains of the fort are intact. What was most interesting to me was that the Fort's principal defences were manned in 1814 against the attacking British ships by U.S. Navy guns and gunners! Not U.S. Army guns and gunners! Well done Navy!!! See the 10 minute video first, sign up for the 'War in the Chesapeake' Talk (one of the best NPS talks in the nation). Excellent Gift Shop. Take a drink with you, it gets warm. Fort Street and Locust Point area has many restaurants and stores (examples: Miguel's Cocina, Himalayan House Indian, L.P. Steamers Crabcakes, Chipotle, Ledo Pizza, Subway and yes, even a McDonalds). Enjoy!

We took the Banner Circulator bus (free!) from the Inner Harbour to Fort McHenry. It lets you off at the entrance to the area and it is a pleasant walk to the Visitor's Center. As others have said, the staff at the Center is very helpful, even recommended that we purchase the pass for seniors to all National Parks - at $10.00 this is a huge savings. After watching the film in the Visitor's Center - be sure and watch this before you walk out to the fort - we walked to the fort and spent an hour walking around it, reading the information and visiting the buildings inside the fort. It is beautifully restored. This should be the #1 place to visit in Baltimore! The next day we visited the Flag House where Mary Pickersgill made the famous flag - again, an important place to visit for anyone intererested in the War of 1812 battle that took place at Baltimore.

This was a suggestion by someone else so I wasn't sure what to expect, the parking lot was full, but as it covers a large area it didn't seem crowded. Cost is 7.00 but my companion had an annual pass so no charge for us. Parking is free. Saw the video presentation & it was very well done & highly recommended gives you a clear understanding of what you will be seeing. After that presentation you can walk around & view the interactive exhibits in the visitors center. From there you walk over to the fort. As it is the 200th anniversary there is much to see. There were several re-enactors (military & civilian) a fife & drum corp & cannon firing. Volunteers & rangers to answer any question you might have or to lead tours. It reminded me of Fort Moultrie (not the shape) but the magazines & bomb-proofs being a good place to duck into to get out of the sun & get cool! Bring a hat & wear your sunblock.

On a fine day, no better place in Baltimore. The site is extremely well preserved and the visitor centre is a great addition. The video on the war with the dastardly Brits is very good, but it was a bit unexpected when the screen rose to reveal the flag on the fort in the distance when everyone stood up and joined in with the words, hands clutched on hearts, all very serious. Not the way we Brits behave, maybe we should! Very similar to the fort in Halifax, Nova Scotia, could easily have come out of the same catalogue. Good value for $7 for adults.

Well staffed exhibit, very helpful employees, and insightful information. A bargain at $7 per adult. My kids enjoyed it too. The introductory movie was awesome. My only complaint is that it was 95 degrees and the drink machines were sold out. A concession area would be nice (and provide another revenue stream for the park).

Get the all-day water taxi pass ($14) and take in the harbor sights along the way to the monument. The exhibits are well done, showing accommodations for the privates on up. The full-size replica of the flag that stirred Francis Scott Key to write the Star Spangled Banner was flying when we were there but they do fly different flags depending on weather conditions. The full-size one is huge!

Most people are drawn here for the history, but I also find Fort McHenry to be a perfectly enjoyable spot to spend a lazy summer Sunday with friends / family, a picnic, and a frisbee. Very peaceful place to watch the boats in the harbor, maybe fly a kite. A note to those who prefer to pack along a mimosa thermos or brewski - alcohol is forbidden, and there are rangers who periodically surface to check on everything, but for the most part, with discretion, you can responsibly enjoy your beverage in peace. I would also add that there is a fee to enter the museum, but it's debatable whether just sitting on the grass has any cost (I assumed not and had no troubles, but would gladly have put up a few dollars for several hours of undisturbed, shady bliss).

Driving there is already half the fun. The road is narrow and winding, offering nice views. On arrival you should go to the visitor center to gather some information, watch a little introductory movie and get an area map. There are quite a few nice places for a picnic. The dwellings are just two miles down the road from the visitor center. A few dollars entrance fee is due if you have not one of the annual passes for the National Parks/Monuments. Volunteers provide you with some more information and send you up the trail to the dwellings. It is a one mile round trip. Don't miss out on the free ranger tour at 1 pm! This is the best way to really see the dwellings and imagine what was going on there hundreds of years ago. Without the ranger most people just walk through, missing the somewhat hidden petroglyphs and stories behind.

We really enjoyed this experience, there were very few people around which made it easier to visualise what a hard life it must have been. The climb up is not too bad, plenty of steps to help and the caves make it worth the effort. We drove in on 35 via Emory Pass, a really scenic route. We found 35 to be better than 15 down to Silver City. There are no road markings for most of the way and the road is very twisty and narrow in places. In itself this doesn't matter but most of the traffic coming the other way was in the middle of the road which made for a few near misses on blind corners. This park is a little of the beaten track but so worth a visit.

First was the winding drive north of Silver City, with breathtaking views. Next was touring the interpretive center to obtain a sound feeling on who made the cliff houses, when it was done and how important it was to make this a National Monument to preserve this history. Our January walk to the cliffs was cool (below freezing), giving us a feeling of just how the local peoples would have endured. Volunteer guides explained all aspects at the cliff site and we were able to walk into many of the living and working quarters. Admission charge was so very minimal. Highly recommended for all ages, but you must be capable of a little bit of walking and climbing.

It had snowed overnight so it was a long snowy drive in. When we finally arrived it was well worth the effort. We thought we would be the only ones there but that was not the case many had also made the trip also. The volunteers that manage the sight are excellent and very friendly. The few dollars it cost is well worth it! We quite enjoyed the whole day.

We travelled from Logan to this Historic site and it was quite a scenic drive. Passing through small towns you become more aware of the vastness and isolation of the area. With the windows down you can hear the monument before you see it. It does feel as if you are driving in the middle of nowhere and this highlights the feat of engineering that joined two sides of a continent. The staff in the visitor centre were very helpful and had answers to every question. You are able to get up close to the engine and Jupiter was on show the day we were there. The detail on the engine was extraordinary with plenty of character. When you look around there is virtually nothing to be seen for miles and you can only imagine the hardship faced by the people who built this railway. This is a testament to the endurance and technical ability of Humankind.

Seriously - go. Every American should see this and appreciate exactly how it progressed our country. The actors were awesome- the costumes are great- you can get right up to the both trains and take pictures with the cast. $7 to get in and worth every penny

We did the grand discovery air tour. The tour lasted 45 min. We booked at viators. We booked a morning tour well in advance. When we arrived a day earlier it was very easy to reschedule the trip to that day in the afternoon. We preferred the airplane trip over the helicopter trip because of the costs and the duration. A little warning might be in place since 2 of our group of 5 got a bit airsick. We flew a rather small plan with 8 passengers with a great view for everyone. If you want to be sure of a window seat in a larger plane it is possible to reserve window seats in advance for additional costs of $10 per seat. My eldest son was very happy because he was allowed to sit in front next to the pilot. The staff was very friendly. And the most important thing: the views are amazing! You can hardly imagine the magnitude and size of the grand canyon till you have seen it. Enjoy your flight!
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: We went for the connoisseur package inc return transfer to Boulder Airport, return flight to the north rim, helicoper ride, coach to Bright Angel lookout point, packed lunch. It was expensive at $908 for the two uf us but it was a superb experience.
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: The flight I took over the Grand Canyon was a fantastic experience. I would thoroughly recommend it. The plane trip was the cheapest option for seeing the canyon from the air. I was very happy with the experience and would recommend it to anyone who does not want to pay top dollar. As I did it do w helicopter flight, I can not compare it with this option.
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: My girlfriend always wanted to see the great canyon from above so we bite the bullet and did. Prices are very reasonable considering what your doing. We took off with a handful of other people and flew completely over the whole grand canyon. It was a breathtaking experience and should not be missed if you have the opportunity.
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: At just over a thousand dollars for 2 for the day, it was packed full of adventure! Flight from Vegas to the canyon, then into a helicopter to the bottom of the canyon. Hop into a pontoon boat for a short ride along the Colorado river at the base of the Canyon, then the return trip to the top. Hop on a coach and go to Eagles Point for the best photo opportunities (forget the Skywalk-total ripoff as you cannot take your camera with you) but you can pay for a photo! Then to the next point for lunch, more great shots...everywhere you look!
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: the trip was amazing but when we arrived home to find they had taken the full cost from my card and the deposit on top of it so ended up paying 160 more and they ignor requests for the payment info. and they keep your reciept when you check in. you have no prove and they dont respond what a disapointment to the trip. RIP OFF merchants
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: This was the highlight of our entire tour to America. It was the reason that I came on this holiday. I was absolutely delighted when we booked our 399 dollar exact plane fight and were so looking forward to it. We found out about an hour and a half before the flight that it had been rescheduled. ( reason unknown) The timing of this conflicted with other activities of the day so we were rescheduled to a 45 minute helicopter ride that afternoon. We actually arrived at the airport only to be turned away and being told that it was too windy for a safe flight.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: Though low budged we decided to pay 199$ for that trip.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: we booked the 50 minutes round trip for 299 dollars each person; a reservation is recommended, as the flights are booked out very fast;
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: Two of our party were in the middle two back seats of the Helicopter. We had a wonderful view of the backs of the heads of the front passengers. What a waste of $US279.00 each. ( approximately $NZ436.00 each, or a good part of a weeks wages after tax for most New Zealanders.) A big mistake. Full price for those two seats is a total rip off. Will never take middle back seats in Helicopter again. Very Very disappointing.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: We planned our US trip for 12 months, and spent a heap of time researching different operators and tours - and hearing horror stories about hidden charges, incorrect bookings, and the rest. After all that, we chose to take a Grand Kingdom tour with Grand Canyon Helicopters and it was absolutely the holiday highlight for all of us. It cost NZ$1200 for 4 (2 adults, 12 and 10yo), or US880, and it was worth every single cent.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: A 45 minute helicopter ride over the Grand Canyon was one of the best things I have done in my life. I could not believe how emotional I felt and how insignificant I was in the history of the world amidst this natural wonder that has taken millions of years to form. The short commentary provides information before you just sit and marvel. I unashamedly cried. It was simply spectacular, breath taking, astounding and magnificent. So spend the dollars, it may seem a lot when you are travelling but nothing beats seeing this brilliant natural wonder away from the thousand of tourists on the ground so busy photos with their selfie sticks that they fail to see.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: Being of the view that I will quite probably only get the chance to visit the Canyon once, and making the most of each stop in my tour from the east to the west coast of the states, the helicopter ride over and in the canyon was never a question. Though I paid $275, for 45 minutes, I can definitely say it was worth every dollar. The close proximity to the canyon is priceless. Our pilot was great, and I was thrilled to be co-pilot, with probably the best views of the ride. He played music in the background of the ride, and as we flew over the forestry and dipped into the canyon listening to Coldplay Paradise, I really did feel like I was in Paradise. That feeling alone, is worth the money. As one of the wonders of the world, I feel like you have to take the helicopter ride to truly appreciate the size and beauty of the canyon. There's great views of the Colorado river, and our pilot chatted throughout, pointing out interesting elements of the canyon. Of course the ride doesn't last long enough, but it's unforgettable. Make the most of your trip to the canyon, don't be tight, and make a great memory! Highly, highly recommend. ( I didn't book through a company, just at the helicopter desk at the Canyon itself)
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: $750 for two was pricey but worth it if the experience was truly awesome. But it wasn't. Flight to GC was long and the view of the GC was very brief. We basically dropped into a bend in the river; not much actual flying through the canyon. Quite unspectacular, especially after we saw the grander views from the national park visitor center. I would not repeat and save the money.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: We were very nervous booking our reservation online as it was $900+, however all went smoothly with Papillion Grand Canyon Helicopter Tours promptly emailing the confirmation. We called 24 hours in advance as recommended to confirm our booking. The helicopter terminal is at Grand canyon national park airport outside of Tusayan a 20min drive from the park (you drive past it on the way in). We arrived a little early and they bumped our flight to an earlier on which was nice. There were 5 of us. I was hoping to give all the kids (3) a window seat but due to weight distribution in the helicopter we were allocated our seating. In saying that I think we all had good views and took some good photos through the windows. For most of us it was our first helicopter flight so we were so excited, it was very smooth, however 3 of us did end up feeling a little airsick about half way through the 45min flight (most of which is over the canyon). Very expensive but as a one in a lifetime event worth it.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: I had an accident and tore the meniscus in my right knee which will require surgery. Wrote to Grand American Adventures to request for a transfer of my spot on the Grand Canyon and Zion 11 days walking tour in November to next year, All that I’ve got in the dozen of emails I received was “100% no refund”. I wasn’t asking for a refund but a reschedule since they have numerous such tours throughout the year and It’s a medical condition that I suffer from, with a full ER report and surgery booking to prove. I chose to spend $2,700 on a walking tour with this company because they are British and I have a stupid sense of camaraderie, which now seems to be extremely foolish since there are hundreds other US companies that offer cheaper tours with the possibility of company credit for trip cancellation in case of medical emergency. I find this tour company very unhelpful, inflexible and most importantly, unethical. #donotjoin #grandamericanadventures

I visited with family, my mom in particular had difficulty in walking but nature guide us through and it was a lifetime experience..... we came in the family car which cost us only $30 to enter the park and everything else are for free... as far as your eyes can see...we rode the free shuttle bus going to the most popular south rim as far as Hermits Rest... we stopped every single point and for me it was the Hopi point exceeds my expectations... Its worth every sweat and sore feet.. and it makes me wonder why people paid loads of money to enjoy the view when its for free?! So as an advice you can enjoy the experience without breaking the bank. The North Rim is actually just few minutes walks from the car park itself which wild animals are happily grazing and visitor friendly just try not to scare or bother them, you can take as much picture as you can...

Failure in planning the trip to grand Teton. Two days or more are strongly recommended. A park pass is required. If you visit Yellowstone and grand Teton together, one pass is good for both, as I remembered, $50/7days/two parks. Good to see sunset if you plan well.
We entered using the national park annual pass ("America the Beautiful" - cost $80.00 for two people). Otherwise entry is $30.00 per vehicle.

Absolutely spectacular! Loved the several hikes that we did: Lake Phelps to Death Canyon, Paintbrush Canyon, and Cascade Canyon. Even with less than desirable weather (rainy and chilly in July) the hikes were awesome, especially Cascade Canyon. The price of the boat ride across Jenny Lake to Inspiration Point and Cascade Canyon was a bit of a surprise for a short ferry ride ($15 RT). It does save around 2 miles to the trailhead so it was worth it to us to save our miles for the Canyon. Loved our visit and hope to return to hike again.

It is worth visiting Grand Teton especially if you are going to be visiting Yellowstone National Park as one fee covers both - when we visited it was $25 for a car (less for individuals accessing by foot/bike). We didn't do any of the walking trails but drove between the various sites. The scenery is spectacular and we tool lots of photos. We had average-showery weather and it was still beautiful to see and enjoyable.

travelled through the tetons on the way to Jackson hole. took some fantastic photos. Passed the lakes, some lovely mirror images. Snow capped mountains, impressive. Grand teton shows well above the other peeks.

When you enter the park you pay $25 dollars for a weeks pass which includes Yellowstone Park. We drove in to the park and within 5 mins out of the mist a stag appeared!! We then drove up the valley wow you can see the glaciers still in September.

I was there in late september 2012 to avoid the crowds...Ok but because of winter shutdown of the park only 2 campgrounds were open. Lots of wildlife, mostly bisons...nice autumn colours. Campgrounds without showers i found overpriced at 23$ and 20$ . Side gravel roads are open and in good shape. Lots of access to lakes and rivers for fishing and canoeing.

Coming from "down under" I had heard very little about this National park . Although the park is adjacent to Yellowstone National Park, it has its own, unique flavour. Make an extra day to spend time to See the Massive upright mountains, the lakes Surrounded by aspens and other trees and of course, the wild animals. The wildflowers are coming out beautifully at this time of year. The $25 you pay for a Seven day entry pass into the Yellowstone National Park also covers Grand Tetons.

This park has very scenic views and a great lake, There is a lot to do here I chose to go hiking up the most popular hiking trails and the view along the way of the lake and the park were breath taking. You can either catch the boat to where the hiking trail finishes and walk up to the waterfalls from there and you can catch the boat back to roughly where you start your hike I chose to catch the boat back, I think it was $6.00 one way cant remember the exact amount.

We camped in Great Basin, partially to see the stars because there is little light pollution and they are simply brilliant. We camped in a campsite on Snake Creek Road (which was free). We used campsite # 10 where we could hear the creek at night. They have a fire barrel so get your firewood at the town near the visitor center before you head up the road. The wood was $5 and was sold on the honor system opposite the gas pumps in town. (far side from the visitor center). There is a small store for food staples but it was pretty sparsely stocked.

Not the biggest of parks and located in the middle of nowhere but a great park with real diversity. The Lehman Cave - Great Palace guided tour was great, the ranger was really knowledgeable, happy to answer questions - it lasts 90 minutes and is well worth the $10 each. Rangers in the park visitor centre were really friendly and made you feel welcome.

My wife and I were there to see the magnificence of the sand dunes and to do some hiking. The hiking in the immediate vicinity of the visitor centre is okay but nothing to get too excited about. We did Mosca Pass on the first day and while a nice trail, it felt a bit of an anti-climax as the top of the trail didn't mark anything in particular. The sand dunes themselves are phenomenal. You have to see them to comprehend the scale. We hiked High Dune which is 700 ft high. Set off at 9am and can tell you it was hard yards in a few places. Stick to the ridges and you'll do fine. Don't climb the face of a dune - we did a short one and that was a bad move! Views from the top spectacular and worth the effort. If we had more time would have gone to Star Dune. Climb Dune Overlook as well if you have the time. It's not a long or difficult hike but provides a super view over the dune fields. We also went to Zapata Falls - you can see dune fields from there too but it's a bit far away to be any good. Oh, and if you want to take photos of the dunes, go early as the shadows are most dramatic at first light (at least in July they are). If you go at sunset, the sun is behind the dunes so you you're facing all shadow so much less dramatic.

Had a great fun time. We hired a sand sledge from a shop in Alamosa and it was well worth the $18 – so much fun! We stopped at the Visitor Centre first and the views of the sand dunes were amazing. Just a little way further down the road is the parking for the sand dunes which are about ½ mile walk from the parking lot. It was hard work walking on the sand, even more so, hiking up the sand dunes to slide down but so much fun. But when people say sand will go everywhere, they mean everywhere!!! But I must admit though I did have a quite spectacular wipe out on the sand sled! Near the parking lot is a picnic area with flush toilet and changing facilities.

If you want the sand sledding stop at Great Sand Dunes Oasis and rent a sleigh for 20$ plus tax. Stop at the visitor center and take directions for what you want. Leave early if you want to climb as it gets really hot. After, drive to the dunes parking. Before, get dome mosquito spray as the parking is heavily loaded with mosquitoes... Take also care as you need to cross a creek before getting to the dunes. After this small things, indulge the beauty. Sledding, hiking, walking, watching people, all together. A memorable visit but need some info...

Our Troop has camped here 4-5 times and find it a very inexpensive place to stay with easy access via the METRO (Greenbelt Station $14 all day pass). Sites for scouts very big, picnic table at each as well as grill. Weekend check in/out on honor system. Heated rest rooms!

I can't rate the whole park, as we only had 5-6 hours to explore it. But we went to the main visitor centre, and once we'd finally paid our $5/person fees (the ranger was busy with another customer, and we had to wait an age for him to finish.....meanwhile the other staff member standing around apparently couldn't take our fees from us) we did the hike to Devil's Hall. This was amazing - both the scenery all the way on the hike, and the final views when we got there - stunning! Would love to have had more time/days to explore some more.

If you go anywhere on the Island of Maui, you HAVE to go Haleakala National Park, especially for the sunrise. It takes as lot of effort to make the drive to the summit in time for a 6 am sunrise but it was a breathtaking experience. You MUST go the Park's website and make a reservation for your visit for $1.50. (sunrise only) No exceptions, you can't drive to the summit without one. The park visit is $20 but we bought a 3 park year pass for $30 as we visited other parks during our tour of some Hawaiian Islands. Be warned, it is darnn cold at the summit before sunrise and we had long pants and two layers of sweatshirts but as I said, its worth it. Many people go up the mountain for sunset and say it is great too. (no reservation required) We didn't hike any of the trails as they all looked a bit too challenging for us but the view from the summit is breathtaking, the drive is exciting both up and down and no matter when you go, you will be in awe of this mountain.

This park includes several trails, the sacred pools and the crater. When you pay for the parking, keep the receipt, you can visit the park again 3 more times without having to pay for parking again ($25).

This is a must see that is worth the $20 entrance fee. The winding road leads you through several climate zones where you will see the change in vegetation and feel the change in temperature. Take a jacket with you to the summit.

A scary as hell drive up the volcano but well worth the $20 car entry into the park. Don't look down as you drive but worth the trip to the summit. The temps can be much colder upwards of 30 degrees difference. The craters and cinder cones are pretty amazing. You will be high above the clouds and you can see many neighbouring mountains. Worth the visit.

Ok, I'm only doing 3 stars here because we missed the sunset due to weather. Hence the title. We did this the morning after our wedding for a symbolic sunrise to start our new lives together and while the sun did rise, the clouds and rain blocked the view from the summit. We probably would have gone anyway, but I wish I'd have checked the current summit conditions, which NPS does recommend. We were prepared for cold, but the rain and gale force winds made it a new challenge. My main thought upon seeing all the people in tour buses who paid $100+ a person was that wow, that sucks. The tours I'm sure don't reschedule you for a day when the weather is better and there was nothing to see.

The rates to get into the park are sky rocketing. It's really sad! They say your entrance fee will be good for a week - well that's just silly. No one goes up the volcano more than once per visit. Please, everyone, do complain about this!! By 2017: $20 for a motor cycle and $25 for a car!! Just terrible.﻿

Before you set off, have a full tank of gas, food and water - there are no amenities in the park. If you are hiking, be prepared, sunscreen, first aid kit and clothing appropriate for climate. Permits are required for overnight trips in to the wilderness area and are FREE. Available from the Headquarters Visitor Centre until 3pm. Well signposted from the main road. The road is 38 miles of winding 2 lane well paved surface. Be mindful of posted speed as there are many, many hairpin bends. This is a popular route to bike, up and down, so watch out for bikers at all times. Once you enter the park there are no guard rails so be very careful. There is a $20 entrance fee to the park which must be paid via credit card only. The ticket is good for 48 hours. The first visitor centre, the Headquarters Visitor Centre is just inside the park. Stop here for good information, a map of the park and bathrooms. From here it takes approx. 30 mins to reach the second visitor centre, the Haleakala Visitor Centre, open from sunrise until 12 noon. Many people like to go here to watch the sunrise. Again, lots of information about the park from knowledgeable park rangers. You can take many different hikes or just enjoy the ambiance of your surroundings. From here you can take a short drive to the summit, over 10,000ft. The observatory is off limits to the public but is the fourth best place on the planet to view the universe. On the drive from the base, don't be put off by the change in weather. You may encounter sun, rain, overcast, low cloud all within 20 mins or so, but keep going - it's worth it! If you are a nervous driver or don't like heights it may be an idea to take a tour rather than drive yourself, especially in the dark (going up to experience the sunrise).

The trip up the volcano through the clouds and reaching the summit (10000+feet) were one the highlights of our trip to Maui. The views of the crater and the clouds are fantastic as well as the views of West Maui on the way or down. Make sure you bring your camera and check the weather before you leave. It costs $20 (no cash card only) to enter the park and plan to stay for 2 - 3 hours.

So much fun to drive to the top of maui. 20 dollar entry fee to park and they take credit cards. Bathrooms just past the park entrance and at the summit. Can't believe I forgot our jackets. Bring some warm clothes if you go. Felt like we were on the moon... so barren. Watch out for bicycles going up and down as there is no shoulder. Stop at the Kula lodge on your way back down for yummy food and more breathtaking views.

We did not realise until it was too late that you needed a reservation for sunrise. Anyway we decided to go up anyway. It is a fairly long drive from Kapulua the route is close to 40 miles that winds its way up the mountain. The national park cost $25 dollars for a car to go in but the ticket is valid for two days. Their are great views on the way up but absolutely stunning views from the top. Looking into the crater is like being on another planet. As other have mentioned it very cold at the summit so take warm clothing. Also there is no food or drinks sold in the park so you need to take what you need with you. If we ever come to Maui again I will be better prepared and make sure I book the sunrise tickets

If you can, a must do visit when in Maui. Breath taking views! To see the sun rise from 10,000 ft is amazing. When the sun broke the horizon a docent at the park started a Hawaiian chant to welcome the sun. After that she gave some history and info on the island. Very interesting. It is cold so layer (48 degrees) and be early as the parking fills fast. $15 entrance fee, no cash, credit card only. Check sunrise times and travel time from where you are staying and plan to get there at least 1/2 hr before sunrise. Bathrooms and a visitor center/gift shop at the top.

If you go make sure you make it to the crater! We drove up into the park on our own ($10 day admission, but good for a week at all the National Parks on Maui and Hawaii). We arrived here about 10am after a 2 hour drive from Lahaina. I had been years ago, and it was less crowded, but I was still struck by how beautiful this place is. The crater is arid and silent, and the colors and hues just amaze. We did a brief (30minute) hike down part of the Sliding Sands trail, which was the best opportunity to get away from the crowds at the visitor center and Red Hill summit viewing area. Remember to bring plenty of water. Do to the altitude and the low humidity you will get very thirsty.

Weather at sea level was in the 80s...temperatures dropped to a cool 65 degrees F at the summit. The ride up was mostly in cloud but the summit was sunny! The summit vista was as expected...quite grand. We were at the summit ~10:45am ahead of tour buses and vans which was nice.
