For those who seek to see a Silver Sword plant the extra little ride up past the summit visitor centre had a "SilverSword" garden in the middle of the parking lot (small medium and blooming SilverSwords...along with a few dead remains). There were no Nene today. Heading out of the park at noon we noticed a building line of vehicles waiting to pay the gate fee($15/car)
$15 for entrance to the park, but it is good for 3 days.

Our cruise ship docked at Kahului, Maui. We rented a car at Kahului airport. It took more than 1 hour drive from port to Haleakala National Park. There are two visitor centers in the park, one at park entrance, the other at top of the mountain. There is a $10 entrance fee per car.

First tip: You have to leave your hotel by no later than 4am to be able to see the sunrise from the top of the crater. This was my third visit to the crater, but the first time I was able to make it in time to see the sunrise and it was well worth it. And yes, there will be people up that early in the morning to head to Haleakala, believe me. The entrance is $5 per person, and there is a ranger there that early to take your money. I stayed on the Ka'anapali side of the island and we made it with about 30 minutes to spare before the sunrise. IT IS COLD AT THE SUMMIT, SO BRING JACKETS AND SWEATS. Don't let the warm Hawaiian days fool you, it gets cold up 10,000 above sea level. The road is narrow and winding, so bring a lot of patience and maybe motion sickness pills if you are prone to it. Once you get up to the summit, there are trails to hike so definitely bring food, water, a backpack, sunscreen, hat, and walking shoes.

This natural wonder is not be missed. The views you experience on the drive to the summit are just as spectacular as at the summit so at only $10.00 per vehicle for a three day pass to the park it is the most affordable and special thing you can do on the island. You don't need to be up there for sunrise as you will enjoy the park and it's trails all day long. Our first attempt to see the crater was hilarious as we got up early for the sunrise only to be clouded in and even though it was 38f it felt like minus 38 with the wind chill, it was still an unique experience. We were awarded with blue skies the next day to be amazed at the views of the crater from Kalahaku Overlook, this outlook gives you the best view of the crater. The colors at sunset were even better then sunrise.

An American National Park. No words can improve on that. That says it all – Thanks John Muir and the thousands that have followed in your footsteps. I’ve been to many and each seems to be better than the next – but I think that’s due to each making me a little more complete. Haleakalā is no exception. It’s like the Grand Canyon surrounded by the breathtaking blue Pacific. What a feast for the eyes – for all the senses! A wonderfully spiritually fulfilling day. Now for some details. This was an absolutely hassle free trip. You get to drive to the very top of the volcano (10,000+ ft) in about an hour from sea level. The purest won’t like a road in the park but there is plenty of wilderness and hard hiking to go around. The park is not anywhere near crowded and the Rangers (like most Hawaiians) are really nice and make you feel like they want you there. The Rangers are also remarkably knowledgeable and happy to share their experience. If you want to camp they’ll set you up at the park entrance – no worries or preparation needed. It costs $10 to get in the park. This trip is an unequivocal must do! Finally, I didn’t do this but a sunrise visit must be outta this world.

Haleakala National Park is not just the summit of the volcano as some reviewers seem to describe. The Park covers an area of 33,265 acres. The entrance of the entire park is $10 and is good for a three day period. The park is divided into two distinct sections: the summit area and the coastal Kipahulu area.

We decided on seeing sunset at the summit so we could enjoy the drive up and we are so glad we did, We were amazed at the change in landscapes as we got higher and the view going up was something to see and experience. Take note the ticket booth doesn't give change for your park pass so have the $10 per car. Once at the top we stopped at the crater lookout.....that is a sight in itself looking over into that vast area with all the changes in colors.. Wow. We arrived at the summit lookout about 45 min from sunset.. Took a look around at the observation area with all the great information, It was cold and windy but we were prepared and dressed for the occasion, Our biggest laugh of the day was seeing everyone wrapped in the striped hotel towels and even one lady in a bedspread. Not everyone reads trip advisor before taking this trip I guess :). As the sun went down I realized that the observatory that is at the summit (not open to public) sits directly in front of where the sunset would take place so after a few photos and some deliberation we decided our best view would be a little down the mountain at one of the lookouts so that's what we did and it was amazing, the view of sunset was stunning. We stopped at a couple different places and even made it out of the park area before dark. Maybe the sun sets a bit farther north so the observatory isn't always in the way but in December it sure was. I'm glad we chose to descend for some shots, This was worth the drive and even if you aren't keen on sunrise do this instead, Equally amazing!

The drive up the mountain is about 30 miles of switchbacks . There is a self administered machine where you pay 10 dollars and get a ticket for your dashboard. The visitors center has some useful information in it and clean bathrooms, there is a small cabin at the next level to get away from the wind . The personnel in there were really knowledgable and then at the highest level there is one more building in which there are signs so you can read about what you are seeing . The views are amazing . It looks like what Mars or the moon might look like. Expect lots of changes of temperature, maybe rain in spots and fog that comes and goes . Well worth the gas and time

Went to the mountain to see the sunset, even though Lonely Planet advised against it. We drove two hours from Paia and arrived at 6pm, just above the rain clouds, we watched a glorious sunset by 6:50. Well worth the $10 entrance fee, that gives you access for three days.

Four of us hired a car and drove up to Haleakala. The road is windy but quite wide and well marked. Be careful though as there are cyclists and skate boarders to be weary of. We did not see any cows on the road, but were warned about them. Entrance into the park was $10.00 for the car.

If you do only one thing on Maui visit the volcano. The vistas are breathtaking. Like the Grand Canyo it is a real challenge to take photos that will do it justice so have patience. It was only $10 per vehicle for a visit. We loved the winding road. It was in great shape. We saw the Hawaiian state bird, the Nene, and some wild goats. Bring you coat and hat. It's cold up there at 10,000 feet.
Drove up Crater Road for the sunrise. Left our Hotel early morning at about 245 to reach around 5 in the morning. Very cold up there at 10000 Feet.

I'm sure sunrise is spectacular, but midday, if it's clear, is also amazing! Ranger says that the reflected heat of the crater means that you can usually see into the "crater" (actually an eroded valley with cinder cones) even when cloudy. I've been here twice, once (November) when it was socked in and drizzling and I nearly froze. It was gorgeous with a gorgeous view this time, looking out all the way to West Maui, and south to the Big Island, but wow, the wind will almost blow you over! If you can hit up a ranger talk at the lookout tower at the very top, do go! It was very informative about native birds, ecotones, plants, geology, etc. And the lookout is glassed in and out of the wind. Love the silversword plants. It was National Parks Week, so there was no admission that week (normally $10).

We did both sides (Kipahulu and the Crater) and would highly recommend spending as much time as possible at this incredible park. The topography changes vastly depending on where you are in the park. The Kipahulu area is on the ocean and is lush and tropical. The other side of the park climbs to 10,000 feet above sea level and you can see the changes in plant life as you acend the mountain. It's approx 20 degrees cooler at the top - it was cold and foggy the day we went and too windy to hike. Our only disappointment was not being able to have a better view of the crater. The park pass if $10/car and is good for 3 consecutive days (not really feasible to do both sides of the park on the same day).

We visited May 31, the day was sunny. We first drove through the town, then out to the visitor's parking area. There's a $10 park entrance fee for drivers. We took the free shuttle bus to the lower town and got off and walked around, up and down the historic streets. There is a walking bridge next to the railroad line crossing the Potomac and Shenandoah River. Many hikers climbed the mountains nearby. Really a beautiful place loaded with history.

This park where 3 states and 2 rivers merge is a must. Entrance is $10 per car and is valid for 3 days. A bus takes you to the old town center every 15 minutes. Take water and if you walk along the river, take a spray against the many small midgies. Watch the movie screened every 30 minutes, lasting 15 minutes. Take a picnic basket. Take many pictures, it is full of history and beautiful.

I'm not sure the exact boundaries of the park as it applies to the Appalachian Trail (AT) but the Loudoun Heights trail to the south/southwest of the Harper's Ferry city centre is a must! It's rated as difficult by the NPS, and features an ascent of ~1200 feet with the first 2 miles. The closest trailhead is at the junction of Route 340 and Shenandoah Rd; cost is $10 for the day.

Harper's Ferry National Park encompasses the town of Harper's Ferry, WV, as well as the civil war battlefield at Bolivar Heights, and the surrounding heights in Maryland and Virginia. We loved the little town of Harper's Ferry! Positioned where the Potomac River meets the Shenandoah River. Three states, two rivers, one National Park!!! We had half expected it to be like a theme park - how wrong can you be. Park your car up the hill for $10, courtesy of the National Park, pick up their informative leaflet and hop on their shuttle bus, which takes you to the lower town. There are exhibits in many of the "shops" .....make sure you see the film on the history of the town in one of the first shops you come to on the right hand side, before you explore further afield. It really sets the scene for you in terms of how the town grew from its humble beginnings into such an important place in American history. Other must sees are John Brown''s fort and museum along with the site of the US Armoury, the "Harper House", the Catholic Church, Jefferson's Rock, the riverside, the pedestrian bridge to Maryland and the C&O Canal, the Appalachian Trail and the riversides. There are also cafes, restaurants and pubs as well as gift and craft shops in the two main streets up the hill. Take care as you wander the streets as motor vehicles are allowed in the town (limited parking). It really is a brilliant place to wander around and the history of it makes it even more special. Unfortunately, we did not have enough time to tour the battlefield as we were on route elsewhere. Don't make the same mistake!!! Give yourself a whole day to see everything!

Visited Harper's Ferry and was surprised by the history and quaint beauty of the town. It really is a walking museum that takes you back in time. We only spent a few hours there on a Sunday afternoon in winter, where the days are short. We managed to capture some beautiful photos over the water as the sunset as well as visit a numbers of the museum and shop recreations. Highly recommend allowing at least 4 hours and I'm sure you would need longer on warmer days as imagine it's very busy. We were able to park near the train station which costs $10 for your pass. Alternatively there is parking further away with a free shuttle to the historic part of town. Entry to the various historical houses and shops is free.

This is where the slow slide toward Civil War became a strident March! In October of 1859 John Brown and 21 other abolitionists seized the armoury in this town and attempted to incite a slave rebellion in Virginia and throughout the South. The raid was put down after a siege by a detachment of Marines led by Colonel Robert E. Lee, and Brown was executed for treason against the State of Virginia. The town is at the confluence of the Shenandoah and Potomac rivers, and is 67 miles northwest of the Capitol in D.C. by way of I-270 and U.s. Highway 340 W. The Natioanl Park is open from 9 am to 5 pm, and the entrance fee is $10 per car. You park at the Visitor Center and take the Shuttle Bus into Harpers Ferry. One leaves every 15 minutes for the town. Once there the temptation is there to wonder what all the fuss s all about. But when you realise that the entire town is either a preservation or a replication, and when you look around at the hiking trails, the views and nature all around, you begin to understand what this Park is all about. There are many museums, gift shops, historical plaques and other exhibits describing various properties on High, Shenandoah, Potomac, and neighbouring streets. The Potomac Grille, Scoops Ice Cream and the Cannonball Deli are all excellent choices. You will wish that there was more air conditioning in these places, but remember - the town is 'preserved'! Lots of uneven surfaces and several steep paths and stairways. Harpers Ferry is about at the mid-point south to north on the Appalachian Trail, and visitors should take the short, steep walk up to Jefferson's Rock to take in the overview of both the town and the rivers. Take a walk along the B&O Canal, an historic portion of which is still there. Walk along the riverbank, or across the railroad trestle for other stunning views. And then there is the terrain itself, the woods and hills. Beautiful, and a big change from the barely rolling flats of the tidewater! Enjoy!

Delightful. For the $10 fee you can hop the shuttle and avoid parking hassles = well worth it. The town is delightful, interesting with good local beer in the tavern!! I loved the little museum that has the old machinery that made the rifles for the war. John Brown was here before he mouldered, there is an intricate trestle for the trains and the Point gives an excellent view of the confluence of the Shenandoah and Potomac rivers. One of the little stores sells objects made from soft Virginia coal - one was a train and we called it John! I bought a pig.

Visited May, second stop of our 5 week, RV tour of the American civil war battle fields. It is full of history and a very beautiful place, it has lots of original building, that are open for you to look round. It is run along the similar lines as Beamish and the Black Country living history Museum's in the UK. The key features are, John Browns raid, and the Armoury. Whilst we were there reenacters were giving demonstrations, on the different types of rifles and musket used in civil war. We stayed on the KOA site which is at the entrance of Harpers ferry national park. It is only a very short drive from the camp ground to the visitors center, plenty of parking for cars and RVs. At the visitors center there is a large museum and film shows plus reenactments, after the visitors center a shuttle bus will take you to a Harpers ferry historic centre. Every thing is included in the parks entrance fee which is $10 per car or RV and all its passengers. It is really outstanding value. If intending visiting quite a few NATIONAL PARKS, it my be worth while buying a $80 national park pass, this gives you entry in to all the national parks throughout America for 12 months from the date of purchase.

I visited the park in late November, when it was quite chilly and windy. The scenery, including the rivers, mountains, and trees were beautiful, and I kept thinking about how I couldn't wait to return to see the different variations each season would present. There was an entrance fee of $10/car to enter the park. We took the short shuttle ride from the main entrance down to the riverfront, but in retrospect, had I understood that we could have driven ourselves and parked, I probably would have done the latter, as there was not much to see at the main visitor area. The shuttle ride did include a short audio introduction, though, and that was a nice touch. There were several exhibits housed in the individual buildings surrounding the riverfront, and the bookstore had lots of nice gifts and sundry items. The privately owned shops and restaurants seems quaint and fairly reasonably priced. There is a train station right in the town, so that would be a nice way to travel for a different spin. The Appalachian Trail runs right through the park, too, so I am looking forward to returning in warmer weather to explore at least a bit of that. Finally, I would just point out that there is a driving tour map available at the visitor centers, and we visited a few of those spots. Lots of history and beautiful scenery to experience. Definitely worth a day or more for a visit!

We didn't take a guide but found our way around easily, reading up on the various historic events around the village. We had a picnic on the Potomac river's edge - clean enough to sit on the sand and eat. We watched the rafters go by - next time! I would recommend Harpers Ferry as a brief day stop as you can visit most of the attractions in a few hours. The parking is expensive at $10 but there is free 2 hour parking close to the railway bridge.

We knew a little about the history of Harpers Ferry before we visited this National Park but when we left, we knew a TON more. We stopped by the visitors centre and talked with the volunteer rangers and they suggested we go on the 'Top Down Tour'. We did and it was excellent. The two rangers who guided us through the 2 hour tour were fantastic. They both had an indepth knowledge of the area and its history. Questions were asked by the group and they answered right away or they found out the answers before the end of the tour. It was a great experience. The town of Harpers Ferry is fascinating and had such a large impact on the United States and its development. The cost was $10 to enter the park and this included parking, shuttle buses that took people from the upper to lower part of the site. It also included the top-down tour. Fantastic. I will actively tell people that this is something that should not be missed.

I've visited here three times in the last year - once with my teenage brother-in-law, once with with a gang of 20 teenaged Boy Scouts, and once with a pair of friends when we walked in on the AT. It was enjoyable by all three groups, and is a great deal at only $10 per carload (Thanks national parks system!)

We loved our first visit to Harper's Ferry. We went mid week - no crowds. You could move easily throughout the buildings and step back in time. The scenery was unforgettable and we took lots of pictures. A few glitches...We took the shuttle bus from the Visitors Centre which was a good idea but the driver was nasty. When my husband thanked her for the ride as we exited, she literally growled at him. She did the same to other passengers. We also were less than impressed with the treatment our son received when he tried to sign up for the Junior Ranger's program, which he has done at other parks. The girls made him feel very uncomfortable and he decided not to participate. Other than that we enjoyed our visit and hope to return someday. Need at least 2-3 hours. Very reasonable entrance fee - $10 for the family.

An unusual national park in that the park intersperse within Harpers Ferry the town. Doesn't look like much until you start walking around and found that there were a lot to explore. Many displays tucked away and integrated with the historic building of the town. There's also rafting, tubing, or hiking opportunities in town. $10 gets you three days entry, day parking, and shuttle ride.

Beautiful and huge park.....you can pay $25 if you enter with your car and you can use that ticket for the whole week! Different places to go....you can visit the tourists center with interesting information, you can see the steam , if you go during the night you can see the lava because the park has active volcano but go with warm clothes because is cold! You can walk 13 miles and see the lava in front of your eyes!!!!! You can visit the lava tube too. Inside the park there is a military camp too. You can't miss it !!!!! Really interesting.....
We had two goes in trying to see everything, with our first trip in the rain and $3 poncho from Walmart in Hilo helped due to the heavy rain.

Not much to see, a huge crater, bit of smoke, $25 entry fee, Jagger Museum is pretty run down as was the visitors center, while the landscape is really amazing, i don't think it is worth the trouble, its a full day from Kona, perhaps if you get a helicopter tour it would be better.

Having visited the park on a one day bus tour many moons ago, the opportunity to return and explore it more thoroughly was a key reason to visit the Big Island. Staying on site at Volcano House (see separate review), this was a terrific base from which to explore the natural beauty and devastation wrought by the island’s still active volcanos. Hiring a car in Hilo provides the greatest flexibility as the park is considerable in size and, while cycling may be an option for the healthiest individuals, the distance between sites can be great. The visitor centre can provide more information on attractions (but beware some grumpy rangers trying to reduce expectations of seeing rivers of molten lava) however the maps provided are, strangely, not terribly intuitive. Cross referencing provided information with websites and commercially printed guides will give greater insight into which attractions cannot be missed. Jaggar observatory is a highlight, offering the closest (legal) views of the caldera and a nighttime visit will yield incredible views and photos of the lava glow, as is the chain of craters road which visits various sites of volcanic devastation in all its forms as well as the tourist-heavy Thurston Lava Tube. Trail walks vary from easy to intense, short to long. Don’t expect to be seeing much in the way of close-up lava, as it is located in spaces far away from car parks and the main attractions and is, generally, a few hours walk each way. Also, food and drink options are low and expensive, so drop by a convenience store on the way to the park to grab water and snacks. Park entry is about $25 for a 7 day car pass. Also on site is an art gallery, sulphur and steam vents, loads of spectacular wild life (keep your eyes peeled) and walking trails to various lookouts. At least a full day of activity, if explored thoroughly without walking to the lava flows (that in itself would be a 4+ hour activity for fit individuals).
There are a lot of things to do in the Volcanoes National park. The $25 car ticket is valid for 7 days, and I definitely think a minimum of 2 days is needed to see as much as possible.

Ok you can't rush this. There are lava tubes, steam vents, and of course a volcano to see! We spent the night at the volcano house cabin to have 2 days there. There is a ton of walking so bring comfy shoes. There are also some things to see and do that are short walks if it is an issue. We had a great clear night to view the volcano when dusk started. That is when you see the best. My husband informed me that the stars are amazing, the most he's ever seen. The camping area is so dark so good for star watchers. I don't know I slept all night after all the walking. I also appreciated that is was only $25 for the car load for an entire week. Very fair park fees. The restaurant in volcano house has an extremely limited menu so not good for kids.

I wanted to see some oozing lava. Which according to the work on the street was happening when we were there. We paid $25, to a curt gate attendant, to get into the park only to find out the only place to access the flowing lava is from outside the park. Having paid the park fee we thought we should at least see what is there. First stop was the smolder crater. All you can see is the smoke coming off the lava lake and a huge caldera. Personally I did not find this too exciting. I did like the Jaggar Museum, it had some interesting, easy to understand displays. We then back tracked to a 4 mile hike that traversed the rim of an older caldera and then down one of the walls across the cooled lava and up the other side. Be sure to buy the $2 (after you have all ready paid the $25 entrance fee) guide book, the hike would be just a walk without it. It was OK but if asked I would say not worth the hour and a half. I have walked through a lava tube before but our friend had not so we did that. As far as educational value is it small. Really it is a walk through a dark tunnel???? The trek to where the lava spills into the ocean is long and would take a whole day so we did not do it. As far as the national park, unless you have a real interest in volcanos I would skip it.

We were driving round the island, prior to a helicopter tour the next day, and we decided to visit here at the last minute. That meant we only had a short visit (it takes a while to drive right round!). We visited the caldera and the museum, and that was spectacular. Would have liked to drive the crates road, but had no time. As we were doing the helicopter ride, we weren't too upset, but if you were not, I would think you'd want to go! If we'd planned better, we could have combined this with other Parks in Hawaii, which would have been cost effective. We didn't have an up-to-date guidebook, so were a little surprised to find out that in the last 5 years the price has risen quite a lot (our book said $10, and it was $25 - not really expensive for what you get, but it was just the time scale). An interesting bit was the naturally filtered water you could refill your water bottle from, and the exhibition about sustainability.
Drive the south route from Kona, about 2hr 15 mins. Cost $25/car for entry. we visted the Crater rim trail and Jaggar Museum, as well as hiking the Kilauea Iki trail

We had 11day's staying in Volcano,spending most of them in the park at all time's day and night.It was alway's very clean.The staff and volunteers worked very hard to make everyone's visit good.Some day's the crater was high,some day's we did not see anything.The crater did show up better at night.$20 for a week pass $25 for a year.You could get in for free after 7pm or 8pm not sure now.To see what the Volcano can do,go down Chain of Craters Road to the Sea.We had a good time in the park.

We spent a day at the Volcanic National Park and were lucky enough to see lava at the crater at Jagger Museum! When you arrive you can speak to the park rangers that will advise you on trails in relation to fitness/what you want to see. It is $20 entrance fee which lasts a week. You do need a car to get to each of the areas. Then you can park up and do the hikes which range in distance. The park rangers will also be able to guide you as to what you will see as sometimes dependant on weather, areas can be closed off or lava may not be seen. Well worth a trip! Make sure to bring suncream and plenty of water. If you do the 10 mile hike down to the lava flowing in to the sea they recommend 3 litres of water per person and torches as well. It's very breezy at the park (high altitude/close to the sea) - I got burnt as I didn't realise how hot the sun was! Be careful!

The park is large and offers many options for people of differing fitness levels, and visitors with varying time allocations. You can visit this park for a couple hours, or come back for multiple day trips, with either option providing opportunities for meaningful experiences. Cost to enter the park was $20 for our family in a car and gave us access for seven days. We only had enough time to visit for a few hours, but will come back on our next trip. Parking around the site was a challenge, but with patience we managed to locate a spot to park. If you're willing to walk a little ways you can park wherever you like and hike to whatever you want to see, and for those that are more mobility challenged there are quite a few parking areas spread throughout the park. The map you receive when you enter shows various locations of interest and different trails including trail lengths and vantage points. We plan to visit the Island with my elderly parents in the coming years, and they love to get out and explore, but due to health issues we need to be careful how for out we take them. This park is great for that because there are plenty of short, easy, well managed trails to walk that have wonderful vantage points to take in the craters, and the flora and fauna. The lava tube is also very accessible. Most of the trails we hiked were well covered, and provided ample shade. Bring water and snacks as there doesn't seem to be much near the park in the way of shops/restaurants, and you'll have to drive to access these services.

This is our second visit to this aewsome park and 1st visit with a young child. We did a new hike each day and also the Thurston Lava Tube. This park can be as easy or as challenging as you choose to make it. The visitor centers are good and lots of wonderful scenic views for those looking for less steps. If you are able to hike some of the trails, do it! And grab a $2 guide book to take along with you. Our 4 year old loved tracking down the next # on the hike.

Family of four (2 children ages 6 and 3) came to the park today. We had a great time looking at the lava flowing and bubbling away. There are always tours happening each time I have been there however there is plenty of space to get around. There is lots of parking and walking areas to explore. Cost is $20 per car to get in. It's worth the trip to see the lava.

It's not everyday that you get to see lava pouring out of a cliff, so I highly recommend this activity while the volcano is active. At the Kaimu entrance, we rented the well-maintained $20 mountain bikes from Elron and were very happy to have free water on such a hot dry day. It's a dusty ride to the cliff through an impressive and unforgettable landscape. The resilience of the locals who return to claim their land and rebuild on the lava is beyond impressive. Cooled off with a very welcome cold beer at Uncle Awa's Bar near the Black Beach.

Go at night, and as a prelude to the sights watch Dante's Peak the night before to set the tone! If you're driving, just keep going all the way up Crater Rim drive, there are steam vents along the sides of the roads and marked laneways to stop where you can get out and see these... it's a bit of a catch 22 with that as the steam vents are good during the day and you can get some nice pics but the volcanic activity is amazing at night... so choose the lava viewing. $20US private vehicle fee IF the drive is open (it wasn't in our case as the Sulphur dioxide gas was too prevalent at that point), you can call up and check for that. Worth it and a trip from Oahu? Definitely. Go and see this phenomenon!

It takes 2.25 hours from Kona on windy highway with speeds up to 55mph. You climb 3000 feet so be prepared for cooler weather and rain in the winter months. It was pouring when we went so lots of steam and cloud over the crater at Jagger museum. The park rangers are very helpful and informative. We were able to buy rain ponchos at the interpretive centre you see as you enter the park. $20 per car to enter. We walked through the lava tube and that was really neat!

My family and I spent the day at the park. The staff at the visitor center were very helpful to help us organise our day. We drove down the chain of craters road and stopped at a number of places including the lava tube. Based on the advice of the visitor center staff we drove to the end of Highway 130 to view the lava flow into the ocean. In order to view the lava flow there is a 4 mile one way gravel path at the end of the highway. You can rent a bike or walk however we decided to walk and it took us 1 hour 15 minutes on the way there. My kids are 11 and 15 and they were fine. Take lots of water and there is a port-a-loo halfway there. The bikes were $20pp and would take you 40 minutes one way but it may be a little challenging on the way back if you are staying late at the lava flow. There were also tandem bikes and bikes with baby carts on the back. We viewed the lava flow between 6pm and 7pm and it was amazing. I highly recommend coming at sunset. I had seen reviews stating this was an extreme hike but it wasn't the case. If my 11 year old can do it I'm sure you can too. Overall it was a great experience and we could have easily spent another day at the park exploring.

We found the staff so helpful with advice, information, maps for viewing & hiking during our visits to the park over 2 days. We were advised by B & B where we stayed to buy the $25 entry pass & this then allowed us to use it on Maui as well & save us entry for multiple visits.

Despite miserable weather on our two days in the volcanoes national park, this could not put a dampener on what an amazing and truly incredible place this is! The park costs $20 per car entry however the pass is good for 7 days. Start at the information centre and speak with one of the friendly and knowledgeable guides for advice on what parts/features/trails will best suit your time, needs and fitness abilities. They were more than happy to tailor walks for us so that we made the most of our time there. We did the crater hike which was out of this world! You descend 500ft into a crater that used to be a lava lake. The hardened lava has dried in the swirling shapes and patterns of the original flow and you can see up close plenty of different types of lava rock. We felt like we were in an alien landscape and the mist and rain made it all the more surreal. Watch out for the steam vents, these can scald you if you get too close - stick to the trail. Tungsten lava tube was an easy hike and pretty good as far as lava tubes go! Steam pots and lava lake spurts visible from the Jagger museum were AWESOME. However, our highlight was definitely down the other end of the park along the coastline. You can see where brand new lava flow has literally created new land and experience crashing waves against pitch black lava cliffs. From the arch, you can hike into the latest ongoing eruption from Kileaua. Lava is spouting from the cliff side directly into the ocean and forming new land. The steam is out of this world and it hot (obviously!) This hike is tough, about 16km round trip - no trail and over sharp and treacherous lava. Sturdy shoes needed and plenty of water, it will take you around 5hrs so if you are going in the afternoon, take a torch. Be prepared for the heat bouncing back off the black lava too and take sunscreen! To finish off we visited the Peroglyphs which are a great insight into the history of the indigenous people who lived and survived in this harsh environment. This is a short and easy walk and very interesting. We could've spent our full week here however time did not allow it! Be prepared for all weather conditions - we experienced sun, rain, fog, mist, wind and humidity with a temperature range of 16-31oC. I highly recommend a visit to the Volcanoes National Park. There is something for everyone and is a once in a lifetime opportunity to marvel at the power and wonder of Mother Nature.

We visited the park during the day time, at night, and toured it in a helicopter. I preferred the night time view of the bubbling crater (via a astronomical telescope provided by Kailani tours' Jim Carey) than via the $600 helicopter tour! It was magical. It was great to stop by the steam vents during the day and also to walk along the rim.

The volcano is generally completely covered by rain and/ or fog, and they do not tell you this at the gate. So, for $20 you get to hike through the caves, yo can do a lot more hiking if you want, and to look at the museum. But, do not expect to see the lava flow, to do thid you need to go to Helo, hire a boat, and go out at dark to see it from the water.

We drove 100 miles to get to the park. It was a free day so we didn't pay the $20 fee to get in. I'm glad we didn't.the bottom of the park was closed so that left us with a view of the volcano please see picture. And that was it.there is a visitors centre but apart from that not much else. But I suppose we ticked the box

Drove from Kona. $10 entry per car. Make sure you watch the 20 minute video in the visitors centre first to get an idea of what it is you are going to see. then talk to one of the many guides about how much time you have and they will give you a map telling you the best things to see in that time frame. Short drive to the actual musuem and viewing site. Well worth the trip

We stayed in Kona so hiring a car and heading to the volcano national park meant a long day of driving -but boy are we glad we did! Honestly this was my favourite part of the trip. Obviously mother nature plays a big part in how much Lava you actually see and we happened to be there at a time when she was very active. We paid $25 as a car to get into the national park which isn't a big deal. Bring lots of water, a jacket as its a bit cooler up here and a rain coat: good chance you'll get wet! The Ranger at the information center was very helpful telling us exactly where the best areas would be to go, breaking down how long we wanted to spend there and what hiking trails would suit our desires. The Thurston lava tube was a very easy and short walk through pretty rainforest, and the Jagger viewing platform was brilliant. Our view of the Lava spitting 3 stories into the sky although quite far away was spectacular and humbling. We then drove out of the national park on the Rangers suggestion and went down to the end of highway 130, where we hired bicycles for $10 an hour. The 13km round trip ended up taking us about 3 hrs but that includes over an hour of walking on lava fields and watching where the lava was flowing into the ocean with a billowing cloud of steam. If you're not worried about riding back in the dark, stay until nightfall like we did- that's when things really heat up and the glow of the lava truly intensifies. If a sight like that doesn't impress you then nothing will. I will be recommending this to everyone!

It was like driving on the moon passing through all the different lava flows on the way to the park. It is something you probably won't see anywhere else. $20 entry fee per car and there isn't any food as such, certainly not fast, rolls in the souvenir shop are $9. We drove to the crater to see the lava put on a show, it wasn't doing anything the previous day. We the drove down the Chain of Craters road to the sea. Amazing. We didn't do the walk to the active lava flow as we didn't have the time. You can get helicopters from Hilo but make sure you prebook, lots of cruise ships and we missed out!!! We were told that you can access from the other side and hire bikes to make it a little easier to get to.

Be prepared to see everything from a distance. No actual lava was able to be seen so best to go at night if you want to see the glow. There is a $20 entry fee for sites you can see free elsewhere. For lava viewing go to the lava viewing where the lava hits the water at the end of Kiama chain of craters road, lava tubes head to kaumana caves and take a flash light. The only plus side of this tour is the education and it is more child friendly as you can drive to each spot. Maybe one for the family but for the adventurous head to the free spots and get a real taste of the sites.

What can I say - this place is incredible. $20.00 to get in and more than worth it. Go at night and see the glow of the lava in the Halema'uma'u crater - best spot to view is from the Jaggar museum. During the day you'll get amazing views of the caldera from the balcony of the Volcano House hotel, which is also a great place to eat. There are numerous walks around the park - I recommend the lava tube walk and Devastation trail. Check out the park's information centre before you do anything. You can stay the night at Volcano House, or for a cheaper option, we booked a cabin at the campground about 10 mins from the park, on the main highway (book on the Volcano House website) - very basic but really comfy beds.

Visiting this park (US$20 entrance fee) will give a first experience of the impact of volcanos. Extensive lava flows, numerous craters (including an active crater), a lava tubes are just part of the experience. Visit the visitors centre which has a great film and make sure you drive the Chain of Crates road to the end of the road. Be prepared for all kinds of weather. A great experience and if you are into hiking (8 miles / 13 km round trip) you can walk to where the lava enters the sea. Amazing! But be adequately prepared as it is hot.
The volcano visitors information centre is a must. There are daily walks brochure, and other maps free. The re is a controlled booth to the park! ; there is a$10 entrance fee for a week.

I read the day before my visit that the latest red lava flow is slowly going towards the sea and is accessible from the park. I left behind the planned visits of the overlook and cold trail hiking and decided to hike the 10 miles roundtrip to the hot lava flows with my family, whatever it took. It was an amazing adventure. The first portion of the hike is from the gate at the end of the chain of crater road, using the chain of crater gravel service road, a nice and easy but very hot walk (still better than through the jungle). Then when about square with the smoke, we walked up on the cold lava fields to the hot lava flow. You can feel the warmth from quite a distance so its not like you can step on hot lava by mistake. I had previously made myself a wooden stick from a dead branch so we were able to poke red lave as we wished. It's a unique and amazing experience, finally we are able to see lava up close instead of seeing it from 5 miles away. It is very slow moving flow so there is no risks unless you jump into it. Still, secure procedures and good sense must be used when approaching and playing with red hot lava. The heat is so strong anyway that you cannot really stay close to it for a long time. We were also lucky to meet a geologist at the site that was giving a private lecture to 2 guys who must have hired him at great expense. He showed us quite a few tricks. We stayed with the lava for about one hour and then walk the 5 miles back to the car. It is preferable to do it very early in the morning from the park (much less people), or later at night from the Kalapana direction (shorter but lots of people), avoiding the noon sun as much as possible. I drank 2.5 litres of water during the 5 hours journey. I have memories, pictures and stories for a lifetime, all for a $20 entry fee for the car. It is probably not for everyone so be aware of your abilities and endurance to hot temperatures before going there. Thank you Hawaii Volcano National Park.

The Volcano put on a great show for us this time, some lava was bubbling up through the top of the lava lake which was only about 80 feet below the crater rim and glowed red hot all throughout the evening. We visited the steam vents, Thurston lava tube, Volcano House, lua mana crater and the Iki overlook. You can easily spend a couple of days exploring so the $20 entry fee is well worth it. The information centre and Jagger museum have lots of interesting exhibits and info including crater webcams at Jagger. There are many scenic stops throughout with parking and walks to suit any level of fitness (My 75yo Aunt did the Thurston Lava Tube walk). If you do nothing else, visit this park. You can keep up with Volcanic activity through the Hawaii Volcanos Observatory service. Dry days are best as rain will cause the crater to steam up making it difficult to see.

where else in the world can you stand INSIDE a crater of an active volcano knowing lava and the living mountain are rumbling under your feet. It was an amazing experience and very affordable $20 per car

We were a group of 8, with 4 kids between ages 6 and 11, on a day trip from Waikiki to do a helicopter experience in the morning. After we had seen lava flows and craters and vents from the air, we hired two cars to see them up close. Everyone thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Volcano National Park. Be aware there is a $20 per car entry fee to the national park, but that gives you 7 consecutive days' access. First the Visitor centre, which was well presented, and had lovely staff who were knowledgeable and enthusiastic. Next we drove to the steam vents, and did a short walk in that area, enjoying the views from the lookout there. Then we went up to the Jaggar museum. Kids and adults alike were thrilled by the view of the Kilauea crater complete with bubbling lava, and the information in the museum was well presented, interesting, and helpful. Kids loved the seismograph and spent quite some time trying to make their own seismic event go "off the scale". We had plenty of time, so we then headed down the Chain of Craters Road to the sea. The drive was spectacular, and in excellent condition. We stopped to walk through the Thurston Lava Tube, which was a short hike which the kids managed quite happily. There were some steep spots though which may cause problems for the less mobile visitors -it is a mountain trail of course!
$20 gets you a 7 day entry.

Kilauea is the most active volcano on the Big Island. You can see smoke coming from the crater and we were told if we visited in the evening, we could see red and orange flames too. This volcano is just over 4000 ft, less than half the height of the Haleakala on Maui. Pay a visit to the Jaggar Museum where you learn about different volcanic rocks and the rock formations. After that walk through the extinct lava tube (Thurston Lava Tube). The whole trip is less than 3 hours. If you have another 3-4 hours to spare, drive to the lava-buried village of Kalapana and along the coastline of Puna. I am sure you will enjoy the scenic ride.

Drove out to the volcanoes, paid the $15 to the Rangers, who let us through but gave to information at all about what to see ect... It was raining so we went straight to the tourist centre and collected maps.. They did have lots of people giving advice and you could get supplies like ponchos if needed. Then headed to the museum as were told the rain should stop soon. Museum was really poor, very boring.. Nothing interesting for kids at all and could not see even the outline of the volcano.. Stopped off at the steam vent stops, which was a rectangle hole with steam coming out... Really not worth getting out the car to see. Did the sulphur walk, again really nothing to see. All the descriptions that we read about the volcanoes and other sights are really misleading and exaggerated. Not at all worth the effort.

Arriving on the island this was our main activity to do. Luckily when we arrived we realised their was a bus straight to the park only costing us $2 each way and the $8 cost of entry to the park. The tours being around $120 each! We walked around crater rim about a 11 mile walk which was easily done in about 5 hours which stops and breaks for food and water. Amazing sites to see along the trail and easily sign posted. Would recommend to everyone

We visited twice, once during the night and once during the day. In the night you can see the glowing of the lava in the volcano which is amazing but not much else. We went back the next morning and spent a couple hours going down the crater road. The crater road is amazing, there are plenty of places to stop along the way. The views are breathtaking and we were able to get right down to the water. We also walked through Thurston lava tube which was great. It is well worth the trip. Entry was $15 for our car.
rent a car or better a jeep its worth the $$..the drive is breathtaking and sae and so many waterfalls and trails to walk..the smell of sulfer is weird..
Entrance to the park costs $15 per car and the ticket is valid for 7 days. Some areas are closed at the moment due to fumes from the volcano.
We visited the park in poring rain but it was still a great experience ($15 entrance).

One of the best bangs for our tourist dollar on the big islands do great way to learn more about volcano activity. Pleasant and knowledgeable staff to provide direction and with the accompanying booklet it was a great and informative hike across the crater floor too..and Thurston lava tube was also a must see. Never before have we witnessed a tunnel of this magma tube ... the active volcano viewed from Jagger Museum was also very good..the whole package was a must see for anyone visiting Hawai'i.

We left from Kona and stopped on the way to the black sand beach which took about 1.5 hour and we had a picnic lunch. This beach is amazing and I will write about it in another review. The road is very safe and it took one more hour to get to Hawaii Volcanoes National Park. It costs only $15 per car, valid for 7 days, and there is so much amazing places to see, feel and smell in this park. We went first to the Kilauea Visitor Center: very interesting, staff very courteous and quite nice souvenirs to buy. We found an excellent book on Hawaii's fishes that we had been searching for a long time (Hawaiian Reef Fishes. Sea Turtles, dolphins, whales and seals). We then did the Thurston Lava Tube and it was really fun and spectacular. It was quite cold at 50F with great winds. We were wearing our hot winter clothes and as a joke, some people offered us to rent them!!! :) Afterwards, we went down the Chain of Craters Road. Quite amazing to see all the different craters and surroundings of different sizes and shapes. On our back, we stopped at Steam Vents and it was very surprising to smell and see the vapors (SO2-sulfur dioxide) coming out of the ground. After this, we went to the Jaggar Museum. The lady at reception was extremely nice and showed us the real time 4 computers of the crater and explained to us that we would see a spectrum of orange lights at the crater rim after sunset. We took a nap in the car and at 7:00 pm we went to see this amazing site with different shades of orange light from the lava in the crater. We would have liked to see the lava but I think that we we can only see it from the sky. Coming back to Kona took 2.5 hours and it was easy and confortable. I would go back again to walk around the many trails and go to the Volcano House for a meal but there is so many beautiful sites on the Big Island that we will continue our different adventures on the Big Island.

My husband and I had 4 nights in Volcano and spent every day exploring the National Park. The rangers were great and trails were easy to follow but take plenty of water. The fees were US$15.00 for 7 days what a bargain.

My wife and I had a rental car so we went up to the Volcano. There is a Park Admission that was valid for 7 days. We got to the park early thinking the Visitor Centre opened early but it opened at 8.30 am. You need to try to get to the Lava Tubes early to avoid the Bus Tours so we went down to them. They aren't the biggest Lava Tubes but they are really worth seeing and walking through. We then went back to the Visitor's Centre and had a wander around it. Then on to the Steam Vents and the Jagger Museum. The view from the Museum and the other sights at the Volcano are worth seeing. These Volcanos erupt regularly but are not the same as Mt St Helens. The Locals have to live with the flows but this type of Volcano doesn't explode.

What an amazing place to visit. We did a day trip here from Honolulu ourselves and saved plenty of dollars by doing this. We booked our own plane tickets on Hawaiian Air, rented a car from Dollar Car rentals and self drove the national park. It was very easy and we seen all the same attractions as a day tour from Honolulu would of done. The national park is very easy to negotiate and well signed. Do not miss this area if you are travelling to Hawaii.
My Husband and I did this Park on our first days of being in Hilo. You pay one fare $16.00 for your vehicle and the ticket is good for one week of visitation there.

So much of this park is easily accessible by car. Do not book a tour to see this park - so overpriced and you can get in the park for $15 and the pass is good for a week! Lots to see - give yourself the entire day! If you are fit and have the time do the hike down into the crater - it's awesome.

Back in Oz now and still can't believe we we got to visit this wonderful place!!!! The whole experience was AWESOME!!!!! We would recommend everyone to visit and walk the crater then stay for dinner in the restaraunt and watch the glow of the lava from the volcano. I would recommend a light jacket though as it get's a bit cold. I would like to say that $15 US for a car of 4 people to gain entry was soooooo cheap and would also like to say how surprised I was at how clean the toilets were! Thank you to the lovely waitress who gave us travel tips, wish I could remember her name as she was soooooo lovely. Going back!

Fabulous attraction. We were on the Dawn Princess Cruise ship, so rented some Alamo Chevy Corvettes and did the easy drive up into the mountains. Watch the temperature as it plummets as you get higher, went from 38C at ship to 19C up the top. Cost only $15 per car to get in. Spend time in the theatre and info Centre then drive around, great views fabulous experience.

Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is the most exciting tour you can take. There are so many spots to see, so please take the short seminar given at the park before going out. We went to the Thurston Lava Tube, visited Jaggar Museum and then went to the steam vents. The tour can last for hours depending on much time you have, but as we came from Kona we had a few hours to get back before sunset. On the Big Island there are not to many lights on the highway so traveling at night gets very dangerous. Plan your trip accordingly so you can get back home safely. Make sure to arrive early in the day so you can have enough time to drive back home before sunset. Your children will love the tour including adults. Admission is not very expensive so it is worth the trip when you have a big family. Mahalo!

This park shows you the wonders of nature. The vastness of it can not be described or captured in pictures. The park is open 24 hours for those that want the night time experience of the volcano. Plan your day well because you can hike it, drive it, or do both. We were there for 4 hours and still didn't see it all because it has hot and we ran out of time in our day. There are learning centers with park rangers to answer questions, and they give you maps with trails and suggestions. The lava tube was worth seeing and walking through. The entrance fee was $15 for the car load and there are gift shops. Bring a water bottle or purchase one there because they have rain water filling stations and you will need to drink lots of water.

Going to Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is a must see if you're on the Big Island! Make sure you check the weather before heading out. If the day is going to be rainy, then try to go on a day when it's sunny. When it rains, it will obscure all there is to see as it can be quite humid and cloudy. That was great advice that was given to us by the park ranger and I'm glad we waited for a nice day to go. Pack a picnic lunch if you're going to be there for awhile. There are some picnic tables in shelters. Go early as these spots can fill up fast. We did everything we wanted to see in a day. Didn't make it to the evening glow but we loved everything else there was to do. Enjoyed Thurston Lava Tubes. Steam vents were also very interesting. You must have a car to tour the park. Did see some Nene geese there as well! The cost at the gate was 11.00 dollars/car. This gave us unlimited access to the park the whole day. Would definitely go again as we could have spent a lot more time there.

Not just to see the volcanic smoke, but the many other walks and sights available make this a must do on your trip to the Big Island. We went 4 times during our stay, including 1 memorable trip up there at 4 in the morning to look at the red glow. Only a handful of people at that time of day & it was full moon too so some stunning views of nature doing her thing. I would recommend starting at the visitor centre just inside the park to get your bearings, then the other visitor centre at the Jaggar Museum. From there you get the closest view of the smouldering crater. Be aware you won't see lava erupting out of it at the moment, just sulphurous smoke. At night it takes on the red glow and is more atmospheric. I think the 3hr hike through Mauna Iki crater beats it (make sure you buy the $2 guide from the trailhead first), and we also did Mauna Ulu hike. The drive down Chain of Craters road to the petroglyphs is lovely & almost no-one around when we did it. Staff are very knowledgeable and helpful. There was a new lava flow during our stay but inaccessible by foot and would cost up to $500 each to see by chopper so missed that one . . .
flew in/out Hilo while vacationing in Oahu/Maui. Really was worth the trip and low $15 car fee for entering the park.
We rented a car and did our own thing. Car rental was about USD$130 for the day, and took about 2.5 hours from Waikoloa Beach Resort.

Self-drove from Hilo. It costs $15 to get into the park. Plenty of tourists there. We arrived just as the museum at the accessible active volcano (a big smoking hole is all you'll see) was opening, so that was bad timing for us, because it was super full, and hard to get a look at the exhibits.

Allow time for a few visits to get the most out of your visit here. We went 5 times over 2 days which allowed us to see the crater glow at night, 1st time foggy, 2nd time on a clear night and again at daybreak. Walk the crater rim and trek across the lava floor...thus was an absolute highlight. It took us, a 50+ couple, 3 hours and was worth every minute. A surreal and unique experience. The drive on the crater drive was lovely and a visit to the lava tube fun. We stayed in a b&b in Volcano which allowed multiple park visits with ease. $10 Pete car for a 7 day pass...great value.

there are no dislikes at all it has loads of trails,best one is Kilauea Iki trail plus the sulphur trail,to do it all you need at least 4 days that's what I did,ideally you would be best staying at volcano house because everything is St the doorstep plus you won't have to drive to the park,but volcano village is about a mile from the park so if you can't get reservations in volcano house then opt for volcano village the people are really pleasant plus u can walk yo the park you don't even have to drive it saves u 15 dollars in parking fees
We went on all day that culminated with the dinner at the lodge and then the twilight volcanoe viewing. Worth every minute and dollar.

No visit of Big Island without this park.It was this why we went to this island, to see a 'smoker' , an active volcano and the area around it.Entrance is 25$ per car.But...in case you want to visit more of these parks or State Monumens you'll save some monet by buying an annual Park Pass for all National Parks in the States for 80$. Two people can sign, so we gave it to our daughter who lives in the States to use it till next April.

Difficult to justify the cost of the expensive tours available. We had a hire car so did it on our own. Inside the park (entry is $5pp) there's a wide range of walk options for all fitness levels, an excellent visitor centre and interpretative centre. Don't miss the great view of the volcano from the Jagger Museum or the short walk to see the Thurston Lava Tube. You need a minimum of a couple of hours in the park or up to a couple of days if you're a keen bush walker.getting to the Park independently is definitely the way to go.

An amazing place full of great opportunities to explore. From the vista of the crater itself to the lava tube and countless trails, one could spend a great deal of time there. As it's quite a drive from where we stayed in Kona, I would suggest a couple of nights in either Volcano or Hilo to really do the area justice. Your $10.00 entrance fee is good for a week. I know we'll spend more time there next visit.

Stayed in Hilo for 2 days for the purpose of going to the Volcano National Park. This side of the island is very rainy. The drive from the Hilo Hawaiian hotel is where I stayed is basically a straight road. A 45 minute drive roughly. We drove there ourselves. Headed to the park by about 4pm. $10/car to get in and valid for 10 days. As I was told best time to be at the National Volcano Park is about around the 4-5pm. Enough time for you trek through the Lava Tube, then go the other part where you see the smoke coming out from the lava.For family's that have infants or toddlers. There are 3 parkades. The 3rd lower parkade is the closest Lava tube. It was quite cold once we got the Kaileau crater observation station. Not sure what the temperature would be in the summer. The lava started glowing at about 6:45pm and got more brighter as it got darker.

How lucky are we that we have such amazing and beautiful National Parks to visit and explore. We spent a full day here and were not disappointed, even though it was quite cold and rainy. Lots of knowledgeable Rangers around and the views were spectacular. Jagger Museum was interesting and some great short videos at the Kilauea V.C. Make the drive all the way down Chain of Craters Road, the sea arch is awesome and the views go on forever. The hike to the Petroglyphs was short and well worth it to see the area. Don't forget your National Parks Passport Book and collect your stamps. Great spot. Thanks National Parks Service!!

Awesome national park, cheap to get in $8 per person, good viewing of volcanoes, past lava sites and hot air sites as well as old lava tube and jungle/rainforest walk, some shops and accommodation , food limited while in the park, bring your own. can get cold up there so bring something warm

The $10 car entry fee allows repeat visits within a week. On the first day we watched two introductory films in the Visitors Centre, followed by the Kilauea Iki Trail. The hike was led by a voluntary guide. The loop trail is just over 4 miles. It has different starting points. We hiked past the ohia forest, then descended down to the lava bathtub below. There is molten magma still beneath the surface. Along the way there were rock cairns to direct hikers. We found the ascend from the crater's east end to the rim exhausting. It took us two and half hours for the hike. I would classified the hike as moderate in difficulty. The second day we visited the steam vents, Jaggers Museum, walked the Thurston Lava tube and drove down the Chain of Craters road to see the petroglyph and the numerous places of interest. On the third day we watched a hula and mele (dance & chant) performance, organised by the Volcano Art Centre. It was a magnificent show and free of charge. The Volcano Art Centre organises performances once a month, usually on the third or fourth Saturday. The Art Centre is one of the best small art centres we have visited. There were some beautiful wood and glass exhibits, as well as photos and jewellery. Prices are very reasonable. We left the park to have lunch at a small cafe in Volcano called Cafe Ohi'a, good food at very reasonable price. After the refreshment we drove to Punaluu Black Sand Beach, about 30 miles south. We also saw five green turtles nesting there. We returned to the park, did some shopping at the Art Centre and finished with a drink at the Volcano House, which has magnificent view.

We really enjoyed our day in the park, We had a National Park Pass, so it didn't cost us anything to get in, but even so, I believe it was only $10/car. The Chain of Craters Drive was excellent with lots of spots to stop. It was interesting to see all the different lava flows and craters from various years. Beautiful coastal view at the end. We enjoyed walking through the Thurston lava Tube. Viewing the glow of the lava from the Jagger Museum was very cool! We packed picnic lunch and dinner for the day. Only 1/2 of the Crater Rim drive is open due to the lava flow, and miles of the road which were wiped out from previous years' lava flow.

At $10 a car, access to this natural wonder is worth it. Your pass is valid for a week and there is an abundance of activities to choose from. You can see an active volcano from a safe distance of course. You can visit the Museum, hike across lava to the ocean, see petroglyphs, watch as steam filters from the earth beneath you, hike along a crater, drive the chain of craters drive, eat a fabulous burger and fries, the best in the area, at 10 pin grill or even camp over night. The gas at the station inside the National Park is cheaper than anywhere else we found. This naturally devastated area is gorgeous and worth at least four days of your holiday minimum.

Not sure whether it was a good or bad thing that it was a cloudy day we went on ! It was about 64F at the visitors centre and drizzling slightly at times but it did make walking a whole lot easier . $20 for a weeks pass for one car is incredibly good value

We had one night and day for visiting the Volcano National Park. It is one of the most stunning places on the Big Island. We saw an active volcano crate with lava bubbling by night and did a hike through some cold lava fields by day. The surrounding is awesome! This is a thing, you can only see in a very few places all over the world. Entrance fee for a private car is 20$, valid for seven days.

This site is extremely interesting. We have visited this place 4 times over a 6 year period and the wonder of nature never ceases to amaze. The large crater with steam venting all around can be an eerie experience, especially when it's a little cloudy and raining. Kind of Jurassic Park like. We have walked the small crater ( Kileaua Iki?) floor and rim trails several times now and each time never ceases to amaze us. The museums have lots of good info n the washrooms are nice n clean. The Thurston lava tube is also well worth a trip. It only takes about 15 minutes to do the walk. The park fee is only $10:00 per carload and is good for a week. There are many hiking trails in the park, but we have only done a few easy ones.

There are a number of places to visit other than the volcano and they include the cliffs with steam and the lava tunnel. There is an informative Visitor Center and the Jagger Museum and over look of the crater. Entrance is $20 per car.

It should first be mentioned that the "central attraction" is the volcano Kilauea, not Mauna Loa. We were lucky to be there to witness the lava erupting in the Halema'uma'u lava lake. The Jagger Museum overlook is the best place to see this attraction. The park rangers are very informative and pointed out that the mountain that we were standing on was "breathing" (the volcano inflates and deflates!). The hike down to the floor of Kilauea (it is away from the lava lake) allows one to walk on the hardened lava. Continuing down the Chain of Craters road, you can follow the lava to the ocean. However, to see the actual entry of lava into the ocean, you need a guide ($$$) or take an evening boat ride (from Hilo).

The Park Service does such a great job! For $10 for a car-load for a week, you get access to the visitor centre, films, talks, advice from staff and volunteers, trails, museums, great deal! And the park is fantastic, with thermal vents, sulphur clouds, gorgeous evening red-glows from molten lava and steam vents. Great trails and roads and lots of attractions. You should not come to the Big Island and not go to the park.

This is one of the main reasons to visit Hawaii - to visit the Volcano National Park ! Amazing to see the power of what nature can do. We paid $10 fee for car entry into the park and drove to see the crater and the smoke puffing from it. There were areas where fumeroles were active from the ground. Took many photos and checked out the interesting displays in the Volcano Visitors centre there. Next we drove to visit the Thurston Lava tube in the park area. This was very interesting to see as well. While in Hawaii- definitely go see the Volcano areas.

We first did a tour with a company through the park, and then went back the following day to do some exploring on our own through the park. There really is a lot to see and do here! The highlights for us was seeing the Kilauea Caldera from the Jagger Museum, seeing the steam vents, and doing the Kilauea Iki Crater hiking trail. You do really need at least a full day to spend in the park. It's only $10 per vehicle to enter the park, and the pass is good for a whole week which is a great deal.

I hadn't been in a while and wanted to see what had changed since the last time we were there. The Rim of Craters is currently closed because of noxious gasses which meant the Jagger Museum was the end of the line. There is a fee, but if you are 62 or older make sure to purchase the Golden Age Pass for $10 which allows you to get into all the national parks for you and your passengers for the rest of your life. What a deal.

This is a state park, so there are a lot of park rangers doing a lot of pushing around. There aren't enough parking spots for the numbers they allow in so you can't even get to some of the places you want to go. And you can't see lava flow, only the glow. Try the Arenal volcano in Costa Rica where you see the lava flowing and they have hot springs out of the water heated by the volcano.

About a 40 minute drive from Hilo. If you plan on doing a few of the hikes, allow yourself several hours, or if time is short, you can just visit the main points by car along the crater rim. The crater is a must see and the landscape looks like you're on the moon! We didn't get to see it at night, but if you can, try and see it both night and day to ensure you see the lava glow. We paid a $20 entrance fee per car to the park at the rangers station. The Rangers are very helpful and worth having a chat too, to get the best advice on how to see as much as you can if you are on a time limit. You could spend a couple of days or more camping, hiking etc, there is a lot to see and experience. Once you've had your fill of the crater, head towards the Thurston Lava tube and time permitting, drive the Chain of Craters Road, you won't be disappointed. Add Black Sand Beach, complete with life guard and shop, to your must see list as well. You'll see turtles there also having a sun bake, absolutely wonderful.

Seriously, you are on the Big Island, how can you not take in Volcanoes National Park? Volcanoes are one of the island's most famous features! And you can surely spend a lot of money on a tour, but instead rent a car for the day, pay the $10 entrance fee (good for a week), and enjoy the rest of the day for free. Pack a lunch to eat in the park and have dinner in nearby Volcano town. Expect to spend at least half a day, but our family spent 6 hours one day and then went back for more the next.
For $10USD you get a complete days worth of activates. From steam vents, crater, lava tubes, sulphur banks and more volcanic rock that you will ever see again. Not to be missed.
We bought a National Parks pass before coming to Hawaii that got us into this park and another one on our stay here (valid for 12 months, $80).

We stopped in at the Visitor's Center to find out what was good to do. Fully recommend going left out of the the visitor's center and driving down Crater Road to see all the lava fields all the way to the end where the arch is. Good stop along the way is the lava tube. I do not recommend the hike to the petroglyphs as it is about 1.8 miles round trip over lava to see a few faint drawings in the lava. Then backtrack all the way past the visitor's center to the steam vents and walk to the edge of the crater to see the big steam. I also recommend going to the Jagger Museum after dark to see the glow from the crater - take a good camera and tripod if you can. Good view of the stars too. $3 park entrance unless you are military. Bring water and sunscreen and be prepared for rain. We have kids 15, 13, 9, and 8 (boys and girls) and all loved it.

Of course, safety is of paramount importance, but the closure of around 75% of the rim drive means little to see of the volcanic activity. The park is a significant drive up from Kona, and I would not recommend the trip if you're hoping for a lava show. The visitor center is interesting though, and the entrance fee reasonable at $10 per car.

Cost of entry into the National Park is very low, only $10 for the car, and the pass is valid for a week. We stopped in at the visitor info centre and talked to a park volunteer about what hikes they would recommend. After a stop for lunch at the Volcano House Hotel, we headed out on our hike.

These days one cannot see actual lava flows, but there are still steam vents, craters, lava tubes, lots of spectacular viewpoints (especially along Chain of Craters Road), interesting petroglyphs (0.7 of a mile off the road at Pu'u Loa), good hikes of various lengths, camping, cabins, an hotel, a volcano museum and an art exhibit, as well as wild turkeys, nenes, and other birds. Some of the lava flows are very photogenic. If you have a U.S. National Park pass, it is good here; otherwise $10 admission (good for a week). Good restaurant with a view of the crater at the hotel. About 40 minutes out of Hilo to Park Headquarters; close to 3 hours from Kailua-Kona. (If you are on the Island for two weeks or more, we recommend dividing your stay between the Kona side and the Hilo side to avoid long driving days.)

I highly recommend arriving early in the morning and packing a lunch and dinner so you can spend the day here. Even better would be to take your time and spend two days. Once you pay admission (only $10 per vehicle or $5 per individual) you have a pass for a week. When we went in March there was no accessible lava flow, but it was still worth visiting the park. Tip: you should stay after dark to see the lava glow.

As with all national parks the entrance fee of $10 for seven days is a snip!! Make sure you spend more than one day here if you really want to see this park even without major hiking. In addition, you really want to go in after dark to see the volcano glowing red so we recommend you stay in the area.

We arrived to the park in our rental car along excellent roads and found ample parking but could see this being an issue at times. Once we paid the $10 park entry fee there were no hidden fees or cost. We went straight to the visitor center and received an excellent description and suggested itinerary based on our wants from David. After that we were on our way up to see the crater followed by a hike and lava tubes. We were able to go at our own pace and were more then happy with the literature and guides at the visitor center. If you have a rental car I would suggest you save yourself a tone of money and make the drive as the highway is well maintained and the drive easy. A must visit on your trip to the Big Island. If you go don't forget your camera on the counter after grabbing drinks from your fridge! Thank goodness for cell phone cameras.

We were staying at a resort not-too-far from the park so it was not a long drive through the miles of lava flows - a great preview of what was to come. The 10 dollar entry for car and passengers is good for a week - bonus!! A park ranger - passionate about the volcanic history of the area - introduced us to the park and provided good advice on the trails and sites. The selection of trails provides for all levels of trekkers and are very well marked. Get to the museum and check out the nearby steam vents - awesome. Walking through Thurston's Lave Tube is a must.

For a 10$ park fee (valid for 7 days) you can explore one of the most active volcano on the planet, walking lava fields and the top of the crater. When driving down to the ocean side (chain of craters rd) you may watch whales (best time nov~apr) or NeNe (ducks). There is a lava tube, there are steam vents and lots of interesting hikes. Easy to spend a whole day or more in the park.

A different kind of park, well laid out with lots of information on volcanoes. The most exciting part is the crater rim drive and for the more adventurous there is the walking trail. A day well spent, $10.00 admission rate is reasonable, though the merchandise in the visitor centre is expensive, but you a have choice not to buy. Carry water and some warm clothing as nights can be chilly, especially if you are planning to see the" glow" in evening.Fill up your car, if you are driving from resorts.
Paid ten dollars to get in for the two of us in our car, cheap as chips for what you can see and ticket lasts a week.

Spent a day in this park. $10 entry fee is good for a week. Make sure you drive the road of craters down to the lava going across the road by the ocean - really interesting. The crater rim and steam vent walks are good and suitable for most anyone as is the lava tube walk. Definitely make sure you visit the Jaggar Museum around sunset so you can see the glow of the lava. Well worth at least a day in this park.
for $10 enterance fee its excellent

The Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is just awesome! Near the little village of Volcano you will find the entrance to the Visitor Centre.Fee is 10 dollars and is valid for several days, so keep the receipt. The main attraction is the crater of Kilauea, by the Jaggar Museum. The visitor centre has great exhibits, films, and ranger led programs, a hop and restrooms. The Ntl Park also includes Muna Loa and Mauna Kea, don't miss them!
The access is very affordable ($10 for a carload of people) and there are MANY things to see. So keep the access ticket given at the gate, because returning after dinning is REALLY worth it.

We visited that park and started off at the visitors centre where we learnt of the best sights to see. We went to the steam vents first which was spectacular!! We were here on a sunny day right after days of rain so they were really letting off steam! We went to jagger museum and saw the Kilauea crater which was fantastic, didn't see any lava but saw plenty of smoke. It would be amazing to be here at night as it has a red glow to the volcano. The road from jagger museum to the other side of the crater was closed due to volcanic activity. We then went to the thurston lava tube I was hesitant about going in these lava tubes as I thought it may be claustrophobic but it was fine! The tube could fit a large car inside them and it was well lit up and an amazing feeling. We drove past and stopped at a few pit craters and drove down to the 2003 lava that blocked the road off near the ocean lava was everywhere it was incredible too see!!
