We spent 4.5 hours in the park and I think that's the absolute minimum time you should spend here to really enjoy everything. It is a $10 fee to enter per car valid for 7 days that goes toward improving the park. One tip is they have a few places to get a beverage but not anywhere to eat we were starving when we left so bring some snacks at minimum!

As we've learned on this vacation... the least costly things to do in Hawaii are absolutely the best experiences! Today was the BEST $10 we have spent! Rainforests, lava tunnels, steam vents, hiking down into the crater, exploring the formations and steaming cracks, and then hiking back up - an accomplishment but well worth the effort. It was an overcast day (our helicopter tour was cancelled) so we spent much more time in the VNP and enjoyed every second. I actually don't know how we would have made the trek back up if it wasn't for the overcast skies and the light mist in the air. It is not for elderly or those with a disability. Such an interesting adventure for any age and any member of the family. The rangers are top notch and so good at directing you to the exact right excursion for your skill set and interests.

We left our hotel near Kona at 3pm to head to the Volcano. It is a very long drive due to low speed limit and twisty roads. Looking at the map I would have thought it would only take an hour to get there! In reality it was a 7 hour round trip, including time spent at the park. It was only $10 to enter the park. We went to the volcano museum where there are great views of the steaming crater about a mile away. Our young children were fascinated with the displays in the museum. We stopped at the steam vents which the children enjoyed. The heat from the steam is quite amazing. We also walked through the lava tubes. We were completely along for this. I don't know if it is usually busy.

If you come to the Big Island , this place is a must. Bring your hiking shoes and spend the day on the many well marked trails. Most of the people who visit will stay on the buses so it's fun to get out and walk. The trails are well marked and you have numerous examples of lave flows and collapsed roads to get a unique appreciation of volcanos at work. I also recommend the drive down Crater Parkway to observe the lave/ocean interface. The cost is minimal ($10 per car). Rent a car and explore.

If you're tired of just laying around working on your tan, give Volcanoes National Park a try. We rented a car for a day and drove over from the Waikoloa area. It's about a 2 hour drive, one way. Leave early and make a day trip out of it. You can visit Hilo at the same time. The entry into the park is $10 per car, one of the best deals on the island. We spent about 3.5 hours at the park which gave us time to see the main attractions and to do one of the trail hikes. We did the Halema'uma'u Trail, which leads you down to the Kilauea caldera. The trail starts behind the Volcano House. A word of warning, the hike takes you 425 feet down to the caldera floor, it's not bad going down but coming back up was a bit more difficult, the equivalent of climbing the stairs of a 35 story building. The staff at the visitor center can help you plan your visit, just tell them how much time you have.

Rented car from Enterprise Car Rental,shuttled quickly to nearby shop and we were off on our tour very quickly. Shuttle driver gave us directions and drive times to the local sites, so we were well prepared when we set off. Enterprise had a key drop off so we were not pushed for time. Volcano National Park was less than an hrs drive. Visit the ranger station first after you enter and pay your $10.00,the rangers will show you the maps and load you up with all the usefull information. Start at the volcano,skip the steam vents, then work your way back to the lava tube(worth the stop) and then the45 min ride to the ocean and the end of the road. Drive was very interesting,there were several view points( pick and chose) and the roads end was well worth it. We didn't realize what along day it was and we were not prepared for it, we should have packed a lunch and more water as there is nothing in the park except a small overpriced snack shack at the end of the road. Stopped for a late lunch on the way back,great day. With gas it cost $62 for 4 people

What an amazing place; you see the start of the world here! For $10 you are given a week long pass for the park. You can walk through lava tubes, hike around a giant creator, see the Jagger Museum and take a breath-taking 20 miles drive down to the coast. Simply one of the best experiences I can think of!

We arrived at the park around 9.30 a.m. It took us 3hrs 15 mins from Kona taking hwy 19 although we stopped at a few view points on the way and also for coffee and snacks. We left the park around 8 p.m. and took hwy 11 back to Kona, taking 2 hrs 15 mins. On arriving we went for a short walk with a Ranger which was very informative. Crater Rim drive was closed at the Jagger Museum so after spending some time in the museum and viewing area, we drove back, stopped at the Thurston Lava tube then onto Chain of Craters Road. Park signage could be better as a few times we stopped at areas that didn't seem to be much but turned out to be really worthwhile.... 1969-1974 Mauna Ulu lava flows for one.... short walk from parking lot. Went as far as we could go on Chain of Craters road...to the 2003 lava flows and walked on some of the youngest land on earth.... where the lava flowed across the road. In the distance on the shoreline, we could just about see some steam where the lava is presently entering the ocean. Went back to the Jagger Museum stopping at the Military Camp for Starbucks (Yes!) coffee.... they also serve good food at the camp. The Jagger Museum car park filled up very quickly around 6p.m. and people had to park in the overflow parking lot a short walk away, but by about 7.30 p.m. it was half empty.... perhaps because the temperatures had dropped considerably and it was cold... bring a jacket. Awesome to see the glowing flume cloud at night. So much to see for only $10 per vehicle! My only regret is we didn't get time to hike the Kilauea Iki trail which I really wanted to do.... will have to go again!!! If we were to go again, I would make this trail a priority and maybe stop off at the military camp for dinner before heading up to the Jagger Museum (around 8p.m.) for nighttime viewing of Kilauea. Apart from driving through pouring rain in Hilo area, the weather in the park was sunny and warm.... shorts and t-shirt.... although around about 5p.m. a fleece and/or jacket plus gloves was needed.

Volcanoes National Park was $10 per car and the highlight was the Thurston Lava Tube and interpretive centre with its awesome view of the crater. We learned a lot and drive down Chain of Craters Road, making sure we stopped at all the look-offs along the way. Very educational.

I loved going to this park! It was 10$ a car to get in, which I find reasonable. The lava tube is pretty awesome, and found the closed road at the bottom of the part very interesting. Best place to see the glow of the lava is from jaggar museum! The people at the visitor centre is very informative and friendly, and the art gallery beside the center has some interesting stuff.

This was my favourite day on the island (and it was only a day because we had limited time). We came from Kona so it was a long drive (about 2 hours – no traffic), but it’s worth getting to the park early. We arrived about 8:45am. It’s $10 per car for 1 week entry – very reasonable. Speak to the rangers at the main visitors centre first. They’ll give you ideas on what to do given your time frame. We found this really helpful. They also have guided tours you can go on, but we decided to explore the park on our own. My favourite trail was devastation. Even if you don’t walk the whole trail it’s worth walking a few minutes in to see part of it – the feeling was one that I’d never had before. It was breathtaking and eerie all at the same time. Make sure you stay to see the glow from the lava after sunset… worth the wait! Take your water bottle and snacks/picnic with you – there isn’t much in the park. Also, it does get cool and wet (weather changes in a heartbeat up there) so be prepared. We had a bite at the Lava Café nearby – check my review list for thoughts on it.

This was our second trip to park and so worth it. Entrance to the park is only ten dollars for a car, with your receipt good for a week, for as many returns as you like. During our day we a 90 minute free tour with Ranger Rick, check this out , if only for the nose flute! Also visited the Jagger museum, art studio, Thurston lava tube, steam vent's, several overlook's, visitor's center and walked the Kilauea Iki trail. All of these can easily be done in a day, with no rushing around involved. The weather can be changeable, so an extra layer is advisable. We did think would fry under the sun, down in the caldera on the Iki trail but there is quite a cooling breeze so don't think you wont make across, it's well worth the effort. All in all this park is has got to be on your "to do list", you wont be disappointed.

Visiting Hawaii National park was a good experience and is worth the $10 admission fee for a vehicle if you are going with others. Unfortunately when we visited, about 1/2 of the crater rim drive was closed due to sulphur dioxide fumes. We drove the portion of crater rim drive to see the jaggar museum, view the active crater from a distance, see the steam vents, and the sulphur deposits; however, after driving first to the museum, we realized that you can and probably should just walk as there are a few trails through the rainforest worth seeing.

The entrance fee of $10 for 7 days any day any time best value for money in any resort. Good information centre very helpful staff, maps and walking routes available. Access to the craters very good some are quite a walk but worth while.

You buy a $10 dollar pass per car that is good for 7 days, so make sure you save it, because you may need more than one day to visit this vast place, make sure you visit the different attractions available here and make sure you stay to see the glow of the volcano after sunset, memories to last a life time.

We booked this one-day trip through Viator and run by Polynesian Adventures. This was going to be one of the highlights of our Haiwaii vacation and cost me almost $1000.00for a day trip. This cost was a very large part of our budget and was greatly anticipated as a once in a lifetime treat. In retrospect, I shpuld have known better. The advertising site showed photos of smoke and red lava-flow and also indicated that a spectacular night-tour was available. I took this to imply that we had a chance of seeing some lave. Wrong! we were collected by coach from our hotel and then waited for two and a half hours at the airport before flying to the Big Island to be told immediately by our driver on the ground that we would not be seeing any lava-flow that day or any other. A bit late to cancel then. What followed was a coach trip around the Big Island visiting some sights but mainly spent long stops at souvineer-type attractions and the worst lunch I have ever struggled to force down. We did see the crater and some steam at one point but this stop was around 10% of the total time. At the end of our tour, the driver said we were very early for our flight back and did we want to roam around the shopping mall? Er, no! A complete waste of time and money. On return I complained to Viator who managed to obtain a partial refund ( everything but flight costs). This went some way to compensate us financially but nowhere near compensating all 3 of us for severe disappointment with our once-in-a-lifetime trip.

We happened to visit Hawaii Volcanoes National Park on the 100th anniversary of the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory. This was fortunate as the $10 entry fee was being waved - and the observatory was open to the public. HVO scientists were out in force explaining anything and everything about the park and volcanoes.

this attraction is incredible. we learnt so much and saw so much. id suggest to do the hike, it took us an hour and 40 min. it was incredible. we got some beautiful pictures and video. They only charge 10 dollars and thats a 7day pass.

Squeezed a trip into Hovenweep between doing the Four Corners Monument and the Mesa Verde. Had a nice walk around the well marked paths, uneven surface after the paved area finishes. Took an hour and the recommendation to take bottled water very important, hat and sun screen too.Cost just $6 to visit.

While window shopping in Estes Park we decided to stop by this gallery. So nice, tranquil music playing in the background while you view all the beautiful photography for sale. I bought two packages of blank cards with images of Rocky Mountain Park and a winter scene from downtown Estes Park (to be used for Christmas Cards). Prices were reasonable, my cards were $14.95 for a pack of 12.
park: Images of Rocky Mountain National Park

text: I found this gallery on the internet, while doing some research for a trip to the Rocky Mountain NP area. I was instantly fascinated by Eric's pictures. Determined to see the real pictures my husband and I decided to visit the gallery during our trip in September 2011. Coming all the way from the Netherlands and just having started our trip we had no intention what so ever to buy anything bigger than a postcard. However Eric's pictures turned out to be so mesmerizing, that my husband almost instantly fell in love with a certain picture. Although we really didn't plan to spend 120 $ of our travel budget for a photograph, we just knew we would regret it forever, if we walked out without purchasing that particular piece of art. So after a quick and informative talk with Eric, we decided to purchase the picture. Six weeks later it was delivered to our home in the Netherlands and has been embellishing our living room ever since. So far we have absolutely no regret we purchased this piece of art, which will remind us forever of a wonderful trip to a truly amazing place. The only regret we might have is that we couldn't afford to buy the bigger version of our picture such as the one displayed at the gallery. For us 'Images of Rocky Mountain National Park' is a real must see while in Estes Park and worth a detour, if you're in the area.
park: Images of Rocky Mountain National Park

text: Stunning photography, unique mattI got and finishing. Look around and you can find smaller versions of the larger pictures to create a collage of photos in your home for $150-$200.
park: Images of Rocky Mountain National Park

text: This is a terrific spot to learn a great deal in a very short period of time! The exhibits en route to the Liberty Bell provide some fascinating facts. There is plenty of space at the end of the hall to take in the bell itself. Admission is free, however, there is a donation box, which we highly recommend contributing to! We were fortunate that it was a quiet day, and it didn't take us more than 45 minutes from standing in line to completion.
When we visited (October 2017), the Independence National Historical Park building opened at 09:00 Hrs with only about 10 people in the queue. Admission is free.

Recommend you get tickets online ($1.50) for the Independence Hall tour in advance. It was too late for me to do that so we went to the Visitors Center on Sunday at 8:35am. After a short wait, we got out tickes free for the 9:45 tour, which was the first one available. That turned out to be perfect. We checked out the local area, the Document Room and did the 9:20 20-minute tour of Congress hall. When that ended we started the 9:45 tour of Independence Hall. Both tours were excellent. The guides were very knowledgable and friendly. After the tours, we went back to look at the documents some more and then checked out the Museum of the Americal Philosophical Society. All this made for a very special morning.

I realised how little I knew about US Independence - I know a lot more now. The parks staff are very knowledgeable and give a good presentation. Worth knowing that you can prebook a ticket. The tickets are free but reserving costs just over a $ - useful if you are tight for time.

How convenient is this place? Very! Get downtown, take 6th Street South, park at the Visitor Center on the left side of this one-way street. Pick up your FREE timed-tickets for Independence Hall from the Visitor Center. Tour the National Constitution Center just to the north of the Visitor Center. Why there first? If you don't do it now, you'll skip it later (and it's too important to be skipped). $15 per adult, book online. Excellent background to the Constitution and its importance. Minimum time to fully appreciate the National Constitution Center - 45 minutes. Then head south on 6th toward the Liberty Bell Center, but on the way, be sure to stop at the archeological remains of the original "President's House". Yes, this - not the D.C. White House was where Washington lived as President! A rented house! It is only a few steps further south to the Liberty Bell Center. Security is fearsome here, be aware and organised. Imagine really tough airport security. The displays are wonderful, but you want to see the bell, Right? They have done a fantastic job not only with the bell but with the building. The entire display area for the bell is angled toward the front of Independence Hall, seen in the background through a wall of glass windows as you pose for pictures by the bell. Out of Liberty Bell Center and into Independence Hall. Make sure you get there at least 30 minutes prior to the time on your tickets for more security. There is a line for the Hall, but not a long wait because of the time on your tickets and because groups of 50 or so are taken at a time. Tours begin roughly every 30 minutes, and begin with an orientation by Rangers in the south wing. From there you go to the Supreme Courth of Pennsylvania (not the U.S.) room, and then across the central hallway to the room we all want to see - where the Declaration of Independence and Constitution were debated, edited and signed. Upstairs you will visit the Long Gallery, a reception area, the Governor's Council Chambers, and another room sometimes used for Committee meetings, the U.S. Marshall's Office, and a storeroom. Ironically and very sadly, fugitive slaves were sometimes held for trial here - the irony is that this very room is directly over the room in which the Declaration and Constitution were dealt with! After this tour, you exit out of Independence hall and join another line, this one to tour the first House of Representatives and Senate Chambers - located in the adjacent building immediately to the North of Independence Hall. The House is on ground level. The Senate Chamber is upstairs. It was in this House Chamber that the first peaceful transition from one democratically elected government to another took place (1796, Washington to Adams). The truly shocking thing to me was how small (literally cozy) the Senate was! All in all, this is a must see for visitors to Philly. Open 9-5, very close and convenient parking, many eateries nearby, excellent gift shops in all locations. Certainly not the only things to see in this city, but an excellent start. Enjoy!

Excellent national trust here, comprising the Independence Hall, Constitution centers with movie theatre, the first presidential homes of Washington and Adams, and, of course, the Liberty Bell! Lots of history here! Tickets to Independence Hall are timed but free and available at the Will Call desk of the Centre. You will pass through airport type security to get in.

I searched on Trip Advisor for info on what was available in the Independence Hall area. I enjoyed 3 days in Philadelphia-that was very well done and gave a reasonable idea of how much you might do on each day. I found that ordering timed tickets on line for Independence Hall was a big time saver; it cost $1.50/ticket and was priceless! It was Spring break, so there were plenty of people around, but it all moved well.The area is much easier to navigate than it was in the 60's and 70's.

I cannot believe how filthy the bathrooms are at a National Historical Park!!! Not are they filthy but the people who are supposed to be cleaning the bathrooms are standing right outside of the bathroom talking to one another and smoking cigarettes. Must be nice to have a federal job and do a whole lot of nothing. There were stalls that didn't stay shut and some that had no toilet paper in them. But the woman who was supposed to clean it had no sense of urgency since the man who was supposed to clean the men's room and she were joking and yucking it up!!! I'm glad that our federal tax dollars are going toward their lack of work ethic. Congrats on a job not done!!!! Make sure you DO NOT USE THOSE BATHROOMS!!!!!

I highly recommend. $12 for an hour and 20 minute tour through an incredible cave 360ft below the surface. You can't go wrong. Just get their early to buy your tickets for the same day. The tours frequently sell out.

When we arrived at Jewel Cave there was only the $5.00 tour available. Yes you get to go inside the cave but only to a platform to listen to the ranger's speech. Taking the longer tour would be much more informative and fun. Call ahead to make sure that there are available tours as it is quite a drive to get there.

We (husband, me, 2 daughters ages 8 and 10) recently visited Jewel Cave and really enjoyed it. We got there at about 9am and were able to get tickets for a 9:20 tour, which was perfect (apparently they used to let you reserve tickets on the phone but aren't do that this summer). We took the scenic tour ($24 total for the 4 of us) and it was about 1.5 hrs. The ranger who led it was informative, interesting and funny. You take an elevator down to start the tour and there are lots of steps up/down but it was totally manageable for us. There was one woman in our tour who had asthma and hadn't brought her inhaler and she was having trouble, but everyone else was fine. The tour goes ~350 feet underground and though it's dark you can see some need things (though there are very few stalagtites/stalagmites here). If you're in the black hills, Jewel Cave is worth a visit!

We booked 7 days in advance and had not problems picking up our tickets. Lots of people turned away disappointed. Book well ahead and you will have it made. The cave is awesome and the guides are excellent. This was one of the best parts of our vacation. There is not much to do at the site though, there are a few trails and a very small gift shop. There is alos a fairly interesting video but we got more from our guide. Really good time and very good price. We did a family of 4 for $24, and were there for over 2 hours. Excellent value and good time.

Pay attention to the NPS website and book your tour in advance. I couldn't believe how many people were driving out on a whim to find out that no tours were available until the next day. The "Scenic Tour" is not as strenous as they make it out to be as the steps and stairs are so spread out that you don't realize how much up and down you're doing.

jewel cave is great ,big wide open cavens cost to go on the tour is $8 each and well worth it the tour is about 1hour 30 minutes and your guide is very knowledgeable,well lit inside and there is a lot of stairs to climb but the pace is easy but note it is only for the able bodied,lots to see the flow stone is strange looks like caramel, please note you can not touch anything at all.

Joshua Tree was our first park during our round trip. After the coast and LA that was extremely relaxing and slowing down our speed. We spent at least 5 hours there made several walks were always impressed by the nature and the trees there. Instead of buying the park ticket only we took the „Anual Pass“. The price was 80 $ but it is worth to buy it because several national parks accept it and after 3 parks it is payed. Considering what they offer it is cheap. Luckily we stayed the day after the park in a motel in the mountains with Joshuas close by. So we were able to enjoy these wonderful trees even during the evening time....

This was definitely definitely worth the drive from Palm Desert. It took us about an hour to drive there in the morning and 45 min on the way home. We were limited for time so did the one hour drive/highlights tour. We got out at all the stops for a hike and photo ops. Wasn't too busy at any of the stops we did. The estimated times for each hike on the map they gave us at the visitors centre was off... what they said would be a 30 min hike would actually be 10-15 and a 1 hour hike would be 30min. It was windy there so bring a sweater or windbreaker. It was cooler in the park than it was in Palm Dessert. Beautiful views and lots of Joshua Trees. It's $25 per car for a 7 day pass. Not much wildlife viewing. Only a few gecko/lizards. There is no water in the park so be sure to bring your own supply, as well as snacks and food!
If you plan on going to more than 1 National Park I highly recommend getting a National Parks Pass for $80 (entrance is $25 per car at Joshua Tree) since it lasts 1 year from the time you buy it.

Looking at rocks and trees did not sound impressive, but what a wonderful surprise. The park is superbly presented, with excellent roads, clear signage, informative staff at the entrances, enormous selection of hiking trails, and delightful range of desert flora and fauna. The winter's rains have stimulated massive greenery, flowers, and growth in all plants. The "gardens" of cactus trees, blossoming Joshua trees, and a great array of desert flowers decorates the unique rock formations. We entered from the east Cottonwood entrance, and exited at the main west gate, stopping at the "Rock Skull" and the Hidden Valley trail. We paid the $25 per car entrance fee - a bargain for the 5 of us. There are so many things we want to see when we come back.

We stopped at the Joshua Tree Visitor Centre and were given some great advice in planning our day in the park. Sorry I didn't get his name. He highlighted a map for us and we were off. It's $25 per vehicle for a 7 day park pass. The scenery is absolutely stunning. There are many places to pull of the road, many places to go walking. Our first stop was at Keys View. It was a clear sunny morning and we could see all the way to the Salton Sea. Beautiful valley view. It was extremely windy at the outlook and my husband almost lost his hat. We backtracked to Hidden Valley and did a spin through the campground. A little further down the road is the trail to Barker Dam. Be sure to see the petroglyphs near the end of the loop. It was an easy walk, about a two mile loop. Next stop was by Jumbo Rocks to see the Skull Rock. We then drove south to the Cholla Cactus Garden. It was so pretty. Most of the cacti were flowering. There are brochures at the start of the 1/4 mile trail loop to explain things as you walk through. We turned back north and exited the park at Twentynine Palms. We were in the park for 5 hours and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. There are no services in the park so be sure to bring water and snacks. There is also limited cell service. There are however many picnic tables and outhouses throughout.

We were blown away by the incredibly unique landscape of this desert region. An entrance fee of $25 gets you a week long pass to the park. There are maps, souvenirs, and food available at the West, North, and South entrances to the park. You drive from one interesting area to another to see the various rock formations, trees, plants, and views from the park. There are also old mines and ranches left over from the prospecting and cattle days.The rock formations from ancient volcanic activity are massive; large boulders piled together in irregular shapes and groupings. Some could be climbed on if you had the right equipment, but most visitors were content to hike around the trails at the base and gawk or take pictures. The Joshua trees themselves are very weird; tree shaped with branches and trunks, but with cactus like growths at the ends of each branch. There is something in this park for all ages, and handicapped people could see quite a bit of it by simply driving through. There is more than enough to do for a full day here. Definitely a must see if you're staying in the Coachella Valley.

We were looking for an interesting day drive. The trees and rocks of that location are interesting and we had a nice walk and scenic drive. Itvwas interesting but I wouldn't go out of my way again. The gate fee isn't worth it. It may be worth $5-10. Basicly we drove through and walked about a bit. So For that it was too much $$

Had one day to explore Joshua Tree National Park, decided to hike Boy Scout Trail. From researching the various hiking trails this one had all the various landscapes that you see throughout the park. Joshu Trees, Rock Formations , Caves ,Desert flats, Panaramic views. I parked my vehicle at the south trail head and used a cab company by the name of Desert Sun to transport me to the north trail head for $50. I went north to south however south to north is less strenuous
The entrance fee is 20 dollars. There are many hiking trail. Pay attention to rattlesnakes! And bring a lot of water

Joshua Tree National Park is amazingly huge. For first time visitors, plan to stay for at least 3-4 hrs. There is a U$20 entry fee per car. Prices vary according to which type of vehicle you drive. You can just drive through the park, or hike the different routes, go rock climbing, admire the landscape and of course, the tall, short and spiky Joshua Tree. The U$20 fee allows you to visit the park more than once for a week from the date of purchase.

It's a 5 mile drive from the Joshua Tree Visitor Centre to the park entrance. Cost $20 but that's for 7 days. Excellent info as always from the National Parks. Well sign posted, toilets and picnic benches. Well maintained. A good few hours and informative. If, like me, you like rocks & geological info, it's good.
Absolutely unique desert experience. Joshua Trees like you've never seen before. Feeling of beauty and lonelieness all at the same time. High desert and just a very beautiful drive

We drove through Joshua Tree in one clear, sunny morning and experienced fantastic views of the high and low desert. We stopped along the way to do short hikes - Arch Rock, Skull Stone, etc. Cost was $20/vehicle and was well worth it. We entered at the south Cottonwood exit which was good. The traffic going in the other direction was much heavier. In fact, as we left the park near Joshua Tree, there was a huge line-up to get in. The park and road is well maintained and easy to navigate. There is quite the climb so they recommend turning off your A/C so you don't overheat your car. We got some fantastic photos. I would love to return and stay in one of the many campsites.

We had wanted to spend a whole day walking around here but alas only had Sunday to quickly visit here en route to Las Vegas via Hoover Dam tour. We previously ensured we had the U2 album "Joshua Tree" playing in car (U2 did visit the park and named album after these funky trees). You need a car. The staff at the park HQ/visitor info were grumpy when I said we only had an hour but such is life. It cost USD$20 to take the car in (mandatory) then there were plenty of stops with windy loos (toilets) and walks with informative plaques. Loved the scenery, all well worth it.

This was our second visit to Joshua Tree National Park. Lots of great hiking and photo opportunities. Dangerously windy at Key View but the view was worth it. We planned to be at the Cholla Gardens as the sun set behind the mountains, and we took a few pictures. Take care if you're visiting the gardens... those suckers are sharp!! Joshua trees and boulder outcroppings are really cool. Feels a bit like Bedrock. Kept expecting to see Fred Flintstone pedal by.

We traveled to Joshua Tree Natl Park and knew that the trees were quite different, but we didn't expect the incredible rocks and views. It was unfortunately a very cold and windy day when we arrived (44F without the wind factor), so we didn't venture out on hike, which we wanted to do. So we stayed on the road from the West Entrance to the North entrance and were able to take in the scenery. I would like to visit again and be able to go up to Keys View or Mt Ryan, both of which I am told offer spectacular views. For November, there was a lot of people hiking and lots of traffic on the 45 mph road. If you are 62 yoa be sure to get your lifetime NP pass for all US Natl Parks, only $10 for life, and the whole car with passengers are able to enter under your pass. Sweet!
We headed out about 10:30am and looking back we should have gotten up earlier. It is $20 per car for the day.

Joshua Tree National Park is a real find. We were visiting the area for a festival, and found we fell in love with the desert vibe. The drive through the Joshua Tree National Park is well worth it. You start to see the beauty of the boulders stacks ("Boulder Art"!), and the forest of unusual Joshua Tree cactus trees takes on a beauty of its own. Stopping at some of the boulder piles and sitting amongst them gives you a chance to really feel into the desert and rock piles and the total quiet stillness. It is US$20 for a 3 day Park ticket, and you can camp at designated camping sites.

Six of us drove out from Palm Springs to the "Joshua Tree National Park" (took over an hour to get there) to spend the day hiking. Wish we had allowed ourselves more time as we missed seeing a couple of the places we had highlighted. Make sure you get there early if you only have one day to explore, there is so much to see. I believe the visitor centers open at 8:00 a.m. Admission to the park is extremely reasonable, $15.00 per vehicle and is good for 7 consecutive days. We would have saved a lot of time if we had gone in at the west entrance station (Joshua Tree Visitor Center) instead of the north entrance (Oasis Visitor Center). Of course we missed the first entrance and ended up entering and exiting from the north which made for having to do some backtracking once in the park. Would recommend starting out with the hike at Hidden Valley. This is an easy, 1 mile loop that circles the interior of a small valley surrounded by tall rocks that serve as an excellent bouldering arena. Some beautiful rock formations and we did see a few climbers. From Hidden Valley, drive up to Keys View and take some pictures. There is a 1.2 mile hike you can do there as well from Keys View to Inspiration Peak but we didn't have enough time. From Keys View head towards Jumbo Rocks and Skull Rock. We missed stopping at Jumbo Rocks but we did get out at Skull Rock to take a few pictures. From there drive to the parking lot at Split Rock Trail. This hike is often overlooked as it isn't as publicized as some of the others, but it is so worth doing. It is an easy 2+ mile loop with some amazing rocks that are even more beautiful in the afternoon sun. These were all the areas we saw while at the park, but if we'd had a bit more time, I would have liked to finish off by seeing Arch Rock and taking a walk around the Cholla Cactus Garden. Maybe next time! All the Joshua trees throughout this park are pretty amazing to see as well. Don't miss out on visiting this park if you are vacationing in the Palm Springs area.

On our last day in Palm Springs, we decided to finally go to the Joshua Tree National Park. We only had a couple of hours, but we managed to go the Keys Views (a must!) and walked through the Hidden Valley. Wow...all the pictures you see just don't do it justice. It's an amazing place! Several of the areas allow you to walk around and climb on the rocks too, so if you have kids, they will love it! Entry fee is reasonable ($15 per car) and it's valid for a week. Can't wait to go back and see more!

The park is very well maintained with trail, restrooms, parking and picnic areas throughout. Entrance fee is $15 for a one week pass. There are great view points of the Palm Springs valley, lots of fantastic hiking trails along with rock climbing for all experience levels. Had a great time here. Bring your camera and water!

started drive at Cottonwood Visitor, and paid our $15 entry fee-Good for 4 days, and had a leisurely drive to Twentynine Palms, stopped for many view area and had a few short hikes, could do long hikes but we chose short ones, many beautiful areas of different dessert area, cactus and unusual rock formation,

This park is beautiful. I can't believe we hadn't visited it before on our previous trips to the Palm Springs area. I highly recommend this beautiful drive. We entered through the West Entrance Station. The entrance fee per car was $15. We drove through to the Cottonwoods Springs Entrance. We stopped along the way to visit many sites of interest and viewing areas. The Keys View vista had a stunning view of the valley. Along the Western part of the drive there were many, many Joshua Trees. Most were not blooming yet. In the Eastern part of the drive, the elevation decreases and the climate changes and the Joshua trees disappear. We saw blooming Ocotillo cacti and lots of windflowers. The Cholla Cactus Garden was stunning. We didn't hike because we had our elderly parents with us, but we would definitely return to do some hiking!

Our friends Brian and Louise took us to Joshua Tree National Park. The entrance fee is a reasonable $15 per carload. Lots of good bathroom facilities, parking spots, and picnic tables. An easy, but very scenic hike is the Hidden Valley loop. It is about a mile long and filled with wonderful rock formations and Joshua trees.

Unbelievably beautiful and dramatic with hiking trails for all tastes and abilities, great campgrounds, good (but discreet) restrooms, a cheap entrance fee ($15) and, although busy, big enough to feel wild and exciting.

A closer look at these trees tell you they can survive with much less water yet they are tough, strong green leaves and nice big white flowers. It takes one hour to drive through them, in between there are spectacular rock formations to wow you ad you stop at scenic points along the way. The National Park charges $13 for the trip but it is worth your money to wonder at a unique & special trees only found in this part of the world, no where else.

On a trip to the west coast, we entered the park from I-10 and drove north. The $15 permit (valid for 7 days) covered the car and four passengers. Dramatic scenery changes and organized trails provide for hikers, campers and photographers. We spent 3 hours; however, we could easily have spent several days.

This may not figure in the top US national parks but it is a fascinating drive. We entered via the South entrance and exited from the North-West (via the town of Joshua Tree) and it was probably the right call to view both distinctive deserts. The first is empty and forbidding but the different shades of light make it quite beautiful. Passing through the boulders that divide the two regions, there are plentiful Joshua Trees to admire - again in a beautiful if very different environment. We spent around 4 hours there but we could have easily spent far longer. And if you're into hiking there are obviously some great trails to spread over a few days. The vantage point at Keyes View is certainly worth the short detour for a view over the valley. And the road surface is (largely) amongst the best you'll find in California!

We visited the Joshua Tree National Park yesterday for the first time. We found it to be quite unique - huge one-of-a-kind rock formations, that draw lots of climbers, and vegetation that is unique to the area. Since I recently had knee surgery, we didn't do any hiking, just mostly stuck to the main roads for sightseeing from the car. It is a hiker's paradise though. Got a pretty good look at the San Andreas fault from one of the high vantage points. Make sure you take food and water with you as there's no food for purchase in the park. One word of advice - if you've come in at the West gate, probably best to go back out the west gate when you want to leave. My husband decided to go all the way out to the east end, and the road is torturously winding and curvy (much worse than the Road to Hana!) Note that there is a $15 fee per car to enter the park.

This is a must see. There are so many walking and hiking opportunities in this unique high desert. We only did a short hike in one part of the park but it was awe inspiring. Well worth the $15.00 per car pass (good for the week). It was so peaceful and serene I thought I may have left planet earth for a short while.

A little info to share. There are 3 ways down to the town. You can hire a mule group to ride the trail and a lunch along with a guided tour will be included. You can fly a small plane from top side to the little strip below, again joining an escorted tour. Lastly, you can hike down and back to connect with your guided tour. There are also combinations of the choices such as walk down, fly out, etc. The tour for us was $60 each cash only. No pets or kids under 16 allowed at the bottom. We are a mid 60s couple who like to hike but are not rabid hikers. We chose to do the hike round trip. We flew in for the day from Maui and got a rental car from Alamo at the airport for $70. There are cabs and maybe Uber but with spotty cell service especially at the trail head we wanted to control the transportation. That also allowed us to be flexible on time and have food/drink and a change of dry clothes waiting. You must make arrangements with a tour group or National Park service BEFORE visiting. Mule tours will make the arrangements or "permit" for you. As hikers we paid $60 each cash only to the van driver and signed our name on the "permit" sheet. Done deal, signs everywhere announce $500 fine for hiking without a permit but the catch is we had to hike down to get the "permit" ---Crazy Hawaii! We went to Google to find a tour connection. Father Damien Tours was chosen. We called and our names were put on the reservation list. No deposit was taken nor confirmation # given. After hanging up we were a little apprehensive as to whether that was it, it was very casual. Now the hike. The trail head is not clearly marked. Look for parked cars on the right side of the road just past the mule corral, I believe just past mile marker 5. Park next to one of the parked cars and lock up. If you enter the adjacent state park with overlook you have gone a little too far. Start as early as you can for several reasons: beat the mules and their droppings, they start out around 9am. The early hours on the trail are cooler and more peaceful which also allows you to pace yourself yet still arrive early. Tour vans will pickup either the mule group or the hikers at the bottom of the trail at the mule corral at 10am and wait a few minutes or so for any hiker on the reservation list that has not arrived. There are two separate tour groups. We were very happy with our guide Steve. He was a long time Hawaiian resident, retired Navy guy how also likes to teach history. And the van was brand new not the old school bus seen in the web site. The tour lasted about 3 hours which includes a lunch break. Be sure to pack your own lunch and water for the day as the little store in town has limited supplies. Drinking water and restrooms are located in several locations during the tour. Speaking of water we started the hike with 3 water containers. We drank often as you sweat like you are in a sauna. Hard exercise and 95% humidity mixed with 80 degrees. There are 26 numbered switch backs on the trail. We stashed water near one of the switch back signs for the hike back. We chose #7 as it would be 2/3 the way up and the number was easy to remember. You do stuff like that when you get old! Hiking down took 90 minutes. The trails is steep but has block and concrete steps all the way. Molokai is a wet place. You need to look before stepping over rocks and puddles. Walking steep trails downhill will leave you sore in unused muscles for days after. We used adjustable snow shoe poles to help balance which proved indispensable. We disassemble the lite weight poles so they could fit in our carry on bag. Mokulele Airlines was not as picky as the larger companies about sharp objects or water bottles. At 2:30pm tour over and we started back. There were 7 hikers that hiked down, 2 took the flight back. At 4:30 we were topside, dripping wet but felt we had really earned this memory.

We hiked down to the leper colony in Kalaupapa Valley. It was a muddy hike and slippery and strenuous (but we are from Colorado so we did it anyway) 3.5 mile hike down steep switchbacks. The local airline has good deals to fly into the colony and you can mule ride out (or mule ride both ways). There are a ton of signs that say you need a written permit to hike down ($500 fine) but we just paid Gloria, who runs the bar at the leper colony and that seemed to work fine. Her phone # is 808 567 6171 and she charged us $25 pp. Not sure if this was only to walk around the leper colony or for that + the hike. There are 2 tour companies that monopolize the hike but the USA National Park service people who were working on the trail were nice and didn’t seem to care about permits. In summary, it was nice, but probably not worth the money. I certainly wouldn’t pay $70 pp to do a self guided muddy hike. The cliffs are supposedly the highest sea cliffs in the world. (not sure is this is the HI version of the oldest pub in the UK- all pubs seem to claim this!)

If you decide to hike down, book with Father Damien Tours website directly to pay $50+tax. If you book with Mule Ride (aka Kalaupapa Guided Mule Tour) for the hike, they charger you $69, take their cut and still send you to Father Damien Tours. Nevertheless, the Mule Ride will send you to their coffee shop first to waste your time and try to generate some business.

We spent 6 days on Moloka'i and decided to book a tour to Kapaupapa (booked through Moloka'i Outdoors). We chose the fly-in/fly-out option. The tour was interesting and worth the time (by flying in/out there were some sites seen that were not visited by folks who hiked down or took the mules). However, the best part of the experience was the helicopter flight from the "topside" airport at Moloka'i to the air field at Kalaupapa, having a close view of the sea cliffs. And then the flight back from Kalaupapa to topside via Maui. The view of the Pali coast from the air was totally amazing (could never describe in words), followed from the aerial view of Halawa Valley, and on the return from Maui of the barrier reef along the coast and the many historic fish ponds along the south-east coast of the island. The total cost (approx $215 per person) was pricey but well worth it (lunch was provided)

There is an easy, paved and well marked trail that circles the visitor's center. Explore the history and plants along the way. But for the real views like the sea turtles and fishponds, be prepared to earn them. Two loop trails take you to the turtles and follow the lava lined beach. They are not well marked except at the start and as they cross each other. Take plenty of water, head covering, sunblock and real hiking shoes that lace and support your ankles. After getting to the sea you might see several sea turtles napping in the shallow and tidal pools. Stay at least 20 feet away from the protected turtles. The trails from there on are on rough lava rock. Pay attention to the evidence that others have walked in that direction as the lava in many areas gives little clues as to the route. With the ocean to your back and the highway overlooking the visitors center to get your bearings, the shorter of the two hikes will take you 2-2.5 hours. You will certainly know a lot about lava when you reach the visitors center.

Great views. Great history. Nice place for a walk. Saw sea turtles. Pay your $5 for the national pass and walk over to the snorkeling area for great views of fish and sea turtles. Need to take 2 steps off of rocks to get in the water

The boat(Alaskan explorer) is comfortable with 3 toilets which were regularly checked and kept clean throughout the 8.30 hour cruise.We were given a hot cinnamon roll,bowl of mixed fruit and small can of fruit juice for breakfast,a wrap with a lot of chicken and salad for lunch together with crisps,a 2 bar pack of cereal bar and water and freshly baked cookie in afternoon.These were all complimentary and often there were second helpings.The tea and other hot drinks you pay for.A cup of tea was $2 or you could buy an unlimited refill cup of hot or cold drinks for $7.99.The staff were amazingly kind and helpful.When the sea was rough they came round checking on everyone.They were well informed and professional.I took the long tour which goes to the North western fjords,well worth the price.Hotels can get you 10%discount and Ballayne House can get you 20%.We saw whales,the boat stops to allow you to enjoy the sightings,seals...hundreds,sea lion colony,puffins,porpoises.The glacier is breathtakingly beautiful.The captain stays a long time so you can admire it and switches off the engines.The glacier calves continuously.I rate this whole experience as unmissable.The whole thing is done so well and each person gets individual attention.

We went on the saltwater lodge boat trip to the fjords. This was a small boat with only 13 of us passengers and two crew. Costs a little more than the big boats but worth every penny. Amazing day out and our Captin Tanya was excellent at spotting wildlife we saw plenty of whales and much more.
Liked the way the cruise was managed. Advised to take sea sick tabs, purchased on boat for only $2pp. We were warm and adequately fed.

Kennesaw Mountain Battlefield Park is not as well-known as Gettysburg or Chickamauga but it is just outside Atlanta and was the last "hill" before the investment of Atlanta by Federal troops in the Civil War. The programming is well done but on a bit of a smaller scale than many other battlefield parks. The museum is smaller but well-appointed and informative. The live re-enactments are fairly frequent and very well done. This past weekend for the 148th Anniversary of the battle there were Artillery (3 pieces), Infantry, Signals, and encampment live re-enactments throughout the weekend. The hike up the mountain is a bit challenging for many but the new buses are inexpensive ($2 or so for adults) and convenient. There is no food on site but several nice local places are nearby and there is a mall about 10 minutes away for those that want predictable chain food.

We have a lifetime pass for the national parks that we bought this year. If you are 62 or older you can buy a lifetime pass for $10. There was still snow on the ground in May, but the roads were clear. No words can do justice to the beauty of the park. We entered through the south entrance of Kings Canyon and went to General Grant Tree which was a must see. We also saw the General Sherman. We exited the park to the city of Three Rivers. They are working on the road at this exit and it took us over an hour of stop and go trafffic to exit the park. May is a great time to go.

Entrance fee to Lassen Volcanic National Park is $20 per car. The visitor center had various informational displays and rangers answering visitors' questions. Along with bathroom facilities, there were drinking fountains and a water dispenser for filling your water bottles. Also, there were two small souvenir shops and a cafe at the center. You can also buy bags of ice at the cafe. For first-time visitors to Lassen Volcanic National Park checking out the visitor center before exploring the national park will be very helpful.

$20 for our SUV seven day pass allowed excellent tour of the forest park and Canyon. The Mor Rock climb, General Sherman Tree, Kings Canyon were beautiful with some outstanding views and well worth a visit though those who are fearful of heights and mountain drives should be weary and recommend only experienced drivers tackle these roads independently otherwise use an organised tour. Park staff were excellent and friendly with great advice and how to plan your tour. All in all a very memorable and enjoyable visit and highly recommended.
park: Lakes Trail in Sequoia National Park

text: We wanted to visit the General Sherman Tree as we were passing by the area. The roads are curvy and driving up 7000 feet takes up alot of your time. You do see lots of deer in the area and less tourist then Yousemite, so you do enjoy it better. Highway 245 to avoid at night to exit the park, it is dark with short curve paths, near the edge. Inexperienced drivers should avoid. We wishes we could have stayed longer then a day, campsites are amazing, the path to general Sherman is paved and easy access for those in wheelchairs. Park entry fee is $30 USD for 7 days per vehicule.
park: Lakes Trail in Sequoia National Park

text: The lava tubes were fun (and cool--in both senses of the term), but another highlight was scrambling around Captain Jack's Sronghold (where 60 Modoc held off 600 US soldiers by using natural lava features as a fortress). We were the ONLY people there. Rugged, beautiful scenery and worth the one dollar to buy the trail guide to learn about the Modoc War. We spent about 45 min. on the inner loop, and there is a longer, outer loop option as well. Great place for kids to run around after being in the caves.

Believe it or not, this is world headquarters for Lava Tube Cave exploration, not the Big Island of Hawaii. But this NM is not easy to get to. From Lassen National Park it is 130 miles, 2.5 hours. From Crater Lake it is 90 miles and 1.25 hours. From Klamath Falls it is 48 miles and 1 hour. From Reno it is 220 miles and 4 hours. And from Sacramento it is 320 miles and 5 hours. It is open all year. $15 per car. In peak summer season the hours are 8-6; the rest of the year it is 8-5. There are over 800 lava tube caves in this Monument. Keep in mind that the temperature in the caves will be much cooler than the temperature outside. Dress accordingly. Rocks in the intermediate and advanced caves will be closer to you (sometimes forcing you to crouch or even crawl) and so you should wear long sleeves, long trousers, knee pads, gloves and sturdy boots. You will also need head protection and some lighting source. The Visitor Center sells helmets at reasonable prices, and checks out flashlights which must be returned the same day. Now don't lose hope. There are three 'beginner's caves' to chose from: the mush pot cave very close to the Visitor Center, with it's own lighting, and a prepared floor, enabling disabled access; the Golden Dome cave, also near the Center; and the Valentine Cave in the southeast of the park. Enjoy!

We decided to include Lava Beds in our US West Coast itinerary at the last minute and are very glad we did. Although we only had half a day, the park is quite compact and the main attractions are close together. The rangers were very helpful ( as always) and gave us tips on the best things to see. We went down three on the lava tubes with the help of the torches loaned from the visitor centre. What a fascinating volcanic feature. The lava flows are amazing and the chimneys at Feeneys unexpected. We didn't have time to look at the historic sites associated with the Indian wars, but thought the introductory video rather played down the injustices they suffered at the hands of settlers and the army.

I am not the outdoorsy type, and no way am I going in a cave, yet I LOVED the day we spent here. The vastness of the park and all there is to do is amazing. It was $10 a car to get it which is an amazing price especially because it would be very easy to spend an entire day here.

This place is awesome! We brought our 7 and 10 yr. olds here, arrived at 10am and left at 4:30pm. It was a full day of caving. We felt like we had a really good idea of what the park had to offer, but could have stayed for days longer if we had the time. At US$10/car to get into the park, we felt guilty about how much fun we had! It is a steal!

The campground host is now selling firewood. This is the first season they are selling @ $7 bundle. We were unable to find any firewood in tulelake. Also they sell ice at the visitor center, but it is much cheaper at the grocery store in tulelake.

From where we were camping, we drove close to an hour to get to the Visitor Centre within the park, The drive from the North ($10 park fee) entrance was progressively getting more interesting. The rugged outcrops of black/brown lava were an incredible contrast to the surrounding landscape. Devil's Homestead was a fantastic sight -- a whole sea of lava that looks like it had bubbled to the surface.

I had thought that Lincoln's house would be somewhat recreated but I was wrong. 80% of the furniture and artifacts are originals. Admission is free and NPS Rangers provide a most professional commentary. The visitor centre is high quality too.

Historic site (no fee) with the Lincoln home, the house where he lived with his family before he was elected president. The Lincoln home you can only enter with a guided tour and you need tickets (at visitor center, also no fee; only the parking lot is $2/hour). It is a tour of about 30 minutes and very interesting to learn more about his life as a husband and father. Much furniture is still original. Also surroundings with houses like it was in Springfield in the first half of the 19th century. Enthusiastic rangers, like the tourguide and at the visitor center. Really worth to visit if you have a couple of hours
Tickets are free. Arrive ahead of time and catch the video. Paid carparking across the road. Our tour ranger was great (sorry forgot his name)

Visited with my wife during a mid-west road trip. Parked for $1 and the visit was free. Managed by the National Parks Service with very knowledgeable guides who depart every 5 minutes with a new tour group. We found the house most instructive in understanding the Lincoln background to eventual fame.

My husband and I went to the visitor center first thing in the morning, opening at 9:00, there is parking right on property $2.00 an hour. You will get a assigned time for the tour... Watch the film it runs about 23 minutes. The ranger or tour guide will take you through the house, which is well preserved. Take time after the tour of the house and walk the preserved street to get a feel for what it was like during the 1860's. We did this part first, and then went to the Lincoln Library ... Better to do this part in the morning, and the library later ...
Car park at the side is pay, $2 per hour, we only needed one hour.

From the Lincoln-Herndon Law Offices, three blocks S on 6th to Jackson, and 1 block E to the Visitor Center. 426 E 7th. Open 8:30-5 daily except Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's. There is a Visitor Parking lot just south of the Visitor Center ($2 per hour). Leave any large bags in your trunk. Unfortunately, street parking is only a maximum of 2 hours per day. Arrive early - honestly this should be your first stop on any tour of Lincoln sites in Springfield. If you arrive after 1 pm there is a distinct possibility that you may not get house-tour tickets! Tours are free, but you must have time-stamped tickets to join the tour. So as soon as you enter the Visitor Center, get those tickets! If you have a long wait, you can view the videos, browse the gift shop, or rest in the benches under the trees along the street. A four block area of homes surrounding Lincoln's home has been preserved, so you can also take a look in these. When we visited, 3 of them were open. Preserving the Neighborhood and not just the home gives you a feel for what the area was like in the 1850s. Tours are guided, last 20-25 minutes, and begin just outside the home. The tour itself consists of the parlour, sitting room, dining room and kitchen on the ground floor. On the second floor you see the bedrooms of Mr. Lincoln, Mrs. Lincoln, eldest son Robert, younger sons Willie and Tad, and the bedroom of the housekeeper. I thought the kitchen was the most interesting. What a lot of work using those 'primitive' means to provided family meals. Poor housekeeper! But I was wrong as far as the most intriguing spot in the house was concerned. On the way up the stairs, the guide said that the railing on the stairs was the original, used by all in the family including Mr. Lincoln. To my knowledge this is the ONLY presidential home/museum that allows 'ordinary tourists' to routinely touch something used Routinely by someone of Lincoln's stature! Enjoy!

Take a walk inside Lincolns home and listen to stories of family as told by very informative and enthusiastic guides. Feel how life was for the Lincolns before they moved to the Whitehouse . Not to be missed . Includes movie and other artefacts inside the visitors centre.

We visited this site today. We parked at the visitor center. It cost $2 for one hour but we were told they never ticket or tow if you go beyond the one hour. Your visit must start at the Visitor's Center in order to get tickets from the information desk for the house tour. They run tours every 15 minutes and the tour is free. Our guide took us through the house explaining everything about the house and furniture, a bit on the life of the Lincoln's in Springfield and how this historic site was created. You can take pictures inside the house which is really nice. There are other houses that can be visited on this historic site (about 4 acres) but we chose to go back to the visitor's center and watch a short 20 minutes movie on Abraham Lincoln. This attraction is highly recommend.

Call into the visitors center first to get your tour tickets (free but donations welcome) Parking on site is $2 per hour but as we visited on a Sunday we parked on the road for free. Excellent well informed tour guide takes you around Lincolns home and then you can explore the rest of the site on your own. Well worth a visit.

We visited on a weekday morning, so there weren't many other visitors. The tour is free, but you need to get a ticket from the desk at the Visitor's Center. There is a parking lot next to it, and costs $2/hour. Note that it is on a one way street - we had to go around the block to get into the parking lot.
Main home plus outbuildings. Period furnishings with some original Lincoln family owned pieces. Expert tour guides. Tickets are free but must be obtained from the visitors center. Groups are welcome.

Lowell National Historic Park encompasses multiple tours and exhibits from canal tours to how the mills got their power to the life of the mill workers. I have taken multiple tours here and learned something on all of them. Most recently we went on a canal tour and although the river was high and the boat couldn't go through the lock, the ranger gave us an outstanding tour of the lock by land which was excellent. Going on the boat tour is particularly appealing for families as those interested in the history get to hear a lot while those interested in sitting and looking around are equally entertained. Plus you get to ride BOTH a trolley and a boat. Plenty of low cost parking including a parking garage with $3 parking.

You can take a self guided driving tour for free, with lots of other exhibits near the home itself. We thought the house tour was really good and worth the $3 price. Groups limited to 12 at a time which is nice. You might want to plan ahead though if going on a weekend or during a busy time. We were there on a Tuesday afternoon and only had to wait about 20 minutes for our tour time. Lots to see while you wait though. I think tours are done every 10 minutes and last about 30 minutes.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We found this place on way back from Fredericksburg. Time was short. We did have time to tour the ranch and look around some. I wish we had more time before it closed. The tour of the house was good. There where old planes and cars on display. It is a working ranch. There is a small grave yard where LBJ was buried you can visit. What a nice place. The tour only $3 for the house tour. But you can look around the rest of the place for free. There are restrooms and gift shop.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: What a great place to look around. The little farm at the beginning of the State Park was a nice little walk and we had an interesting talk with the staff there, the smell of the food cooking in the kitchen (no electricity) was mouthwatering. Then back in the car to LBJ's childhood home and the cemetery where he and his family are buried. Then a short car ride alongside his airstrip to his ranch house. The plane and cars were great to see as was the $3 tour of inside of the house - it was like going back in time. As it took ages to go around everywhere it would have been nice to have a refreshment area. All in all well worth a visit.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: This was a highlight of our visit to the area on March 17, 2015. Entry to the park is free and includes a drive with some stops, providing information of both the history and current status of the ranch. There is a gift shop in the hangar with the opportunity of purchasing tickets ($3 each) for a 20-minute National Park Service tour of the ranch house. I highly recommend the house tour. It's what I will remember for a long time.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We had been to this Historical Park niumerous times. We started visiting since early 80's with guided tours. The bus took people from Lyndon B Johnson's boyhood home in Johnson City then to his Ranch in Stonewall, Tx. It is approximately 14 miles apart. We have seen the transformation of this historical site. I remember seeing Ms. Lady Bird outside their house while our tour bus was passing thru. Now that she has passed, we take self tours with our out of town visitors. It is very easy and convenient. You stop at the LBJ Boyhood home in Johnson City first then drive to the ranch. We stop at the visitor center to pick up a CD which will instruct and guide you throughout the park in the convenience of your private car and company of family and friends. The LBJ house is partially open now. Every year, they add a room or two available for public to see. A nominal fee of $2.00 or $3.00 is paid prior to entering the house. It is educational. The place history buffs will enjoy. Donations are accepted. There is a drop box for the CD at the end of the tour. You do not even have to go back to the Visitor Center. How cool is that?
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We were surprized at how much we were able to see. The self-guided tour was easy with the map and CD given to us at the Visitor Center. The tour was very well done and included recordings made by the President and the First Lady. The family cemetery and gravesites of the Pres. and Mrs. Johnson seemed like a quiet country cemetery that could be found anywhere was quite a contrast to the sprawling "Texas White House" with the presidential jet and luxury cars just down the road! The house has been restored to the way it was during Johnson's presidency and a $3 ticket gets a quick tour with basic information of the main floor. There is not much time to really look at things, but the tour guides answer questions. Groups are moved through the house quickly, but you can take as much time as you want wandering around the property, seeing the oak tree under which Johnson held meetings (one quarter of his presidency was spent here so the run way was well used by those meeting with him here rather than in Washington), the river bank where barbecues with top entertainment for up to 1500 people were held, the garages with glass sides providing easy viewing of Johnson cars etc. Very interesting were the cement slabs on which guests to the ranch "wrote" their names. It was fun finding names of other presidents, politicans, entertainers, astronauts etc. Our only downer was leaving the park at closing time when we stopped almost at the gate, hoping to take a quick final picture from the car. A car with a guide pulled up beside us and told us to leave immediately as she was locking the gate and we would have to call 911 to get out! That took more time than it would have for us to take the picture - and left us feeling a little less enthused about the experience. There are also very good exhibits etc. at the visitors' center.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Very impressive ranch-- a working farm with all in costume describing what it was like back in 1918 (no electricity on the farm)- sure makes you think! The overall site is massive, the Texas White House complete with 7000 ffoot long airstrip, cattle everywhere. The house tour is very impressive. Free but $3 for house tour-don't miss it
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: This national park is all about the underworld: the largest cave system in the world, with hunderds of miles of caves. It is not possible to explore the caves on your own, you have to book a tour at the visitor's center or online. The ranger guided tours are excellent, I took the 4 hour Grand Avenue Tour ($26). Don't expect many stalagmites and stalagtites. They are scarce, the only bigger one is the Frozen Niagara, part of the Grand Avenue Tour. The cave are large corridors below the ground, sometime wide, sometimes curving and very narrow. The upperworld is also nice, with nice trails through the woods close to the Green River. Part of the river goes onderground forming new caves (Styx). There are many birds and mammals. There is no entrance fee, you only have to pay for the tours. There is a nice hotel and large campground.
Buy a ticket for a self-guided tour (it costs 5$ per person) and enjoy a walk inside a huge cave and the park outside it and learn something new about the trip of water under the ground.

Took the ranger led Domes and Dripstones tour with over 100 others. This is the world's longest cave system, an underground labrynth comprising over 400 miles of interlocking caves used as far back as 4,000 years ago. 500 steps in and out, 280 to get 250' down, some rock carved, some metal, mostly narrow at a cost of $ 3,000 per step! Really. We bussed to the roughly hewn entrance. Initially the cave is dry with few formations, but as we got lower, it became wetter, with more formations like stalactites and mites. There are a few domes and a pit at 250' where the tour stopped to learn about the history of the place. Water flows below. Temperature is pretty constant and earthquakes don't affect the place. The Drapery Room looks like pleated drapes, the Snowball Room looks like hundreds of shimmering snowballs in the light and Frozen Niagara looks like a smaller frozen version of its namesake. I saw some small black bats, long legged spiders and a pale centipede like insect. There are cave drawings etched on some walls. Since my visit, I learnt that slaves helped build the place and are buried near the entrance including the first guide, Stephen Bishop. Many died within from TB and the work. The caves are considered one of the largest human haunts in the world. Mummified remains have been found dating back centuries. There's an old Saltpeter mine site used to create gunpowder in the war in 1812. A great place - no wonder it is an UNESCO world heritage site.
So...today we did the domes and dripstones tour $15 (each) which is excellent value for the tour and guide info you get.

We went mid week and all the tours were sold out. All the tours. of course they had only 8 scheduled that day. All the same tour. The $5 tour was open. They said the cave was closed for repair. They also say they have a lack of rangers. Make reservations.

We did the frozen Niagara tour which was very good. Our national park ranger led as around the caves explaining all about the beauty of it all and its history. The tour was for a 1/4 mile and lasted 1 hour and 15 mins, including the bus ride to the entrance. It was well worth the $15 dollars. Wear good shoes as it can get very slippery and wet. The visitor centre is also very good and well worth a look around. Not the best caves we have seen but still worth seeing.

This is a nice, quick introductory tour of the cave. Our Ranger was very knowledgeable, and she'd probably been giving tours for many years. Price was very reasonable at $7.00/person, and tour only gets around 25 people per time slot, so it's not crowded. Great activity to do on a very hot, humid day!

Having read about the cave before we went, we thought we could do a self guide tour of the cave, but this is only available when all the guide tours are full. This rarely happens except on holidays such as 4 July. So be aware that you will need to go on a tour with a ranger guide. As it happens, we actually really enjoyed the tour we did....the Mammoth passage which was just over an hour and cost $7 each. The guide was really interesting and we definitely learnt a whole lot more than we would by reading the boards located in the passages. The walk through the cave was really easy. Flash photography is not allowed so take a good camera with you if you want decent photos. The tour recommended to us was the Historical tour, which was over two hours, costing $14 each. I think you would see a lot more different things if you did this one but if you only want a short, easy experience, then the Mammoth Passage is fine. Remember to bring a coat, whatever tour you do as it is really cold down in the cave. There are also things to see above the ground. Make sure you stop off at the Sloan's Pond and also the Green River Ferry. The latter is fabulous to see even if you do not actually use it. Another good National Park Experience all round.

We have been to Mammoth Caves 3 or 4 times in the last 15 years - it is spectacular and a definite must-see attraction in the Kentucky hills. The cave system is still being mapped, and is fascinating in its history. At $14/adult, the tour is economical. Guides vary in their abilities, but ours was well-informed, historically, and did his best to tell us the full history of the caves. We camped at the park - $20 and no services available, but worth the stay,

We went in the early afternoon on Good Friday during spring break, so it wasn't surprising to find that all guided tours were full. We took the self guided discovery tour which is always available (and much cheaper, at $13.00 for a family of four). It turns out this was probably best because our kids (particularly the six year old) would have had trouble enjoying a longer tour. In this tour, they got to run from spot to spot, hearing the few guides positioned throughout the cave, sharing its history. I had taken the tour as a child and remembered other parts of the cave, so I was a bit disappointed that I wasn't able to see them. However, having happy kids was probably more important to my enjoyment of the cave this time around. The park is gorgeous as well, with tiny streams trickling down the mossy rocks of the ravine. The kids saw another child wearing a gold plastic badge and asked about it at the information booth. The park has a fun program for the kids to complete an age based number of workbook exercises about conservation and cave history to become a Junior Ranger, complete with oath, certificate, and badge. This, my children will always remember, and they learned about conservation from the many exhibits in the visitor center!

Stopped by on our way south. Was the only second attraction we saw while passing through Kentucky. Kids had a amazing experience. The boat ride with the car was fun. Kids learned a lot from the information provided by the guides. Tickets were also quite economical and we ended by doing a combo tour instead.

My wife and I did the Frozen Niagara tour a couple of weeks ago. Was a very interesting experience and the tour guide did a good job. Not a whole lot of steps but there was a lot of walking. Tour was worth the $20, but just driving around the park is free and the park is gorgeous. Especially liked the Green River Ferry.

The tour was pretty good. We went on the New Entrance tour. Prices are reasonable. The group size was about 120 people, and for me it would have been nicer with a very small group. The cave is 54 degrees year-round. Getting down there is not easy if you have physical restrictions. You will have to duck and stairs will be wet. The best part is the knowledgeable rangers. They were fantastic. They can answer any question you have and they do it with enthusiasm.

After reading the descriptions of all the available tours I was disappointed to see that many of them involved 500+ steps so I had limited choice. Although I arrived early they were all booked until the afternoon so I was left with the Mammoth Passage option - what a waste of time! It only cost $5 but was a huge disappointment. The guide was lovely and she gave us a brief history and answered questions. Unfortunately there was virtually nothing to see apart from the remains of a saltpetre mine and 5 Indian artefacts.

Sited just out of town, in wonderful grounds ? 800 acres, this well maintained house is good to visit. The rooms and outhouses are fascinating and the visitors centre well stocked. The shop staff and the guide are helpful. Costs 10 dollars per person.

Of all the Antebellum houses in Natchez Mississippi we chose Melrose. The tour inside the house is only $2 each and we were lucky enough to get Park Ranger Barney as our guide. He is full of knowledge and super friendly and we came away after about 45 min not needing to go to another

Firstly, be prepared for lots of driving, but with rewarding vistas, scenery and views. We entered the park at around 9.00am and left at around 3.30pm - we were prepared with a picnic lunch so we could stop at our own leisure, but there is a large restaurant/cafe about half way round. Although the park was quite busy with cars, we never actually felt we were overcrowded as people were moving on all the time to the next vista/stopping point. Lots of photo opportunities and the Palace was the highlight - my mobility did not allow me to take one of the guided tours, but there are still plenty of places to take some fab photos. The visitor centre is also worth a visit as it is very informative with lots of artifacts. The park entrance is $20 per vehicle and does not include any guided tours.

This is good if you want to see where then Indians lived in this area and nice from that perspective. Also very nice drive through. Now the criticism: They charge $20 to get in something I thought our taxes paid for. Claim to have lots of trails to hike but terrible maps and virtually no markers on the road to find them. Each of the trails to the dwellings is blocked for hikers and they require you to pay again to take a guided tour. Several trails have been closed for years due to deterioration yet they spent tons of money building the palace visitor center. Typical government wasted spending.

This park offers many ways to experience the sites for which it is well known. If you want to visit the cliff dwellings up close, you will need to book a tour to do so. We visited Cliff Palace ($5 per person, 1 hour tour) and our ranger was fantastic.
