Tickets for tours of the cliff dwellings must be bought at the Visitor Center at the entrance of the park or at the Colorado Welcome Center in Cortez. Plan ahead, as the tours are popular and the drive from the Visitor Center to the cliff dwellings can take an hour or more. We got to the VC around 8:30 am and the first Cliff Palace we could book was at 1:00 pm. There were six in our group.

This is if you are into history, lots of information, for me it was not worth it fir $198 per person, almost every one in the boat where asleep on both ride. 2 hours of boat ride each way of nothing except listening to information. I would rather do the Ziplines.

I did this trip by boat going out and by floatplane coming back, the difference in cost between the floatplane only and the boat/plane combination being $140. The boat trip was too long and it got to the point of being monotonous with the same scenery; the floatplane trip back was excellent with great views from the skies. If I had the choice again I would do the floatplane only without the boat trip out.

We did the flight seeing trip to see the misty fjords when we were in Ketchikan. We were on a cruise but didn't book through them. We booked when we got off the boat at the information hut. There were loads of tours on offer there and plenty of companies offering this tour. We went with Taquan Air and it cost $199 each (as opposed to $289 I think off the cruise- Holland America).

We took this trip three days ago. The weather was rainy but not bad. We went out by floatplane with a window seat each which was excellent giving a nice view of the route and scenery. Landed beside a pontoon to transfer quickly to a catamaran. After viewing the fjord we departed sedately and viewed the fjord from water level including a very high cliff face with nesting birds and a few seals at the base Then we were uncomfortable on the bumpy, fast and long return to Ketchikan. Some drinks and coffee and a muffin available to go with the guides chat. The guide did her best to make this long slog back interesting. Probably a unique trip but at the price of $369.95 EACH was in my opinion not nearly worth it. Made a formal representation to our cruise operator (HAL) who obtained a response from the operator that ours was the first complaint, that the boat was less than year old boat and was fitted with HD tv. (it had, but you needed to stand at the rear to watch it). Overall we feel it was an overpriced and disappointing trip. We would recommend float plane both ways which is cheaper at $100 EACH less.
Peace and quiet place. Admission is free. Small parking close by. I liked it a lot. Part of 3 to be visited. Look into brochure.

Had a great day. Entry of $25 for car and family of three. Helpful information at the gate and on 1610AM. The road was closed at Paradise center due to the weather. There were a number of sous for photos, walks and looks along the way.

Shame the rain came the days we visited but the scenery is spectaculat anyway. Good cafes and gift shops which are not too pricey but do remember to add in the entrance cost to the park $20. This is fine if you intend to go more than once or visit more parks in the Washinton area. There is no other way to get in and the drive to the visitor centre is a fair way to both Mt Rainier and Sunrise. My husband loved the twisting roads, but maybe not for the nervous driver. The clouds over the mountain are only to be expected at 6500ft above sea level but there are hikes to suit all abilities. Wrap up well even if it seems warm when you enter the park. We had rain, hail, snow and sun in one afternoon and when we got back to Ashford the sun was blazing and druing up all the rain!

My husband and I hiked up Skyline Trail. It was uphill most of the way but we stopped a lot to catch our breath. We are almost 60 but in fairly good shape! It was about 3 hours up and 2 hours down. There were lots of places to sit along the way. The parking lot was almost full at 10:30 on a Sunday morning. The information centre was quite helpful in letting us know the difficulty and approx time it takes to hike. There are lots of trails that come off of Skyline and the maps and signs are quite good. The views along the way are spectacular. It was quite amazing how dry the creeks were and how much of the glacier had melted after this long hot summer. There is a bathroom near the top and a good place to stop for your picnic lunch. It was a very enjoyable day for us. You need a National Park Pass $20.00

We were passing through South Dakota so didn't have long. These carvings are stunning and worth the hour long window of time that we had and $10 parking. More could be seen had we more time. We were left wondering how on earth they managed such a feat.

Mount Rushmore is one of those places that I never thought I'd actually see in person. And now that I have, I can honestly say that no pictures I ever saw beforehand actually did it justice. There's something about seeing it in person and soaking in the sheer magnitude of the sculpture before your eyes. The park itself costs 10$ to get into/ 5$ for active military or anyone over 62 years old (the price= the cost of parking your vehicle). If you're like me and think that you can probably see if just as well for free from the road, please reconsider. It's totally worth the money. Plus, the 10$ also includes some other cool attractions-giftshops, a cafe, a musuem, and an ampitheater (though I must admit that I don't know what they show there). Anyhow, trust me; you won't regret the stop even if just for the photo-op.
$10 for parking. Free entrance. Amazing to see. Go and watch the film in the downstairs auditorium (a bit old and wobbly, but tells the story really well, and brings everything into context).

Yes, it is a little out of the way, but the scenery around it is beautiful so it's worth the drive. As you approach you get a glimpse of the memorial, it's definitely worth paying the $10 to get in though, especially as you can keep going back all year. There is plenty of parking, cafes and toilets. The visitor centre and everything all looks very modern and the carving itself is mind blowing, such amazing detail. You get a great view as you walk towards it but if you want a slightly different perspective you can take the presidents trail (I think this is what it's called) which kind of loops round underneath it. For another view, when you leave there is a lay by that gives you a side profile of Washington. One of my favourite parts of our trip.

Surprised to find that if you are a Senior the car parking fee is reduced from 11 to 5 dollars - I was expecting to pay the higher figure/ As this is the only "entrance charge", this amazing site, museum and introductory film are excellent value

The site is well organised and offers numerous experiences and opportunities to learn more about this unique and iconic monument. Whist it can be viewed from the road for free the nominal parking charge of $10 ($5 for any passenger who is 62yrs or older) is well worth it as you get the opportunity to learn much more about this monument and its history

Great and impressive place to visit. Doesn't look much until you watch the video in the theatre which shows how long it took and the imagination and skill to create it from a granite mountain. You then realise what an impressive monument it is. Lots to do and see, nature trails to follow, gift shops, cafe to relieve you of your dollars.

This site is a beautiful work of art. Directions to get there by car are well displayed and easy to follow. It costs $10.00 to park but admission to the site is free. The facility offers a great view of the sculpture. There are walking trails for those who want to get up close and personal.

I am so pleased we made the trip to this American icon. I was so impressed that for $10 to park your car ($5 if over 62 or military Vet) you get to experience something so amazing.....wish we had been staying longer in Keystone we would have returned to view again at night....At no extra cost!!!! The walking track was worth the effort to do also.

Stopped here during a long road trip. Nice monument. Being very patriotic, I have wanted top go here for years. It really didnt live up to the hype. 10 minutes is enough. Park charges $10 to park and does not accept the national park pass. What do they do with all the money?
A fantastic site to see, good visitor information center with a short film about the construction of the memorial. Places to eat and sit and look at the view. Plenty of parking at $10 per car.

Plenty of parking, that's for sure. Your national park pass does not cover the $8 parking fee, so that's a mild bummer. Very good exposition hall with the story of how & why it was built, lots of artifacts, photos, good film. Nice walk up to the base of the mountain and around.

The Mt. Rushmore visitors centre is worth every penny of the $10 parking fee, which, incidentally, is valid for a full 12 months. After paying this fee, there are no other charges unless you make a purchase - so different to what I'm used to, coming from the UK. We had no problem parking the full sized dually in the parking lot and then had only a short, level walk to the entrance. Once at the monument entrance there are plenty of washrooms and water bottle re-fill stations. The cafeteria serves decent looking food at a very reasonable price - we bought the ice-cream. The views of this national monument at awesome. We attended mid-week and it was not at all crowded - busy yes but not crowded. Certainly worth the visit. Next time we're in the area I will make the effort to see the monument during the night.

Cost is $10 and good for one year. Easy parking, great gift shop, museums, and cafe. Suggest seeing it both in the day and night at the lighting of the monument. Do walk the Presidential Trail. Start the trail on the left for an easier route with not as many stairs.

It's a long drive from anywhere to get here, but it was worthwhile to take in other local attractions. There is a large parking area, $10 for a vehicle, then you enter the site, via the avenue of state flags before you look across to the famous four faces. There is a large souvenir shop with a large selection of goods including Native American items. The cafe has a reasonable selection of food and drink with average pricing. I saw the 9pm show, which drags on for about 40 minutes describing key events of each President, and gets very patriotic, before the lights are turned brilliantly illuminating the Presidents.

Having seen the heads from the distance as we drove along 16A, we were keen to see them close up. First impression were very favourable - expecting to pay $10 for parking and then a separate entrance fee, we were only charged a total of $ 5 to park (as we had a senior in the party) and that also covered entry for all 5 of us. Walking onto the site is very impressive with a flag lined avenue taking you on the trail below the heads. The trail is relatively short, but includes a visit to the sculptors house that holds the scale model initially built. Lots of informative signs provided detail on both the construction and on the presidents. All of us were very impressed and enjoyed the visit.

When we arrived at the Mt Rushmore Monument we were first confronted by a huge walk way leading to the monument "The Avenue of Flags". And then as you walk along the path you can see the faces before you. A truly magnificent sight. We were floored by the details and likness of the sculptures. The whole area is very well set up from the viewing platform to the information centre. There is a walking trail which leads down and around the bottom of the monument. It leads around to the sculptor's studio where there is a mini version of the monument from which the measurments were made and then back to the viewing platform.. A truly fantastic monument and an awesome sight. This is a "Must See " experience. We had a lump in our throat and we are Aussies. The parking was only $5.

We are on vacation in the states and stopped in Rapid City for 3 nights. We went to Mount Rushmore for a few hours. Its easy to find, good parking only 10 dollars to park and get in. The place is in pristine condition clean and well maintain. The rock is pretty and nice. Well made. The presentation at night could be done better.. I think this is a must if you are inSouth Dakota... Its worth the 10$

This has been on my bucket list since seeing the movie, North by North West many years ago. Glad we made the effort to go there. Cost to get into the car Park is $10 this is valid for a year so you can go as often as you like while you are there. Entry in to visit the monument is free. It is a remarkable sculpture and has to be admired not just for it's beauty but the many hours of dedication and skill to create it.

Mount Rushmore has always been on my bucket list and I was not disappointed! $10 to park the car but the monument is free to visit. There is also a museum/exhibition theatre that is also worth visiting explaining how the mountain was created, worth watching and again all free! A wonderful huge gift shop too! It is an absolute must!!
Stopped in while driving from Deadwood to Hot Springs. 10 dollars to park, which would be ok if you planned on spending more time there. It was pretty impressive to see!

The carving is amazing . The work that it took to accomplish this is very humbling . The statues are beautiful to see. The flags that line the walk to the viewing represent the 50 states , and at the base of the flag pole is the date on which the state joined the Union . The statues are pretty awesome , but the entire site is a little anticlimactic . Maybe because we see so many photos of the mountain . The grounds are impeccably clean , there are gift shops , and a snack place if you are interested . The gift shop has a good variety of items and prices . This was a beautiful spot, but it seems it is one of those places that you need not repeat once you have seen it . Parking is $ 11 but the parking is close to the Memorial , and in a structure . We are glad we stopped to see this icon of America .

Simply cannot be in South Dakota and not visit Mount Rushmore. It is impressive on TV, but even more impressive close up. The story behind the Monument is well worth hearing too. For some strange reason, car parking was $11 - an odd amount

I always thought this was goingvto be much better, too much hipe and not worth the drivevoutvof the way.Also if you must go make sure to use the pull over before parking lot to get your picture not wothbthe $11.00 to park to get picture. Truly a tourist trap at the max.

Another place/site we have crossed off our bucket list. $11 parking fee, $5.50 for an ice cream (2 scoops) amazing and beautiful drive into/out of the area and the sight of the presidents is amazing. The day was overcast so we were advised to head there between 1pm and 5pm - good advice! We stayed in Custer which is close to the main attractions in the area, went for a drive to rapid city, glad we didn't stay there, just a big town. Custer, whilst small, has a quaintness and more atmosphere.

Beautiful and well organised site with multiple entrance booths and ample parking with good access and spacing. The $11 fee covers parking and entry - per car, so compared with many other sites is really good value. The site and trail is impressive, and the story and photos of the building process fascinating. Huge gift shop with lots to look at, and a large cafeteria containing photos and models, as well as a reasonable range of food and snacks. Very well designed facilities, and the very worthwhile trail affords a number of different views of the presidents.

A place to visit atleast once if you are in the area , does not take too long, lots of info inside to look at and learn. Yes $11 for parking but it does go to a cause. Restaurant is a good place to eat, they have outside eating and you can enjoy the view.

This has been on my bucket list for some time now and finally getting to see it was amazing. It's $11 to park for a car then everything else is free (much better value than $22 they tried to charge us for Crazy Horse!).
Free of charge to enter, but with a parking fee of $11.
We came to the monument in the late afternoon. There are lot of parking lots and you get an annual parking pass for $11. There is no single day parking pass.

I had seen enough pictures of Rushmore to wonder I would go see it in person but it really is a fabulous monument to behold. The park is set up really well to display the history of the site, as well as the site itself. That, and it was only $11(one carload) for the family to get in. Nice ice cream shop too!

Not being American, we don't have a strong draw to the significance, but it was neat to see and say we have been here. It was extremely hot mid afternoon without much shade so I would recommend going early in the day during summer. The admission is "free", but parking was $11.

this place is far from things so when you drive out, you pass small little towns with souvenir shops. don't stop, keep driving. there is an $11 parking fee but no entrance fee. it is interesting and has a lot of history. there is an air conditioned theatre that shows a video about the history of mount rushmore. if you are interested in american history and presidents, this is a must stop place to see. we enjoyed walking around and learning more about american history. there is an exhibit that is nice as well. the gift shop is huge. they have a cafe that you can buy food at as well. the junior ranger booklet is free and my son liked doing the activities.
We got there early so were able to park for free in the car park. Not that much to see apart from the heads which as others have said may be seen from the road without having to pay the $11 to park.

Mt. Rushmore has been on my Bucket List of things to do for many years. What can you say about a national treasure? It's beautiful and can be seen from outside the complex, which is a great thing for folks on a limited budget. Admission is free, parking is $11. Well worth the price. It was all I expected.

An amazing site to see! It's strange to be there in person, a Great historical site and feeling!! Entrance is free you only have to pay $11 for parking! Also visit the crazy horse memorial it's Also Great to see!! It's a 20 minute drive from mount rushmore
Didn't get here until late morning, place was very busy but still plenty of parking available and not a big wait at the vehicle entrance. $11 for the car load was great value.

This was another stop on our cross country adventure. Stopped here on recomendation from my sister in law. What a place. Ive seen it in pictures and movies but nothing does it justice until you see it in person. It's grand and beautiful all in the same breath. If your driving in that area or traveling, try and fit this in to your schedule. The site is free to go to but you have to pay for parking. It's $11 but when you get your ticket it's good for the whole season. You can't give the ticket away to someone else ether because it has the make of your car, colour and where your from on the pass. Of course there is a grift shop on site and it's super busy. Lots of tour buses on site. Get there early if you want to beat the crowds. Overall it's a great spot to visit. Your not here for a long time. An hour or so unless you want to hike up the mountain is all you'll need.

Well organised, clean plus easy and plentiful parking and only $11. The viewpoint is well maintained and plenty of room for everyone to see and take photos. The Presidential Walk was a great experience as you actually walked on the mountain below the iconic faces.

We were very impressed with the Mount Rushmore National Memorial. We went to the lighting ceremony on the first evening we arrived in Keystone, SD. The next morning we went back up to Mt. Rushmore to visit the museum, eat in the cafe, shop at the gift store and view the memorial again. The infrastructure in amazing and the whole site is well organized and presented. It is well worth the visit. We paid $11 to park at the memorial and this allowed us in the next day as well. There is ample parking space for visitors and stairs/elevators to access the memorial area.

what an amazing experience coming face to face with this landmark. Entry is free but car parking was around 11 dollars which for a family of 4 is a bargain. Excellent visitor center and fascinating video of how it came about and was achieved. Just standing admiring this mind blowing sculpture made a long trip seem more than worth it.

This has been on my bucket-list for too long - but no longer. When you have wanted to see something for a long time, there is a danger that you will be disappointed - not on this occasion. $11 dollars per car to park in an underground facility a few moments walk from the site and that is it - Gob-smacked. Better than I hoped and worth the wait. This is in my top ten of world monuments and you need to see it.

Visiting the Badland it is a short drive to the Mount Rushmore National Memorial at Keystone in the Black Hills. The sculpture of 4 famous presidents of the USA Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt and Lincoln has been manufactured in the period 1927-1941 by Gutzon Borglum till his death. The result can only be really enjoyed by visiting the Memorial. National Park Services do an excellent job to expose it all (incl. a museum) for only $11/car. Must see.

This was one of our "must see" spots on our trip to North and South Dakota and it did not disappoint. There is no entrance fee, but there is an $11 parking charge for cars. (Tour busses pay $50.) The visitor center is reached from a walkway highlighting states' flags. At the walkway's end, there is a viewing platform for Mt. Rushmore. The visitors center is underneath and accessible via steps or elevator. A short film is regularly shown in the visitor center and you are also able to take a short loop hike that takes you closer to the carvings. It is paved, but there are numerous steps. This loop takes you to the carving studio which contains additional information about the creation of the monument and excellent historic artifacts. An artists rendering of the monument is here, and the final product was not exactly like the plan. An audio tour is available for an additional fee. We did not rent it and felt fully informed without it. The light is perfect in the morning for photographs in summer. As the sun is behind. If you take the trail, you can get closer pictures of each president.

Since I was little I always wanted to come here. It took a long drive to accomplish but I think it is well worth it. The site was not too crowded when we were there and I think that is a good thing. They get you on the parking at $11, although, it was a private firm running the concessions. We spent a couple of hours there and got back on the road, yee haw!

You feel like you know this place already but it is so worth a visit. Beautiful setting, well laid out with plenty of rest rooms and refreshment options. All paths accessible and lots of interesting exhibits other than the rock face itself. Spent an easy half day mooching around. They do an evening lighting up session which we missed but I'm guessing it would be spectacular. Parking is $11 (valid for 7 days)- head for a higher parking level. The monument is on level 6 so if you get parked there you avoid the stairs.

We arrived early in the morning and found the monument shrouded in fog. We learned from some helpful folks in a coffee shop in Keystone that morning fog often lifts by noon so we waited. By 11 am, the monument was clearly visible so we drove back up the hill to see it. The monument itself is spectacular and the accompanying facilities and displays are very well done. Rangers were very knowledgeable and friendly. We were even offered free use of a wheelchair for one of our party who was limping. Unfortunately, we were there before the nightly light shows started for the season (on the Memorial Day weekend). Admission is free but there is an $11 charge for parking - the parking pass is valid for a year but only for a particular car/license plate so effectively (unless you are a local) really is a one-time parking fee. This place is well worth visiting, even for non-Americans.

I have wanted to visit here for many years and at last made it. A first thought when planning the trip was 'Oh it has gone commercial' based on the parking concession fee of $11. I was wrong. This is a major advantage, at no cost to the park, in allowing large numbers of visitors to come to Mt Rushmore in a convenient way. The parking was very efficient and your $11 fee covers as many visits in a calendar year than you can manage. I used it for three separate visits over a 4 day period. The public areas are scaled to meet the expected visitor numbers so did not seem overly crowded and a walk around the Presidents Trail thins things out further. I would recommend this for novel views of the presidents. The exhibits create a sense of the undertaking to sculpt the heads and the evening illumination ceremony was worth coming in for. I notice a comment about it being cool in the evening, yes that's true so bring a sweater or a jacket and don't miss Mt Rushmore illuminated. All in all it is worth making a detour on any trip in this area to see this national memorial.

The National Parks yet again have done an outstanding job in displaying this memorial and the story behind it. However it is probably better appreciated once you have been to the Crazy Horse Memorial to see it under construction, also to understand the different scale of the two monuments. This is a beautiful site and well worth spending time walking around. However for those who have a National Park Annual Pass please note you still have to pay for parking!

All totally organised these days with multi-storey car-parks, although friends visited forty years ago when it was park on dirt and walk up through similar.. Entry is free, parking costs $11 for a car. Plenty of opportunities to spend more money.
Pay 11 dollars to park, this ticket lasts a week. Free entry to the monuments. Wow, up close and personal with the statues, there is a walk around the base, not too taxing.

As a rule, I don't read other people's review's before typing mine but this time I couldn't help but look at the ones that people had only given this marvel one star. People complaining about paying $11 to park their car, unavailable!!

My partner and I stopped here during an around America road trip and were glad we did. The drive up is beautiful! Only $11 or so per car for entry (which gives that car re-entry allowance for a year). Very small walk from the carpark to the viewing platform, lots of photo opportunities, can stay as long as you want to explore the grounds. Amazing to see in real life!

although a little smaller than the movies portray it is a very impressive sight, amazing how they managed to achieve this without modern technology. fantastic value for money I think the parking was $11 which is valid for a year. and there is no charge to view the monument from a well placed viewing platform. there is a nice food court serving lots of snacks meals and drinks. there is also a good gift shop although the prices were a little steep for me,
We had a stop over in Rapid City and figured we would take in the famous Mt. Rushmore. It was a really fun afternoon. It only cost $11.00 for the whole family as well.

I stopped by Mount Rushmore while driving from Washington, DC to San Francisco in August 2015. I've always wanted to visit there ever since I was a kid, so this was a dream finally come true! Mount Rushmore is beautiful. I was almost star struck seeing the presidents carved onto the giant rocks. Touring through the museum underground and learning the history behind this massive structure, you really are awe struck by how they were able to pull such an amazing feat off! Parking cost $15 all day. Admission is free since it is a national monument. Fairly close to area hotels in Keystone (about 15-20 min drive away). There are several other national monuments/parks/caves nearby, but this takes the cake for sure! I highly highly recommend if you live in this country, you visit this place at least once before you pass onto the next world. You will not regret it! A++++

We made sure to stop by the historical monument - for $7 (and you can use that ticket as many times as you want in 1yr) to get in, worth it. Pictures don't do it justice, it is an amazing piece of history! The ride up builds up your anticipation and when you set your eyes on it its very exciting! When we were there their was one of the men that help build the monument signing his book. Gift shop was great, clean bathrooms etc. It was hard to leave and take our eyes off the monument
A truly national monument, stunning, awesome and beautifully presented. The entrance fee is only $11 per car which entitles you to unlimited visits - an excellent bargain family day out.

It is a national monument and an international attraction. We were there in the fall and it was a cold day but it was a great attraction anyway but the souvenirs and the food was expensive, as you would expect, parking was $11 U.S. dollars.

This place was so worth the visit. What an amazing place, amazing views, amazing area, amazing trail. It was very interesting and a top highlight of our 3 week vacation int he area. $20 for a year pass is so worth it. Don't waste your money on Crazy Horse...come here instead.

You can see Mt. Rushmore as you drive toward it on Hwy 16. There are couple of places to stop to get good pictures on the hwy. When you pull up the entrance to the park there are kiosks where you pay the parking fee ($11.00 for cars). Cars are parked in a multilevel garage. I have a crew cab long box pick up and had no issues with clearance or finding a space large enough. Stay to the right of you have an rv or motorcoach. There is no fee other than parking.
You must stop in to see this magnificent site. We paid $11.00 per vehicle to get in and there is ample multilevel, parkade style, parking. Very easy to find and only a short drive from Rapid City.

Just stunning!! Great that you can walk around it and get different angles and aspects from the presidents trail. Your 11 dollar entry fee is valid for a whole year so you can visit as much as you like :)

You cannot visit this area and not visit here, we did not take any of the trails going up closer to the monument, we arrived after 6 and wandered around the information centre and then settled ourselves for the lighting ceremony in the amphitheatre.when the sun went down, there was a film, which told of its history and how and why it was created. Then they lit the monument and sang the national anthem. Then they invite all veterans to come down as they take down the flag for the evening. Very moving and very patriotic. A great time and all for the cost of parking the car at $11.

Having seen lots of pictures of Mount Rushmore, we were excited to be finally visiting it, however we were a little disappointed when we finally saw it in the flesh. I thought the $11 parking fee was a bit of a rip off and the monument itself looks much more impressive from a distance than it does when you're actually there. I would actually go as far to say that the as yet unfinished Crazy Horse memorial is slightly more impressive than Mount Rushmore. Glad to have seen it but would not be in a rush to see it again.

It really is one of those iconic US locations that you see in the movies and it really is quite surreal to be there in person. The memorial itself is free but you pay for parking. The ticket is valid for a year, which I'll not get to use again but it's only $11 at the end of the day.

It was our third visit over several years, it still irritates me that you have to pay eleven dollars to park, the attendant says "you can visit as many times as you like until" whenever. It used to be twelve months, these days it is three ! How likely is it that my rental car will be the same one I have next time ( they print your registration number on the ticket). The Presidential pathway is a nice little walk. Remember the place is a mile above sea level, so you will pant a bit. The sculptures are outstanding and the ranger talks very good. An absolute must place to visit.

We were very impressed with he Mount Rushmore National Memorial. WE first visited it during the day and spent about 1/2 day there. We could have spent longer but the grandchildren were tired. Exhibits, videos and museum were great. Park personnel with also very helpful. We went back the next night for the evening show which included historical information, another video and the nighttime lighting of the memorial. It was enjoyable even though it was a second visit. They invited all military and first responders down on stage (it was 9/11) and we were honored. Well worth the time to visit Memorial visit is free, the parking is $11 but parking is good for a week, so it covers return visits.

I have always wanted to see Mount Rushmore and I wasn't disappointed, it was amazing. We drove 5 hours to get there and we stopped at Crazy horse first, which we enjoyed but it wasn't a patch on Mount Rushmore. It costs $11 to park in their car park, this ticket is good for a whole year. There were cars parked along the road way and people were walking in but it really isn't worth it.

It is had to imagine how someone could envision a project of this magnitude and see it to full realization. It is very difficult to put into words how we felt to view such a wonder. we visited the gift shop, viewed the movie and toured the museum. The walk down the avenue of flags was impressive. We returned in the evening for the lighting ceremony. I'm not American, but I thought it was very rude that people would leave before the flag was lowered and the military that were invited to the stage were honoured for their services. There is plenty of parking, the entrance to the monument is free, parking is $11.00, but you only pay it once, the evening is included in the original fee. A definite must see.

for $11.00 we got a pass that is good until years end.very nice to see.if you want to see other parts of mt rushmore ie visitors center sculptors studio it is a lot of walking up and down stairs.very nice though although personally i liked crazy horse memorial better

There were a lot of things to see and do. The light show, the walks and the history. As an American I was impressed by the work that went into creating this attraction. I was disappointed by the fact that it costs $11.00 to park at this attraction.

My wife and I enjoyed our Mount Rushmore visit. It's a marvellous sight. The viewing area is grand. This is THE one thing you have to do in the Black Hills. After that enjoy the surrounding beauty and choose to spend your tourism dollars as you please. I do wonder why they don't blow off fireworks every weekend or every night? I'm sure the crowds would flock back nightly to check this out.

The park is tastefully designed with lots of parking and locations to take pictures during your visit. The Presidential Trail is a must for the photo buff but there is a lot of stairs on the way out. The Sun rises on face of Mount Rushmore, to avoid shadowing arrive early. The attraction is free but there is a $11.00 parking fee.

Really interesting monument to visit, the scale is very impressive and walking around the presidential trail you get to learn how it was done. Tip for the walk along the presidential trail...as you look at the presidents faces take the left hand trail, there are far less steps up going this way, it is a far easier walk. Also our National Parks annual pass did not get us in here you have to pay eleven dollars to park. They also do a light show on the faces each night at 8pm, worth considering for your visit.

We recently were in the area and made it a priority to visit Mount Rushmore. We got there as the rush began in the early morning, but the staff quickly directed us to the parking area which has a charge of $11 for the entire day. The actual monument is free to the public. You can also obtain an audio tour for $5 to enhance the visit although I found that the descriptive panels that accompanied most of the interpretive center displays were sufficient.

There's a parking garage that charges $11 for parking. That's basically the entrance fee. From there, you walk up the the viewing areas. There's a food court with indoor and outdoor eating. There's also a book store that offers plenty of souvenirs, food items, art, etc.

The beauty of America can be enjoyed all the way to the Monument. If you haven't found time to enjoy the country you live in, you don't know what you are missing. Mt. Rushmore is just one more example of what there is here to see. At just $11 for the whole family to park there is lots to see. There is a small free parking lot just down the road but I wouldn't walk it if you are traveling with children because it is a winding road and people are busy looking at the surrounding forests and stone formations.

We were actually thinking of bypassing going into the memorial area but were glad we decided to stop in. The memorial viewing is free but parking is $11.00. My husband and I arrived early in the morning in order to avoid a lot of people which worked out great. The staff at the gift shop were fantastic and the prices reasonable.
So fun! $11/car makes a fun, historical family event. :) The kids loved getting up close to the faces!

Mount Rushmore is an unbelievable monument. Charge is per vehicle and was reasonable. Lots to see once on site. Museum, short film on creating Mount Rushmore. Good viewing area. Walking trail under the monument gets you even closer for that perfect picture.

This Memorial was one part of our road trip we were really looking forward to as back home on PBS America there has been an excellent programme about the history of the MR project. We stayed at one of the local RV campsites and took advantage of their shuttle bus to the evening closing ceremony and at dusk the illumination of the sculptures, at a reasonable cost of 6 dollars per person. We got there in plenty of time but were surprised how small the actual sculpture was. There was a large crowd waiting for the ceremony to start but the lead up to dusk was disappointing. Music and a gentleman who spoke at length about the importance of the memorial in U.S. history. It became obvious that there was a problem as no illumination of the sculpture took place and eventually we were told that there was a malfunction with the power supply. There were clearly thunderstorms in the area but surely that was insufficient to interrupt the occasion? Finally we were told that the presentation had been abandoned so everybody started to leave. As we headed for our bus, suddenly the lights came on and everybody rushed back to view the scene. Unfortunately, the illumination was poor and the sculpture barely visible. We were bitterly disappointed as we had travelled thousands of miles to see this icon of the USA and were moving on the next morning on the next stage of our road trip. Very fortunately, the next morning our visit to the Crazy Horse Memorial took our breath away and made up for the previous evening's sad experience!

Very picturesque drive from Rapid City. $11.00 parking fee seemed a bit steep but worth it because other wise the walk would be prohibitive. Seeing the Memorial in person made it all worthwhile. Would definitely recommend.

now i have been seeing this monument since i was a wee one, and when i finally got to see it in person, i was awestruck, it wasn't the faces it was all the sculpting and time it took to do this, the creativity is on a scale that nobody has time for anymore, and it was cheap too, for an annual pass it $11usd...that's crazy, the site has all the fixins for a day stay...food...souvenirs...phto ops...hiking trail...one can never take a bad photo there, it's designed that way, of course you will be going there if you are in south dakota...it's a no brainer!

This is one of the places everyone has to visit on a trip to the USA. It is a truly iconic American memorial which every American has to visit in their lifetime. It is impressive to see the rock carving close up and for real, but it is a busy place and the parking charges are ridiculous ($11.50). There is a large viewing platform and it is possible to take a short hike around the area and get a bit closer to the mountain. There is also a museum showing the history of the monument. Try to visit the Crazy Horse monument afterwards as this will give you a different insight into the Mount Rushmore carvings.

I've always wanted to go see this memorial after seeing it in films, and I was not disappointed! It costs $11 per vehicle to park by the monument which is well worth it. You can walk through the museum, watch documentaries, walk up to the foot of the mountain, and listen to experts talk about the monument itself.

Well as an Englisman I really wanted to pay this place a visit and see what all the fuss was about, defiantly glad I did and I was surprised by the cheap $11 entrance fee. View is stunning, very clean but a little pricey once you are inside.overall though a very good experience. Don't forget to pay Deadwood a visit.

The pictures we've all seen in textbooks and on television do not do the monument justice. The entry fee was $11 for our vehicle, so not bad at all. We parked in a parking deck that had plenty of spaces available and took an elevator to the entry point. It could not have been simpler to get to the actual monument. As you walk in there are the from all fifty states (and territories) and then the mountain itself. There was not a bad view, despite the crowds of people. There is a museum and bookstore and gift shop on site, as well as an ice cream shop. Thoroughly enjoyed our time there.

Mount Rushmore, an iconic and impressive National Monument. They have a large parking structure very close to the main entrance. While there is no entrance fee, you pay for parking ($11), but your pass is good for the rest of the year -which makes it easy to go back one evening when the sculpture is illuminated. As you enter, you walk along the Avenue of Flags, which includes plaques telling what year each state joined the union. I highly recommend walking the Presidential Trail (422 stairs) which gets you ~right under the monument and gives some great photo ops, as well as trekking out to the Sculptor's Studio (where we were fortunate to catch a ranger presentation that explained more about how the mountain was carved). The Evening Lighting Ceremony (45-60 min long, only in the summer) is described as "an inspirational program focusing on the presidents, patriotism and our nation’s history" and included a viewing of the film "Freedom: America’s Lasting Legacy".

I thought there was more to the memorial than just the sculpture. It is grand and amazing but after an hour we were ready to leave. Not much to do but the museum. The trail was partially closed. The $11 fee is good for 1 year.

The drive up here is awesome. Such a nice scenic drive, especially if you are coming up on a sunny day. The cost of entry per standard vehicle is $11 which allows you re-entry in the same vehicle for the remainder of the year.

Held back by snow in Rapid City for a few days we were worried we wouldn't be able to get to Mount Rushmore. They were still clearing part of the car parking areas after the storm. The first sight of this monument is immense and not being American hadn't realised how moved I would feel when I saw it. Some of the walkways were still closed but the view from the terrace was breathtaking. Pay for parking.

As a non-American, I found this a great tribute to the founding fathers of America. However I feel that The Memorial is spoiled by the tackiness of the nearby Keystone "town" and that many of the items in the gift shop are not made in America. Also the charge of $11 to park is extortionate for the short time it takes to view the carvings and an entry fee would be better.

I am not prone to using superlatives but my words cannot describe accurately the impact visually of this memorial and the reasoning behind its creation. It has to be seen to be believed. The National Park people do a wonderful job in maintaining the area to an extremely high standard, and I am shocked that I have seen complaints about the car parking charge. Eleven dollars is a very small price to pay for this experience. I speak as a UK resident on holiday in the USA.

This is an amazing site and should not be missed. There have been comments about the parking charges ($11) but these are for a whole year! You don't have to pay if you go at night to watch the light up either. Very interesting and to me the highlight of the trip
Only the parking you have to pay(11dollar)the monument is free

a must see amazing workmanship South Dakota's Black Hills provide the backdrop for Mount Rushmore, the world's greatest mountain carving. These 60-foot high faces, 500 feet up, look out over a setting of pine, spruce, birch, and aspen in the clear western air Sculptor Gutzon Borglum began drilling into the 5,725-foot mountain in 1927. Creation of the Shrine of Democracy took 14 years and cost a mere $1 million, though it's now deemed priceless
Very beautiful scenery all around. Well worth the $11.00 admission{per car}. It has a souvenir stand with very reasonable prices. Steep walk up stairs but worth the effort. Great place for all ages.

As a tourist from NZ I thoroughly enjoyed this National Monument as much as my US born husband. Amazing! We went on a cold afternoon in November, so there weren't too many people around. Viewing the sculptures was absolutely awesome! The planning, time, money and effort that went into them all was incredible and was interesting to learn about in the visitors centre. There were a few small gift shops and one massive one. We enjoyed checking out all the state flags that you walk beneath to get to the viewing platform too. $11 (parking) was a small price to pay to see and learn about this amazing work of art!

We have been travelling the states fir 3 months and we took a huge detour to see mount rushmore. I can safely say that it wasn't worth the trouble. After being ripped off by the crazy horse memorial, we were in no mood to pay the $10 parking fee to view the monument. Instead we parked up on the road and viewed it from there. It is so much smaller than I expected and not as impressive as I thought it would be. To top it all off the surrounding town is nothing to look at and there's literally nothing else to do besides see mount rushmore. I shan't be encouraging others to waste their time here.

The reason for our visit to the Black Hills, one of those bucket list visits for anyone, $11 to park your car and away you go, as you would expect for the number of visitors the site gets each year there is more than just the monument to see, 2 different films, a museum! Restaurant and large gift shop

This monument is not worth driving forty minutes for! Don't waste your time. Such a lame sculpture and it's commemorating presidents who are no longer relevant. It would have been SO much nicer if they had just left the absolutely gorgeous natural mountains untouched. Wish I could get my hands on old Borgie. Also, it costs a bloody $15 just to park your car! At least it's not as ridiculous as "Crazy Horse". The only way this is a monument, is if it is a memorial to all the beautiful places that have been destroyed to make way for markers signifying long dead rich white dudes.

A must see by anyone that appreciate the artistic talent and fortitude that it took to create such a wonderful monument. To see it for the first time is breathtaking and to marvel at the skill of the craftsmen is overwhelming. It was something I have always wanted to see and it exceeded my expectations. The park is free but the parking is $17 per car.

The drive up to Mount Rushmore is a great experience in itself so when you arrive you are excited to get there. We paid $11 to take a motorhome in but this is an Annual Pass so if you go back for the night lighting or the faces in the sunrise, you are covered

I'm not American, and I'll freely admit I occasionally think that the whole US patriotism thing goes a bit far. but, in Mt Rushmore there is no doubt that they have an amazing symbol of Nationhood. Although it's easily seen from all over the local area, we paid to go inside and really enjoyed the experience ($15) for a car load of 4 people (for a year) was worth it.

I'm normally a huge fan of National Parks Service sites, but this one was mediocre at best. The faces seemed somehow smaller than I'd expected, and the view was ok but not outstanding. The site felt very commercial - not at all in keeping with the sombre concept of a memorial - not helped by a private concession operating the actually not unreasonable parking ($11 pass good for a full calendar year - so better value in Jan than Sept!), and the myriad of gift shops dotted around the site. Rushmore was one of those 'must do' things in the USA and for that reason it was worth it - but I wont be rushing back.

As a Canadian we definitely learned a lot. A great deal. $11 for a year pass. Make sure to go back at night and watch the lighting ceremony. A lot I didn't know about the 4 presidents. We bought the guided voice tour and it was well worth it.

This was my fourth trip to Mount Rushmore. With my wife's permission, of course, I go away with a buddy each year for two weeks of photography. My buddy had never been before and I figured at 72 it may be my last time here as well. The thing that gets me is it is part of the National Park Service but they don't take the yearly pass here. They get around this by saying the $11.00 fee is for parking while the Memorial is free. Nice move NPS.

You don't have to be from the US to appreciate this amazing feat of artistry and engineering. Very well presented, enjoyed the many fine viewing areas, the film, the museum information, and getting to know more about the other fine works by Borglum. I also enjoyed refreshing my memory on some American history, and learning about the men behind the idea, the men who laboured to make it happen, and details of how the goal was actually accomplished. Parking is $11, and entrance is free, well priced I felt. The heads are visible from afar as you drive nearer, and also from a viewing scope when we were taking a drive thru Custer Park.
The evening lighting program is great, definitely worth returning for. The park is free except for the $11 parking, which is good for a whole year. Super value!

This is a breathtaking creation. We drove 5 hours from Denver to see this man-made sculptors of 4 US presidents. We arrive late in the afternoon and the park is still filled with tourist. We have the National Park Annual pass but we have to pay $11 for the parking. If you are not hiking (I don't see the point of doing this) to get closer to the monument, all you need is about a couple of hours to take pictures, read all literature in the museum, or watch the movie how this park evolved.

The general area had grown since my last visit with restaurants and small shops. The monument is free to visit, but there is an $11 charge for parking. We visited 7-5-14 and there was a very large crowd; perhaps due to the holiday. One of the original "hole drillers" was autographing his book in the gift shop so we purchased his story.
Beautiful, bigger than life, definitely a must see! An observation deck for pictures! They were selling "souvenir T-shirts/bags/hats for $5.00

Been trying to visit Mount Rushmore for years, but being at the back if beyond it rakes some panning. But, trust me, it is worth it. One only pays for irking which is $11. Try to get there early to avoid the crowds. If you are staying in the area, try keystone which is nearby and 40 mins from the airport. Allow about 90 minutes. Coupe of exhibit rooms plus the viewing area. Very disabled friendly. Free wheelchairs available. Combine with visit to crazy horse, which you can see a side view from the roadside and the fantastic needles highway.

There are several areas where the Monument can be viewed form the road. On the Iron Mountain Road as you exit one of the tunnels the faces can clearly be seen from a distance but there are nearer spots to see and take photos. There is a visitors centre but parking is $11 even with a National Park Pass which we thought was rather high just to visit the museum and of course the expected gift shop. We viewed form road and have to say it is awesome especially taking into account when it was "carved". The area around Mount Rushmore, Custer State Park is so worth a visit with two very scenic roads.

As a Canadian, this doesn't have the same emotional impact for me as it does for Americans, but I always find something new to appreciate. Admission of $12/car is for the season so even though you may only be visiting for the time you're in the area, make use of the pass to view during the day and then the evening lighting show.

If you are anywhere near you must go. The set-up is amazing and the trail to the base is a highlight. This should be on everyone's bucket list. There is a parking fee but $11 is very cheap as far as attractions go in the Black Hills.

Although not from the US, we still found this an excellent attraction with a superb associated museum plus shops, food outlets & a small theatre that showed the history behind the monument, played on a loop every 20 minutes or so. The only cost are the parking fees, which I believe were only about $11. A must see for every US citizen.

The $11 parking charge is valid for the remainder of the year . We arrived just after 5pm and the sun wasn't in a great position for basic camera work . We did take a few pictures but knew we would return the following day . After dinner we went back up to see the sculpture lit up . We just missed the show , but still had a great time . After breakfast the next day we went up a final time and walked the Presidents trail and took our time to see everything .
We enjoyed our trip to Mount Rushmore very much. I is a good deal only costing $11 for a car full. We liked looking through the visitor center and of course the mountain. Staff was very friendly.

We're doing a road trip and my Mum had always wanted to see Mount Rushmore. As part of the trip we paid for a park pass at $80 only to find they charge $11 for parking. This is a rip-off way of getting round giving people entrance with the parks pass and I think it's disgusting. Basically you're paying $11 for an old video about the project and carving. It's ok nothing special. Obviously the views of the heads are spectacular but you can see them for miles around.

We were passing close by and thought , "we've got the National Park Annual pass , so why not again" ? Wrong , different body but the entry of $12USD ? is a little price to pay to view these magnificent sculptures again !! Well worth it every time. Just a quick stop this time but still got to the exhibits downstairs (freezing outside !!) and some great photos as well. My favourite President is now Teddy R as he did so much to protect the Nature of America for future Generations & Visitors like us , look up what parks/reserves etc he either created or declared !! A great man in many senses. Highly recommended to all to visit !!

I have always been excited to visit Mt Rushmore since I have been a small child. I was in the process of travelling across the country and we actually went approx 300 miles out of our way to plan our route around visiting Mt Rushmore. Once we arrived I was fairly disappointed. In several pics on the internet it looks huge; However, when we got there it was not big at all, and I was fairly disappointed. We arrived in the winter so many things were not open such as the theater but we still had to pay $11 for parking. It is still pretty cool to see, I can check it off of my bucket list now, but I would not recommend going out of your way to travel there just to see it as we did. If you happen to be passing through do it (even if its 20-30 mins off the road), otherwise... you are not missing much
This is prime example of your tax dollars at work. The money spent on the mountain was well spent, but the rest of the concrete (buildings, parking lots, auditorium, restaurants etc is money wasted.

The minute you get close to this man made wonder you get goose bumps just seeing it's size. Everything is well laid out and organized right from the $11.00 yearly parking pass to the people that work there and are very helpful. there are park rangers walking everywhere to assist or tell you you can't do this or that. Parking is great and it is wheel chair friendly. Lots of washrooms and gift and food vendors. this should be on every ones bucket list and a must do when in South Dakota. The road is easily traveled to get there and if you want to do something more senic and adventurous take Old Iron Mountain Road back but beware you can not take a trailer or motorhome because the road has small tunnels and does a switch back affect to go through the vast forest. You will also see Buffalo and other wildlife. The park is not Pet friendly and they will not let them come out of your vehicle so leave them out of this trip. Mount Rushmore is definetly a must see.Very good visit.

It's hard not to be impressed by the carvings of the presidents at Mount Rushmore. The Memorial is well designed with visitors centre, gift shop, and dining room. The promenade is beautifully laid out with granite walkway and flags, an excellent viewpoint, and then an interesting walk that goes through the woods and closer to the mountain for interesting photo ops. There is an excellent small museum with a good film and a chance to see the sculptor's studio. The fee is $11 for parking but that is actually an annual pass so you can go back to see the night show or visit a second time. We were in an RV and there is space for parking as well as an area to exercise dogs (they are not allowed onsite)

We loved it! At dusk, there's a film in the open air describing the achievements of the four Presidents. Then the sculpture is floodlit. During the day, one can walk almost upto it and there are various walks and other things to see and do in the grounds. Tickets are reasonably priced and are valid for a year.

Always wanted to visit. Had seen recent documentary on PBS on its construction. No disappointments here. Others have complained about the parking fee $11. There is no entry fee for the monument which more than compensates. The walk around is a bit tough in the second half - suggest turning back half-way if you are not good on steps/stairs. The evening show is excellent. Host from National Park Service was great. Short movie on the Presidents and history including First Nations. Altogether a very emotional evening culminating in the National Anthem and lowering the Flag. Armed Forces Veterans invited on stage for the finale. Recommended for all Americans. And Canadians!

Mt Rushmore is one of these places that everybody has seen pictures of, but until you go there you can’t tell the scale of it, hence are potentially up for a disappointment. But luckily there is no disappointment with this national monument. The entrance fee is very reasonable ($11 for a car and occupants), parking is good, and the walk up to the main viewing area is nicely done.

I appreciate that Mt. Rushmore is more important to US citizens than tourists but charging $11 to park appears a little stange and overpriced. Also, if you mistakenly enter the area towards the parking there is no way to legally exit without entering the car park. As for the actual monument we had a "is that it" feeling. Probably the most disappointing monument we have visited in the US.

Certainly a very impressive memorial, there is an $11 car parking fee which enables you to return for the lighting ceremony at night. Despite the crowds the viewing deck gives you an amazing look at the four presidents carved into the mountain. Take the Presidential trail, it snakes around the base of the mountain with very informative signs telling you about each president, you also go past the centre devoted to the guy who carved it before returning to the viewing deck.

This is an AMAZING monument, and to me, illustrates the incredible vision and fortitude of people. We went during the off season so it wasn't too crowded, and the day we had was beautiful and clear. The drive up was lovely, and the sight itself provided lots of covered parking, audio tour, a large gift shop, eatery, lots of clean washrooms, drinking fountains, and a walking trail that gets you closer to Mount Rushmore itself. Be sure to visit the sculptor's studio to learn more about Borglum. Be sure to bring your camera and extra memory cards, sunblock, a hat, and drink lots of water to combat the heat. Parking fee: $11USD. Fee also covers any re-entry into the park for the rest of the year.

At the time visited (January, 2013) I was a little miffed because I considered the $11:00 parking fee excessive for that time of year but I didn't realize that it was a years pass and as it turned out worth every cent.

Although the memorial is very impressive due to its huge size, going there is a waste of time. You can actually see the monument just as well from the viewpoint on the road from Keystone. Entrance is free but you have to buy a parking ticket for $11. I don't think I have spent 20 minutes at the place and have then seen it all. I can appreciate that Americans will feel different as this is a monument of four of their presidents. Being a tourist I have no such sentiments. Defacing the mountain like that remains questionable. Not worth the trouble and expense if you are not an American

Me and my family went here, expecting to see the "great and beautiful Mt. Rushmore" but all we saw, was a big mountain with four little faces in a corner. We were all very disappointed, but we took some pics in order to show them to our friends. We stopped in a parking spot near to the street, and we jumped back into the car. Then, we decided to do a "u" inversion near to the entrance, but we couldn't, so we had to pay 11$ only to come back. The only reason why I think people should go there, are: 1) It is probably the most famous attraction in this zone (Even if I don't understand why) 2) It is so amaizing how people from that time period have built such a precise thing.
Great for the kids to see this and understand the magnitude of the monument. Can't go wrong for $11 per carload.

I read reviews prior to going and I wish I had listened. I paid $22 in parking and stayed 15 minutes. The only thing to do is to look at the mountain. It's something to say you've seen it, but it was disappointing. Yes, you can see the mountain as you are travelling the highway around it, but there isn't anywhere you can easily stop and take pictures. I thought for the money I was paying, there was going to be something more to do, read, something.

We had a great time here. My niece loved it, and enjoyed the outdoor observation areas. She also loved the chance to push the plunger and "explode" a portion of dynamite on Mt. Rushmore (on a screen as part of an exhibit). Rushmore was impressive, and the drive there is quite nice. The only critique I have is that while the giant ice cream cone was delicious, the portion size was too large for all three of us (my husband, niece, and myself). Specifically, I don't think most 6 year olds need 3 scoops of ice cream, so a child size cone would be a good addition to the menu. That said, the cone was only $5, so it was a good value.

I am 43 and had never seen Mt Rushmore - this summer my husband and I took our 2 daughters (ages 8 and 10) to see it and we were all awed by it! It's truly huge and amazing to imagine how it was carved. The site is well organized and nicely layed out too. It's technically free but $11/car to park (so I suppose if you walked there it would truly be free ;) but totally worth the money. Seeing it from a distance as you drive up is cool too. When you get there and park, you walk in to an area with all the state flags, which is nice, and then out to a platform that overlooks the amphitheatre (there is a show there at night but we didn't go). Lots of people take photos there but it's crowded and there is a better photo spot later. The Presidential Trail walk is worth doing - it's easier (fewer stairs) if you start it from the left (when looking at the amphitheatre). It takes you closer to the monument and also passes the sculptor's studio, which is interesting. At the end there is a path to the right to an overlook that is a better place for photos. Also, the gift store here is great (and the day we were there, there was a man there who had actually worked on the monument so we got to meet him!). And the ice cream store there sells huge cones for $5 - yum!

It's a place you want to see. The parking is $11 which is OK as it's no entry fee, and the parking is very close to the actually sight. The avenue of flags is fun, and the view from the terrasse is great. But the heads are so small - at least much smaller than I imagined after seeing "North by Northwest". Which really tells me I must not trust the movies. I enjoyed it,but the teenagers we brought along didn't get it at all.

This is great to see in person. You can see all the pictures you want, but to see it yourself makes all the difference. You pay for parking (which was about $10 and there was lot of parking) and then you get in for free. The walk as you move toward the faces was amazing! There were flags flying of every state and on the pillars there was information about each state, telling when they became a state and in what order that happened. Inside, there was a film that you should see while you are there that lasted about 10-15 minutes. It showed the making of this monument.

excellent - for years we have done what many others do during the rally and pull over at the side of the road and take a picture but this time we decided to pay the $8.00 and park in the lot and have a good look round . it is well worth it

I had been very much looking forward to seeing Mt Rushmore, but when the time finally came, I was quite disappointed and unimpressed. The carvings are much smaller that advertising would lead you to believe. Plus, despite the fact that this is a National Monument and if you have a parks pass, you get in free, they charge $11 for parking. For me, it just wasn't worth it. I was happy just to do a drive by.

Up close and personal, it's unbelievable how it was accomplished. The facility is extremely well maintained. Don't budget more than an hour or two at the very most. You can see it all very quickly. Do was the entire President's trail if you are able. The views of the sculptures are wonderful. One can almost see Cary Grant hanging on for dear life. It is highly recommended to see it in the late evening when it is lit. Unfortunately we didn't get to do that. It is most certainly something for you to put on your bucket list. NOTE: admission to the facility is free BUT you have to pay $11.00 to park. Now that will cover you for a year but I can't imagine anyone making weekly visits.

If there's one thing for me as a Brit that symbolises America it's Mount Rushmore. I've seen it in so many films over the years, so I was very excited to actually be going there. I don't think my brother shard my excitement but by the time we had left he did say he had enjoyed the visit. We arrived around 5pm one September evening, had a walk to the Grand View Terrace, where I was impressed by the size of the amphitheatre. We then took the walk around the base of the monument which gave some good different perspectives of the 4 famous faces. Even though there's no admission fee for the monument itself, you do have to pay a fee to park, which I think was $15. When you think of the work that went into creating the monument itself, never mind the parking structure, I think $15 is a bargain. I'd happily go again in the future too.
Interesting scam. No entrance fee however, you pay $11 to park. It was worth 30 minutes and a few quick pictures. Certainly not a "do over"

You have to pay $11 to park and it lasts all the day, if you want to go back for the night. It did not disappoint and a very nice walk around. It is well built and loved the grand view to take photos. The flags on the way in looked great and the columns with each state on a lovely touch. Nice shop and helpful staff in the visitor center. Worth every penny to our trip

We wanted to see this historic Monument and drove the 28 miles to get a few pics. The car admission is $11, but the gate was open and unattended as we were in off season and near the end of the afternoon. Great views and pics from the parking lot and with some hiking you can get better shots. Worth the trip. Keystone town was closed as off season. No gas or places to eat.

Having already visited Crazy Horse (and being disappointed), I was really impressed with Mount Rushmore. Only $11 per car (compared to $10 per person at Crazy Horse), it was easy to park and a short walk to the Visitor Centre. It was very busy on the day we visited but did not feel overcrowded There are lots of people stopping to take photos but that is to be expected and there is plenty of room for everybody.

Very beautiful area of the United States, with the Black Hills nearby and a very mid-Western feel. Mount Rushmore was, of course, neat to see but impossible to see without paying $11 for parking! Expensive, like the town around it.

Such a wow experience to finally see them yourself and just on TV. It is incredible to see the four heads carved into the mountain. Since it was already late that day I decided not to pay the 10$ parking fee and who knows if there is an additional entrance fee. I just stopped on the side of the road and took a picture. Of course if you have time and want to learn more about the background of Mount Rushmore, I suggest you actually park your car and go inside;)

It's free to get in but you have to pay for parking $10 which was good value. There is a multistory car park then it's a 5/10 min walk to gain a view of the 4 presidents. There is a visitors centre, but please note there will be a lot of school parties.

We visited the Mt Rushmore Natl Memorial this August for the first time. It was a great experience, we are not Americans but as ever we were highly impressed by the nationalistic fervour of Americans. The Memorial is a well constructed and organized place for visitors, with lots of information about the creating of the sculpture, and the evening lighting of the mountain was spectacular. It is a gentle up hill walk from the parking area so even older folks should be able to make the trip. It cost us $11 for parking when we went in the late-morning and that ticket was still valid when we returned for the night show. Nearby Keystone through which we passed but didn't stay looked very interesting with numerous small stores and eating places and some nice looking hotels. The surrounding Black Hills area is beautiful and the scenic drives over the "pigtail bridges" and through some very narrow tunnels along the Needles highway were nothing short of spectacular. Nearby Rushmore Shadows RV Resort where we stayed is also highly recommended.

What a great place...if you are a proud American like my husband and I are, it will move your heart. The presidential faces are so regal and so beautiful--be sure to look at them up close and you will marvel at the detail. Seeing all the flags of each state is fantastic. One warning--if you are going to stay for the evening lighting ceremony (which I HIGHLY recommend), BE SURE to take a jacket or sweatshirt. It gets pretty chilly in that outdoor amphitheater, even in warm weather! It lasts for about 45-60 minutes and consists of singing, presidential trivia, and a video. It will all put a lump in your throat, believe me. The parking costs about $11, but the attraction itself is free. Absolutely beautiful!!

First time after wanting to see Mt Rushmore for about 50 years. Not at all disappointed. Went during the day and then again for the Lighting Ceremony. Yes the parking is $11.00 but then parking in any large city for a day is more than that. The pass was good for the rest of the year and we used it again for the lighting ceremony. The ranger presentation is great and the film was very interesting. A real history lesson for us Canadians. Have driven by the Memorial about 6 times this week - can't seem to get enough of it. Going back today for one last visit before we leave this area. Only downside was the restaurant being closed when we went for the lighting ceremony - but the buffalo burgers at the little stand were great.

If you are traveling in the area, Mount Rushmore is simply a must-see, and everyone visits. However, for a national monument, I thought $11 for a couple hours to look at a giant statue was a bit much. I know it's good for the entire calendar year, but really, how many people visit Mount Rushmore multiple times in a year?

I have an annual park pass and for some reason this park isn't covered which is just a con really. I drove slowly enough round the edge to get good pictures and read about it on wikipadia, I think $80 is enough for them to have from me already.

I was a little skeptical about how entertaining this carving could be, but I really enjoyed this stop. It was $11 to get in and was a great value. There was lots of parking and a great gift shop. We went early in the morning and it was quiet, we left about an hour later and it was packed. There is a small walking trail that goes close to the mountain, and you must do this for the full effect, this trail is pretty well marked. I can't wait to go back.

It has been several yrs since I had seen Mt Rushmore and I thoroughly enjoyed seeing it again with my family. Such a beautiful and patriotic monument! Our family really enjoyed the walking trail, which is nicely done with walkways and railings. Muliple steps but easily navigated, and it provided a closer view of the faces. Also enjoyed the little building below that houses the sculptor's model and some factual information. Although I love the improvements made with the avenue of flags and the columns and granite walkway and grand entrance to the monument, I was disappointed to see the associated artifacts and pictures and factual information about the formation of the monument is no longer on site. Instead there is a restaurant. There is also a gift shop. The fee was only $11 to get in, so a real value to enjoy the beauty of this majestic monument nestled in the beautiful black hills.

Although you can see this for miles away, do not miss out on the opportunity of getting up close to this astonishing sight. There is plenty of background information to learn more about the hows and whys and a big enough gift shop selling descent souveniers to make this well worth a day out. Do not miss staying on or returning to witness the lighting ceremony - a truly moving experience. The entrance to the park itself is free with an 11 dollar parking fee which is valid to the end of the year.

i've always wanted to see this when i was just in 3rd grade and seeing it in person was just awesome! worth the long drive. went there before noon and as expected there were a lot of tourists. travelled with a toddler, a grade-schooler and a teen-ager, which limited our exploration of the place. just walked through the avenue of flags, took a perfect place to take our pictures, ate at the carver's cafe and visited the souvenir shop and that was it. i will definitely go back to walk through the presidential trail and see the lighting ceremony. take a bottle of water with you, there's a free refill station (price of a bottled water at the concession is stratospheric). take level 6 parking if you don't like to walk up and down a stair (though i think there is an elevator to every parking level). no entrance fee but there is $11 parking fee...

This was my first visit there, and will probably be my only one. Nothing against it, there just wasn't much to do. We stayed in Rapid City and it took about 20-25 mins to get here. Admission to it was free, but parking cost $11 and is good for the rest of the year. The facilities here are on great shape, and looked virtually new. The staff said that it was a slow-ish day there, but with the crowds of people, I would hate to be there on a busy day. I would have liked to see more history of the presidents depicted in the monument. Being a foreigner, I have never taken any American History courses, but I felt like I walked away learning more about the sculpture than the men he so carefully crafted. Having something like a rock carving demonstration or more interactive exhibits of the construction of it would have been nice. We only spent about 2 hrs there, and then came back at night for the illumination ceremony which was a disappointment. They basically just played the same video that loops in the exhibit hall, and slowly turned the lights on. Unless you're already there, I wouldn't go back there for that part. It would also have been nice if there was a restaurant on site, not just a burger-shack. We were pretty burger'd out by that point on a road trip. I'm glad I went once, but it wasn't the highlight of my trip.

I thought there was a large carving in a body of rock, I would snap a few photos and then leave. However when I got there it was a different story. This park really takes into consideration everything that you might think of. They are environmentally conscious, have very good food selections too. It is a great place to sit in the open space and read a book or listen to your MP3 player. Then you can reflect on the beauty of this sculpture. I strongly recommend everyone do the audio tour which will share a lot of insider tidbits with you. Without the audio you will miss so much about the history of the location and the people's stories along with it and might be tempted to say this was 'boring'. We arrived at 11am and didn't leave until 4pm. I truly didn't think the day would fly by so quickly. The gift shop offers some amazing items Made in the USA also. A nice touch given everything imported from overseas nowadays. Treat yourself to an American piece of history. PS all you pay is $11 for parking and you get to use the pass for 1 year.

Well worth the visit, and for $11 per car (valid for the year) you cannot complain about the price. Also worth going back for the nightly light festival when the sculptures are illuminated, (this festival is a highly patriotic affair, so if you have a problem with that then it's not for you). We loved it!

As a kid, I was always curious about this place, so far away. I Am glad I was able to finally see it in person. It was all I believed it would be and more. I think the 11 dollar fee for parking is acceptable, it is good for the year ( i doubt we will get back again by Dec though).

Why is this National Memorial not free to visit. After all we got the Alakian Hwy opened to all for free. The Blue Ridge Parkway was only given to the people if it was FREE. The memorial itself was worth the visit but not the payment of a fee for parking
