One of the highlights of our trip, its actually free to enter, you just need to pay $11 to park. Get there early, to avoid queues, we got in at 10:00 and had the place to ourselves for a while. The video is interesting, and the views of the heads are stunning. Do the presidential trail as you get many different views and also visit the hut at the bottom of the trail, it has the original mock ups, and alot of information.
Nice arranged, clean, nice personell. Although we had an beautiful pass we had to pay 11 dollar for parking.
Mount Rushmore is a definite must see, when in the US. Entry is $11 but it is quite remarkable. Parking and access well organized and easy access to the monument.

We enjoyed our visit and the price of $11 for an annual pass is outstanding, (wish they took cards though) Having seen this image so many times it was a "Bucket List" item for us and it is impressive. Do see the Film first which gives all the background information. For Americans it is of great significance but truthfully we preferred Crazy Horse Memorial. They have an audio tour you can purchase too.

We were traveling with and 81 yr old so we got her a wheelchair which limited where she could go. She was quite happy watching us from a distance. There are elevators but the paths are more for walking. There is a museum and a short film showing how they managed to sculpt the heads. We were there in March which was a good time since the weather was so nice this year and it wasn't that crowded. A lot of attractions on the way were not open at this time of year but we managed to find enough to keep us entertained. The fee is $11.00 per vehicle. They have a restaurant that was very good for a limited menu. I had the chicken fingers which were some of the best I have had. My daughter had a sore throat and could only eat soft food. The cook made her a scrambled egg even though that wasn't on the menu at that time of day. All staff that we dealt with were very friendly and helpful.

it was a good place to see, lots of history. you have to show up before 5pm if you want to do the audio tour of anything. We showed up later in the evening for the lighting ceremony which was cool but I was sad that we didn't get to do the audio tour of the place. 11 dollars a vehicle to park, which was fine, and there were bathrooms everywhere which was also good.

How incredibly disappointing to be held to ransom to see a National Monument. They have built an incredibly ugly edifice right in front of this monument which obstructs your view of the faces. To be able to see them without all the concrete in front you are forced to pay for an Annual membership to the carpark. It isn't a huge amount at $11 (at Dec 2011) however we didn't want to stay for hours - just for a few minutes to take photos. We were refused permssion to do that unless we paid.

If you are thinking of going on to see the other monument Crazyhorse which is about 17 miles further on look at it from the road as they charge $29 to drive closer to it and considering its only partly finished is a rip off.

Decided to pay the $11 and go inside park. Well worth the money. The view is even more spectacular the closer you get. You can chat to the park rangers and find answers to your questions about the monuments. Went for a walk along the presidents trail and ended upat the base of the monuments. Amazing. The sculptors studio is worth a visit too. Gift shop is great. Don't even bother with the gift shops outside the Park. They sell cheap nasty alternatives. We had a snack in the cafe. The buffalo chili at $5 a bowl was very tasty. Free refills with the organic coffee was a bonus on a cold windy day.

had great time at mount rushmore i am english but still thought mount rushmore was superb,do your walk around the base of rushmore its very nice things to read along the way they sell lovely icecream in the shop and its nice to just sit and watch people come and go up the avenue of flags dont miss it, it costs $11 dollars to park your car but entrance to the site is free , the parking ticket is valid for a week

Visited Mt Rushmore in July this year and was very impressed with the whole place. When I read there was an $11 parking charge thought it was a bit over the top, but there's no entrance charge and plenty to see, so really it is value for money . The information centre is brilliant and we saw a very informative film about the building of Mt Rushmore. Even the walk way up to the viewing area was interesting, with flags of all the states. It was very well done and not at all 'tacky'. Would definitely recommend to anyone in the area.

In late August 2005, we drove the scenic route to Mt. Rushmore. The morning was spent driving thru the Spearfish Canyon Scenic Byway. Speed limit is 35 MPH so you can enjoy the scenery. If you are in a rush, don’t take this route. Just before Lead is a new attraction called Presidents’ Park. It is a self guided 6 block walking tour, or you can rent mountain bikes to go farther. Stone carvings of 43 Presidents, costs about $8 person. On to Deadwood. What a fun place to walk around on another self-guided tour! Allow at least 3 hours to see town [free], Mt Moriah Cemetary [$1 per person] and visit some casinos and have lunch. There are staged shoot-outs on the Main Street at 2pm. We ate lunch at the Iron Horse. My husband chose all day breakfast, I had grilled chicken salad [$15 USD with tax & tip] . Friendly staff, good food. At Mt Moriah we saw graves of Wild Bill Hickock, Calmity Jane, and Potato Johnny. 3 Eights and 2 Aces was the hand Wild Bill was holding when he was shot by the dirty scoundrel Jack McCall. On to Hill City to shop at the Quilt Corral of Mistletoe Ranch. Very friendly and helpful staff and wonderful selection of fabrics. We opted to stay on Hwy 16 [no park fee] rather than take the Needles Highway through Custer State Park [$5 person]. Hwy 16 has the pigtail bridges and the 3 tunnels, with Mt Rushmore framed in the exit of the last tunnel. Be aware that there is a lot of braking, tight, winding curves and narrow roads. Great scenery, saw buffalo, deer, mountain goats. Mt Rushmore [$8 parking fee] is very impressive. As you walk toward the mountain you pass thru the Avenue of Flags, every state and territory is represented. The town of Keystone is very, very commercialized. We opted to overnight in Rapid City.

We visited Natural Bridges NM on our way from Monument Valley to Capitol Reef NP. And it was one of the best days of our whole trip! The wonderful drive from Monument Valley leads you to the Moki Dugway Pass, which is also a great experience and then you reach this beautiful National Monument. We did the hike to a really cool viewpoint at the first of the bridges and hiked down the whole trail at the last bridge. It was so beautiful! It wasn't quite as empty as most people write here (okay, we've been here during Spring Break), but nevertheless way less people than everywhere else on this trip. And the drive from here to Capitol Reef NP was also outstanding, with stunning views of red rocks, leisurely cows on streets and maybe 10 other cars in a drive that lasted 3 hours

Natural Bridges National Monument ($10 per vehicle) is a great stop to make on the U.S. Route 95 Scenic Drive to see three impressive natural bridge land formations. The park is 35 miles west of Blanding and is open 24 hours a day.

Out in the middle of nowhere is this delightful national monument. You go to the visitor center first for all info and payment. One hike is really fun where part of the trail includes using a ladder. It leads to a wonderful view. None of the trails is exhausting and the last arch reminded us of Landscape Arch in Arches NP. We were extremely pleased with our visit here. Highly recommend and we suggest bringing a picnic lunch to enjoy at one of the overlooks/parking lots. The number of visitors in mid-May during the week is minimal. So nice!!

This was a great alternative option on my way from Moab to Monument Valley, saw few people in the Visitor Center, which gave me more room to enjoy the place. The journey in the car is a mini-circuit in one direction making the necessary stops to admire the natural bridges, the most beautiful for me is the Owachomo Bridge. If time permits, you should walk a little on designated trails. I would have liked to camp in this place but you can not make reservations, it's first come, first served. I use my Annual Pass for save money.

From our base in Monticello it was a pleasant and not too long of a drive to reach the Natural Bridges. We were surprised that there were only three bridges, but each one is different and quite splendid to see up close. We parked at Owachomo bridge and hiked the canyon bottom trail to the next bridge, Kachina, We planned on hiking all the way to Sipapu Bridge, but it took longer than anticipated to reach Kachina so we hiked out of the canyon and took the trail back to our vehicle. We then drove back to Sipapu bridge and hiked down to it. Sipapu is probably the most impressive of the three bridges, but the entire park is scenic and well worth a visit. If one does go hiking, take plenty of water. Even though we were there in late May the weather was quite hot. Sitting under Kachina bridge in the shade was a pleasant spot for lunch. The park entry fee was only $6 per vehicle.

We stayed in the campground for one night (cheap at $10) and toured the bridges the next day on our way to Moab. Great hikes to the bridges; great opportunities for photography. we were there on June 4th, already hot but not unbearable for a couple of Canadians. Worth going to, esp. if you want to avoid a lot of people.

$6 for the car. From the Visitor Centre (with proper toilets) there is a 9 mile one-way loop with lay-bys for photos and trails. It was hot, but there was a cooling breeze. It took near enough 4 hours and we didn't hike any of the trails. You are 7000' high.

This is a stop well worth some time either before or after Old Faithful erupts. The rangers there can give you a very close estimate of when it will blow so you can relax and enjoy the movie, the displays and yes, even the gift shops. The lady helping me check out noted that I had lots of kids stuff. She mentioned that I could support the park with a membership and receive a nice gift in return. For a $35 donation I received a soft wolf to bring home to a grandchild not with me. This stuffed animal would easily cost $20 elsewhere. It is something to consider to help the park thrive. I promise, this was not a hard sell.
we picked up the trail guides ($1 donation for each) which were very useful. Also worth watching the free film the theatre

We arrived late and paid on a sort of honor system where you sign an envelope and put your money inside a box. I guess this is only the case if you are really late or the overseer is not there. We chose our own campsite. Tents can only be set up on sites with a tent pad. Rates are low. Ours was $10. The campsites are beautiful. We explored the next morning with the kids. They loved it. They now want to camp all the time.

This could be a top tourist place to visit but unfortunately it has been neglected although it was still lovely. The best view was from McBride Street. If a few dollars was to be injected into this area it would be a beautiful place to go for a family picnic along with the Paterson Museum just a few minutes walk down the road.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: The Paterson or Passaic Falls is a great surprise and treat if you are ever near Paterson, NJ.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: This park was spectacular. I "stumbled" across it as I was staying in Pecos and drove by it; I drove in to see what it was all about. The walking trail is superb. I learned so much about the history of the people that have lived in this area for centuries. The ruins - particularly the Kivas - were in fantastic shape. You are allowed to climb down into the kivas which I did. The staff were amongst the best I came across during my visit to NM and AZ. This seems to be an undiscovered gem as I virtually had the park to myself. Highly recommended if you are in the area. It is between Santa Fe and Las Vegas (NM) and definitely worth the drive if you are just visiting Santa Fe and then returning to Albuquerque. Best $3.00 I spent on my trip to the American Southwest.
At $20 for the car we were sceptical but worth it completely. The drive down to the painted desert first stop is spectacular. The whole park felt like another planet. Do go!

Had a pleasant few hours walking around this park, had to pay $10 but then could walk around the area. Lots of interesting facts, only disappointing thing is there is no where to buy a drink or snacks from other than sweets.
Definitely worth the 20$ it cost to take the car through, some great picture oportunities and a must see.

We decided to do this trip and have got say it was worth the $20 to see everything. There are plenty of stopping off viewing areas and even a rest stop with toilets (in the middle of the desert). The viewing areas have information boards explaining what you're seeing and some of the views are out of this world.

I was a little bit reluctant to visit this place but i was with a group of friends and some wanted to see this so we all did it and WOW so pleased we did. Admission to the general park area is $20 per car. I was surprised to find that this place is so much more than a petrified Forrest, there are lots of things to see including ancient pueblos and rock drawings which to me was actually the most interesting part! It is easy to walk around as simple paths have been created. Lots of detailed information along the way too. I also like that you can spend as little or as much time here as you like, so for some people i'm sure they could spend a day or two exploring but for us we spent about 3 hours and came away feeling like we had gained so much information!

I had prepared myself for a couple of wasted hours, as articles I had read suggested that this phenomenon was something of a non-event. So its not Disneyland, but I found it fascinating and wished I had allowed more time to do more of the short hikes. We were there late afternoon, which may have helped catch some of the wonderful hues in the rocks and hills. To think that this forest has moved over millions of years from where Costa Rica is today is mind exploding, so I guess some imagination has to be used when visiting this very interesting place. A bonus was the opportunity and walk around these natural exhibits. I'd go again, given the opportunity. My only criticism was being chased out at sunset by the ranger, as this was the best time of day for photographs.
20 dollars an absolute must to spend a couple of hours cruising across this landscape, fantastic place

Admission is free, parking, $1. Their website clearly states the visitor center is not the entrance to the park. There are various entrances. The Boca Negra is two miles to the west and Rinconada is four miles to the east. You can select how much time you want to spend.

There is a lot of compelling things here to see. We spent our time checking out the trails at the Boca Negra Canyon. The dark basalt landscape is really interesting and distinctive. The Mesa Point Trail takes you up a hill, which is fine for most people. If you have difficulty moving around, or if you need a cane or assistance to walk, you may not find this to be your cup of tea. It's not very strenuous but there are lots of small steps. The other trail to see here, the Cliff Base Trail, is flatter. You do get up close to many petroglyphs and the signs inform you of the history and geologic traits of the area. Parking is only $1 and is located inside the city of Albuquerque.

We were delighted with our visit to the Petroglyph National Monument even on a very hot day. We enjoyed the short walks to view a variety of images and then drove to the volcano site for a longer walk. We stopped at the main visitor centre for maps and info and planned our trip accordingly. We only paid $1 for parking to see the petroglyphs and nothing for the volcanoes. Great views back to Albuquerque and beyond. We would have stayed longer but it was closing time.

Petroglyph National Monument is just a few miles outside of Albuquerque, so it is an easy side trip as well as being interesting and educational. You can skip the Visitor Center if you are mainly interested in looking at the Petroglyphs (rock drawings made by Native Americans 400-700 years ago). You can continue on Unser Bl. and turn right at the sign for Boca Negra Canyon. There is a $2 parking fee and a few different trails that will lead you to numerous Petroglyphs. The images are cool and you may see some wild life too!

These peaks are the leftovers of a huge volcano that erupted more than 150 miles south. The San Andreas Fault first split up these peaks and over the eons of years shoved them Northwest that distance to their current location. Mother park has both a western access and an eastern access, but the two don't meet! The terrain here is so severe and beautiful that there is no through road across the park! The west side is accessible from the town of Soledad. The eastern section is accessible from King City. The eastern portion is also better developed for tourism, with several hiking trails. Check the MPs.gov website for details. Entry fee is $10 per car. Nature Center in the eastern portion is open 10 am to 4 pm on weekends between January and June. There is also a campground in the eastern portion - $23 per vehicle and $36 per RV. Weather is very hot in the summer, and generally hotter in the west than in the east. Enjoy!

We visited Pinnacles National Park on the last Saturday of summer. As stated by others, we started early and were glad we did. We arrived at the visitor’s center on the east side at 9:00 a.m. There were a number of people wandering around because they weren’t open at 9:00 a.m. and there were no maps. The sign said it opened at 0 a.m. (which wasn’t very helpful). After peering into the window, we found that it opened at 9:30. Not wanting to start exploring without a map, we waited until they opened. The person behind the counter was surprised there were no maps in the kiosk. Also, the fee to enter the park is $10.00. If you want to start hiking before 9:30, you may want to download and print a map in advance.

Visited Pinnacles the day after leaving Yosemite and actually may have enjoyed it more. The newest National Park is only $5 entry for a week and far less crowded. The trails are easy to follow and give a real sense of the landscape / geology in this quiet gem of the park service.

There are many hikes to choose from, all levels available. The hikes take you through various natural environments, including chapparal (sp?) pine forest, volcanic rocks, caves, etc. The entrance fee for seven days is only five dollars. Take your own food because there is nowhere to eat and the only way to stay is via camping.

$5.00 entrance fee if you don't already hold the Hawaii National Park Tri Park Pass. Located not far from Kailua-Kona on the west coast of the Big Island. Not a big area to look at - could possibly be done within an hour. Presentations/demonstrations of Hawaiian carving and talks by Rangers at different times of the day. Great views right on the water and it's a very serene and relaxing place. Interesting to learn more about the ancient Hawaiian culture. Large carpark and clean bathrooms.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: If you have the Hawaii National Parks pass, you can get in here for free. Otherwise, it is $5 for a car. The park is pretty small. There is a little bit about Hawaiian history. There are some nice palm trees and views. I did not spend a ton of time here, but you can see some fish in the ponds as well. The gift shop for this park was great. It was the only place where I saw a stuffed nēnē.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The driver that we hired for the day brought us here so it was unexpected. Only a few dollars to get in, and mostly outdoors, it was a great and interesting touch of history of Hawaii. Beautifully laid out and far too much for us to look at in the time we had available. Set aside a few hours for a really good look around because there is quite a bit of walking and not always on even ground.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Our friends recommended visiting this location, and we were very glad we did. There is a small fee ($5?) to get in, and they give you brochure that details the various things you will see in the park. We enjoyed hearing the history of the main venue, and the location and buildings around the site were amazing. They offer an audio playback that you can utilise while there with your own cellphone. You call a toll-free phone number they provide and use the menu as you walk through the park to play voice commentary on the various sites you are looking at. We had a Roam Mobility phone plan on our phone, and Roam did not allow us to use the service, we got a message saying that type of service wasn't authorised for whatever reason, which was disappointing, but the map/brochure the park provided does describe what you are seeing. This is a great place to visit for people of all ages and fitness levels. They make the site very accessible.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This National Park charges $5 for parking. There are water fountains, bathrooms and a small gift shop. There are knowledgeable rangers on site, as you might expect. The site is great for a stroll among hawaiian totems and other displays. We visited before snorkelling at nearby "Two-step".
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Interesting history, $5 park entry fee per car, very informative free 30 min talk by the local ranger run 3x times per day (last talk at 2.30pm) also some videos available for viewing by history buffs ( call in advance to confirm times) . Great views,easy park to explore. Beautiful park with a perfect picnic area and adjacent snorkeling area.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: A scenic drive from Waikoloa along the coast. This sacred sight gives you a real sense of Hawaiian history and is a great place to see Tiki statues. Self guided tours available and a 7 day parking pass is only $5
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We went to one Historical Hawaiian Site hoping to see how the Hawaiian's lived and after a long drive were disappointed, but that was not the case with this National Park / Attraction, It was really worth seeing and the entry to the park cost of $5 per vehicle was worth every penny. The site was well set out and even though we didn't go on a guided tour, the self guided tour brochure was informative and easy to follow. Well worth seeing and a must see tourist spot that doesn't cost a fortune.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: A great stop if you are traveling through! The tour is very educational, the monuments and artifacts are so impressive and you have a view of that gorgeous ocean! Right next door is also a small beach where you can go in the water or hang out on the small plot of sand. Also the $5 entrance fee is outstanding!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This is where you can learn about some of the history of Hawaii. It is a national park so there is a $5 entrance parking fee. Start with the ranger talk to understand some of the history. If it is a hot day take sunhat and water with you as there is not much shelter when you are walking around.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This historical village is a must see. It looks like something right out of a movie. The water is crystal clear and the sand is white. You can do a self guided tour and take as long as you would like. They give you a piece of paper explaining everything that you are looking at in this restored village with tiki statues. There isn't much shade and there isn't a breeze, so wear a hat and bring some water to drink because it was really hot when I was there. The charge is $5.00 a car load. There are bathrooms and a gift shop.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: A Park highlighting Hawaiian culture, sitting at a very important and beautiful spot south of Kona. Easy parking,only $5 to get in. Simple visitor centre but there are regular walks and talks. We did the easy self-guided walk (take the map!) which takes about an hour. You get some sense of what life was like 500 years ago, especially as the large retaining wall is still standing, separating those seeking refuge (this park is also called The Place of Refuge) from the chiefs. Always interesting to learn about their often violent history and traditions. Pleasant walking, easily laid out and all v well looked after. Good for an afternoon visit and it's right next to a v famous snorkelling site; 2 step.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Interesting park to come and visit for a $5 entry fee (per car). It showcases a historic place of refuge and the royal quarters right next door. You get a bit of a sense of the history of the place and everything is very accessible and well signposted. Definitely worth a stop although unlikely you will spend longer than an hour there.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We came here to walk around the grounds. It's $5 to park and the pass is good for a week. The grounds are lovely, with some interesting historical information. Right next door is two-step where you can snorkel. It's rocky but there is a boat ramp to enter and the water was calm. In the refuge, there is a massive wall made of lava rock... Had to be 10 feet thick and close to that in height. It separated the king's ground from the place of refuge. There are washrooms on site as well, but no food or drink.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This is a beautiful National Park that is worth visiting. It costs $5 to park and this is good for a week.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Nice historical park. Helpful staff. I liked the recreation of what life was like. You could park outside and walk in but parking is only $5 and good for 7 days! If you walk in there is a $1 charge. Bathrooms are nice. No swimming or snorkeling within park boundaries. But, adjacent to boat dock is a bay open to the public. See Honaunau Bay reviews.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: When we visited in early February most of the park was closed due to surf damage - the ranger was not clear on the fact that very little of the park is open. But we were happy to spend the five dollars in any event - do walk next door to the snorkelling beach - where there are often Dolphins. The park is great ( we have been before ) - and if surf damaged is repaired you will learn a lot (and probably see turtles) but the damage does mean that you should plan on less time spent here than would usually be the case . Kahterine Anne
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Easy 40 minute drive from Kona-Kailua, expect some traffic on the way as the highway is 1-lane. Some beautiful views on the drive down to the park. The $5 entry fee per vehicle is for 7 days and helps preserve the national park so well worth the small change. We parked here to go snorkelling just to the right of the park (there is very limited parking on the road and there is a guy who charges $5 parking next to Two Steps but we would prefer the money to go to the park). The snorkelling was good, waves came in as the afternoon progressed. Beautiful fish in abundance and we saw 2 or 3 green sea turtles. Very exciting (also very busy and quite slippery on the rocks). Had a stroll around the park to dry off although many sites were closed today due to the wave damage. A great half-day attraction and history lesson.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The site is very interesting, wish they provided a bit more information then what is found in the pamphlet/map. Excellent value for money, as it costs $5 per vehicle, and that pass is good for a week.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This was our final activity on our first ever trip to Hawaii and it was a great way to end our holiday. The entrance fee of $5 is well worth every cent!! The park was really well laid out and the self guided tour so easy to follow. It gave you a real insight into Hawaiin life pre Captain Cook. We even saw a native Hawaiin dressed accordingly and working on his crafts, in addition to the reconstructed idols, grounds of a royal palace, a fish pond, and the Great Wall.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We visited this park while out for a drive and it is filled with Hawaiian history. There is a self guided walking tour which is a must and it is by no means difficult. The day we visited there was a native Hawaiian talking about the history of the park and he was very interesting. This is well worth the $5 entrance fee into the park!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Definitely worth the $5 entrance fee. First, listened to the Ranger give a talk about the area, Kapu, place of refuge etc..... got some understanding of the history of the park and ancient Hawaiian culture and traditions. Then went for a self guided walking tour of the area. Saw some turtles swimming in rock pools. Nice picnic area where we had some packed lunch and watched a few whales spurting off shore.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: There's a $5.00 fee, but they don't always have manpower to man the toll booth so you might get lucky. This is a very interesting site for those interested in the history of the original inhabitants of Hawaii (or the second inhabitants if you count the mythical menehune). Get the brochure near the washrooms or you will have to guess at what everything is. The only signs (other than number posts that match descriptions on the brochures) are the signs telling you to stay off the rock walls. The place of refuge as it's called locally (since pu'uhonua o honaunau is a bit of a mouthfull!) was the place you went if you broke the "kapu" rules that guided Hawaiian life until Christianity became more dominant. Pretty much every rule was punishable by death. If you could make it to the City of Refuge, a Kahuna could have you perform rituals to clean the slate for you and you could return home. The rules ranged from fishing or hunting in places that had been placed off limits to allow stocks to replenish to allowing your shadow to fall on an Ali'i (royalty) since this would offend the gods and cause an earthquake, volcanic eruption or tsunami. Good snorkelling is adjacent at two step.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We drove and parked in the lot for the Historical Park, which was fine because I wanted a bit of Hawaiian culture and history. It was only $5 and the pass is good for the week, although really the park can be done in an hour and that's with reading the pamphlet at the sites. It is all about location.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The attraction is not large but a must for the amazing statues setting and spiritual feeling you get once you are there. They only charge $5 to get in and they could charge more and if this was in England they would, you would be mad not to add this beautiful place on your list of things to do. We were even lucky enough to see a beautiful turtle on the beach.While there we met a ranger called Charles who was lovely and gave us a little gift after spending time talking to him re allsorts.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This park is full of history, worth the $5 entry fee. It is a self-guided tour and you are given a map when you enter the park. Once you get into the park area, follow the map and each different historical point is clearly described on the map. The view from the park is amazing and you can see turtles swimming around in the surf, and maybe on the beach! It was not very busy when I was there but there is plenty of parking. You can probably spend and hour or so here just exploring. There are signs up prohibiting sun bathing and picnicking in the park area. When you are done in the park, head over to the beach/snorkeling area (Two Steps) right before the park entrance. This is a great snorkeling location (two steps down into the water) and it's nice to cool down after the park. There is a more sheltered beach area if you are not a snorkeler.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The Place of Refuge is situated a 5 minute drive from the bay that overlooks the Captain Cook Monument and for 5$ entry, is worth the money. There is a Hawaiian Temple where 13 Chiefs were buried and excellent tour guides that explain the relevance of the sacred land to the Hawaiian people and blend in the culture with school group visits. A truly inspiring experience.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We had read about the Place of Refuge in the guide books so took a trip out. It was a 45 minute drive but well worth the effort. The $5.00 park fee is minimal. We missed the guide talk but wandered around at our leisure with a self-guided brochure that provided all the info we needed to get a good picture of what happened there. Anyone who committed a transgression toward the chief would be absolved of the crime if he could reach this place before being clubbed to death. Quite an incentive! While out this way, drop by the Painted Church which is nearby. Also worth a look.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Ample parking. A five dollar admission. A self guided tour with some audio and a good guide book. It was very interesting and informative. Lots of great photo opportunities. As it is a sacred and historical site there is no smokin, sunbathing or swimming. Save those things for Two Steps which is right there beside the park.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Good self-guided tour of this beautiful site. Entrance fee is $5 per car. History buffs may want to read up in advance. There are free interpretive talks at 10:30 AM and 2:30 PM. Wildlife viewing too... we saw BIG green turtles and colorful fish. The NPS doesn't allow snorkel rentals in the park, so bring your own or rent in advance if you wish to swim with the fishes.

Fascinating! Want to go there again and again. Sequoias are mindbendering. Feel yourself in fairytale. We camped at Jededdiah campground and this experience unforgettable. If you want to see and feel sequoias, Redwood is the place to do it, not Sequoia Park with coulpe trees among others. Love the place, love the atmosphere. Facilities is really good.

Unless you have an interest in WWII historical facts, this may seem a bit boring. The memorial was less than spectacular and I expected a lot more information. However, the Red Oak Victory ship tour was fun and informative. Admission is free, but donations are encouraged.
park: Rosie the Riveter/World War II Home Front National Historical Park

text: I was on a US road trip. Drove 7 hrs from Utah down to Tucson. Arrived to 103F temps!! Drove round the east side first which was OK but not really worth the $15 fee.
Beautiful scenery, deep blue lakes, mountains capped with snow and gorgeous aspens in the Fall. The Coal Bank Pass is particularly fine. Recommend the drive up to Silverton from Durango.

The drive from Durango to Telluride over Molas Pass and the Red Dog is awesome! The beautiful Colorado Blue Spruce, Aspen, creeks and the fresh blue sky is so refreshing! Take your time and definitely stop on top at Molas Pass, just unbelievable!
Amazing drives up and down mountains! Scarry if you don't like heights! The Red Mountain Pass to Silverton is incredible! Very beautiful!

Drove east from downtown Saratoga Springs to the Battles of Saratoga National Historical Park. At the Visitor Center (open 9-5, seven days a week) there is a 20-minute black-and-white documentary film about this turning point in the American Revolution as well as a diorama of the area, a gift shop and washrooms. There are a lot of bus tours stopping here. The battlefield grounds are open dawn to dusk, seven days a week for hiking, cycling and horseback self-guided tours (cost $3 per person 16+) or drive arounds for five dollars on the ten-mile one-way tour road which is open early April to early December. You buy a pass card to display on your windshield and get a route map with all 10 battlefield stops indicated. A great outdoor history experience on the warm, sunny fall day when we were there.

This is a wonderful battlefield park that has been left pretty much unspoiled. Start your visit at the Visitor Center. If you have an ancestor that fought here on the American side the ranger will retrieve his name from a database and provide you with what information they have on him. They will also indicate on your park tour map where his company was positioned during the fighting making your visit a very personal one. There is an excellent display that brings the battles to life with the use of a model of the battlefield and LEDs. There are displays showing uniforms, etc. and a nice gift shop. For a small fee of $5.00 you purchase a park driving pass (valid for 6 consecutive days) and set off to explore the park on your own. There are ten stops where you get out of your car and walk to a small interpretive board that explains what you are viewing. The signage is minimal so it helps if you have done some pre-reading about the battles that occurred here. There is also no indication of how far you have to walk and whether the trail is a loop back to the car or a trail into the park. The British and American fortified lines are clearly marked with stakes so orientation to battle landmarks is fairly easy. Allow 2 hours at least to do the car drive if you want to get a real feel for the battlefield. We visited in October and the foliage was spectacular - along with the frequent deer sightings. This park has something for everyone, history buff or nature lover it is well worth the visit. Please take time to pause and reflect on the lives lost here - it is a place to connect with the past.
start at the visitor centre, $5 access to drive the park, watch the film at the centre, gives a good overview of what happened on the battlefield here.

We spent 2 full days in the park and we could easily have done with longer. This is really 2 national parks in one, and each very different from the other. In late August we found Kings Canyon to be very quiet,ideal for enjoying the majesty of this truly remarkable place and walking some of the trails that allow you to enjoy this pristine location. Sequoia however was very busy, with lots of people around the great trees and also further along the park road adjacent to the museum. The sight of these great trees is really something to see and if you are in the vicinity of these parks you need to make the time to see them. Both parks are covered by the one entrance fee of $30 per car for 5 consecutive days and as in all the national parks I have visited the United States park service has done and are doing a wonderful job.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: I visited Sequoia National park with my wife and kids aged 10 to 13 in mid September. The road up from the National park entrance is a full of twists, turns and sharp bends. At the start you are driving through an arid climate with dry weather plants. The first attraction you come across is Tunnel Rock. As we drove we saw tarantula's crossing the road and deer feeding on the sides. A little higher the scenery started to change with more pine and fur trees. About 3 quarters of the way up you can stop at a scenic point and look up at Moro Rock. This is worth climbing, the view is amazing and it is not too hard of a hike. 400 steps in all. Continuing on as you pass through 5500 feet altitude you can start to spot smaller Giant Sequoia trees. Passing through 6000ft you drive around a bend and there in front of you are those massive trees. We were in awe at the immense size of these ancient trees. Bend after bend reveals another tree then another until there are too many to count. It's a truly humbling experience knowing that these trees have stood the test of time. Another bucket list item ticked off.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: We spent one day in the park we used the free shuttle service inside the park and the shuttle at 15 $ round trip to 3rivers
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: Spent a month in California and this was the best part. In Seqoia NP the walk through the 3000 year Sequoia trees, some of the oldest living things on the planet, was humbling and thrilling at the same time. It is something I will always remember. Try to go when it's quieter and leave the crowds at and around the General Sherman tree, take a packed lunch and walk a bit further to enjoy this special place in quiet majesty. Buy a detailed walking map at ranger station so you don't get lost. The free road map you get on entry is not detailed enough for hiking. We bought an annual pass for all USA national parks for $80 , this was best $80 I spent!
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: It is very humbling to stand next to a living, growing thing that is over 2000 years old. The trees are gorgeous, and words and photography rarely do them justice. Bring your own water and lunch as there are few concessions in the park. $30 entrance fee per car. Free shuttle service within the park. Sequoia Shuttle (reservations required, $15 round trip) from designated pick-up locations is a good way to go.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: Holy cow, I wish I did a little more research on this park! The road is horrendous!!! Hairpin turns all the way, steep cliffs and ignorant drivers who are in a hurry. This is an hour drive just from where you pay, and do you ever pay...$30 for a day each vehicle(unless you want to actually go back another day it covers you for a week). Once you get to the museum where allot of the trails are the trees are amazing, there was snow in the shady areas, it was beautiful. The bathrooms at the museum were disgusting and old and this was at noon. The worst part was driving up and the second worst was going back down! Oh, and if you want trail guides, fork out more $!
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: This was one of our absolute favourite places visited on our recent trip. The sequoia national park is spectacular and the sequoias nothing short of magnificent. There's several walks which cater to all fitness levels, though take the time to just sit and wonder at these incredible giants. We all adored this national park and came away energised and serene! Staff were friendly and knowledgeable and there is a free bus that drives you along the sequoia Valley with really interesting commentary. The gift shop offers great information and nice souvenirs. To get into the park is a usd$20 or $25 fee per car (I confess I cannot remember!), but we'll worth it! Do yourself a favour and visit, if you're in the area!!
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: After paying the small fee to enter the park (I think it was $10 but can't remember) we drive to Cottonwood campground which you are not allowed to reserve a site. When we got there, we realized that it was one of those camping sites that you reserve on the honour system, where you drive around, choose your site and then put $10 in an envelope and put it in a slot at the reservation board. I couldn't believe it was that inexpensive for one of the most beautiful sites we've ever camped in! We stayed in site 68. There was no electricity there, but I think there are electrical sites in the campground. There are flush toilets, water pumps located throughout. We had a great view. We had neighbours on either side of us, but the sites were so far apart that we forgot they were there. It was very quiet. Really a beautiful place that shouldn't be missed.

The Lewis and Clark National and State Historical Parks covers a very large geographical area and many different sites. Your best bet is to start at Fort Clatsop (admission is $3 per person) where there is a small display on the expedition and an excellent recreation of the fort used during the winter of 1805/1806. I would then head across the river to the state of Washington and visit the Lewis and Clark Interpretative Center which is located in Cape a Disappointment State Park (a $10 flat charge per vehicle is required for the park and there is a $5 per person charge for the museum). The museum does a fabulous job at providing an overview of the expedition in chronological order and it is interlaced with relics, copies of original letters and other items which enhances the narrative. There are several other sites on the Washington side of the river including Station Camp, Fort Columbia and Dismal Nitch - none of them were worth the stop.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: Fabulous visitor centre. Fee is payable. It is worth every cent. Really detailed presentation and displays of the expedition. Amazing interactive activities at end.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: Walked to the top and enjoyed the Lewis and Clark history walls. Pay for parking and pay for exhibit.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: We went for an evening cruise thinking it may be the best time to see some wildlife. We paid $20 and all we say was prairie dogs! Don't waste your money unless you are camping in there.

Great park. Spent the day pretending I was in a western film. We saw bison, eagles, wild horses from the car. Some great walking trails but too too hot on our day. Cost $20 for our car valid for 7 days. Go to the painted canyon overlook for free if you want to see bison and the badlands style of the park. No water stops on the way round - make sure you have provisions!

This is a great park if you enjoy hiking and seeing wildlife. There are plenty of opportunities to catch great pictures of buffalo, prairie dogs, birds and wild horses! The landscape is beautiful. We hiked the painted canyon trail which was perfect for our time constraint. It was a mile loop. It's not a tough hike. I had a 13 year old, an 8 year old and a 5 year old with me, it was just the right length for the younger ones but still fun for the older boy. We then made our way to do the drive through the park. There are many spots to pull over and take pictures. Make sure to use the restroom before you go in to the drive. The only restroom is at the gate. We paid 20 dollars at the gate to drive the loop. Well worth it!!

The Southern Gate to the Theodore Roosevelt National Park is located minutes from downtown Medora. Upon entering the park, you will find the Visitor Center which provides good background to the park. A 35-mile drive in the park will allow you to see some fantastic topography and animals close up. Our drive was interrupted momentarily as buffalo crossed the road. Best part of visiting the park is the $10 per vehicle fee which is good for seven days, so you can stop by the Visitor Center one day; complete the 35-mile drive another day; and ride horses a third day. Staff in the park were courteous and helpful.

This area is breathtaking. If you are just passing through, at least stop at the painted canyon overlook, a rest area on I94. but the real deal is the 36 mile loop through the park. $10 gives you a multiple day pass for the loop. It is a slow leisurely enjoyable meander through some of the most interesting scenery east of the Rockies. There are Bison herds, wild horses, various deer, and prairie dog villages to see. If you can spare the time, this area is absolutely worth it.

We did the scenic loop drive through the park at the South end. Gorgeous views, saw a buffalo herd very close to the road and saw wild horses. Kids 12 and 9 enjoyed the drive, which due to construction was lengthy but still well worth it if you are not in a hurry. $10 per vehicle to enter but pass good for a week and for both north and south units.

It costs $10/per vehicle. The drive took us about an hour and a half. We stopped a lot to take pictures and look a scenic spots. Lots of buffalo, close up. We were told there are herds of wild horses, but were unfortunate and didn't see any. Lots of Prairie dogs. A little bit of construction on the roads, but no big deal. Traffic isn't too bad, so you can slow down or stop to look at things.

It is about $10.00 for two adults (can't remember), the drive is about 1 hour and a half. Lots of buffalo close up, and prairie dogs, and apparently wild horses, but didn't see any. Lots of pretty scenery!

We were making our way from Payson to Globe and happened by the Tonto National Monument - Cliff dwellers park. What a wonderful find! I'd previously been to the much better known "Montezuma's Castle" off I-17, but this was more accessible and gave a better feel for the inhabitants 600 years ago. The hike to the cliff dwelling is one-half mile with a 350 foot climb -- not unreasonable -- and the reward was both the dwelling and the view from above of Roosevelt Lake and the neighbouring mountains. This is a must-stop if making your way down Route 188 between Payson and Globe!

I found the steep hike up to the cliff ruins among the Saguaro cactus and the pleasant view looking over to the Roosevelt Dam more interesting than the actual ruins. There's better ancient ruins in the region I've seen such as Wupatki and Mesa Verde, though this is better than Tuzigoot and Montezuma's Castle in my opinion. It's worth seeing if you have a park pass, it's one of the cheaper monuments (I think $3 per person) but I found about half an hour sufficient to see the main ruins (I think there's a guided tour available to some other ruins). If you're in the Phoenix area, it's fun to drive here via the Apache Trail.

If you are interested in Cave Dwellings and can't get to Mesa Verde the Tonto dwellings are a perfect substitute. Located East of Phoenix in a beautiful area the Tonto Dwellings overlook Lake Roosevelt. They are easy to get to, just a short hike from the parking lot and you can enter into them being careful not to climb or touch walls. The entrance fee is $3.

If you are in the area be sure to stop at the Tumacacori National Historical Park. National Park passes are accepted. They will even give you a self guided tour brochure to borrow and if you like it you can buy it for $1. The visitor centre had a basket weaving display which occurs on certain days of the week. There was also a volunteer making fresh tortillas. Donations were encouraged. We took the ranger lead tour and would highly recommend it. Lots of interesting stories.

This site was absolutely worth the $3 admission fee and we enjoyed visiting the grounds, with all of the history - especially the mission church itself. The visitor experience could use a bit of updating. For example, the short film was very, very dated and left out a ton about the history of the mission.

We enjoyed our visit here - but wished we had skipped the guided tour and bought the $1 guide book instead. Unfortunately our guide was not very knowledgeable and I felt most of the tour was not worthwhile. The 15 minute film at the start is quite dated but still useful though it refers to the Spanish missionaries coming to Tumacacori to "civilize" the native people ....not quite the point of view I expected. But the buildings are interesting and I enjoyed walking down to see the new gardens being planted.

I paid for the trolley tour of $16. It was not the best tour that I have had but I recommend it. Most people did not tip but I did. We had a full trolley car and one woman had her lap dog with her that was quite annoying! This park is free otherwise. It gives insight on how we came to be what we are today. Also, reminds us of our history and how very very smart our forefathers were setting foundations in place that pulled us together as one nation.

While in Philadelphia for a conference, I received the tip to go to Valley Forge from a television promotion of local attractions. I took the SEPTA Rt. 125 bus from 13th and Market St. to the visitor center of the park and the entire trip took only 1 hour with stops and cost $3.50 one way. Once at the park, I was amazed. There are many miles of trails, many, many interesting historical tidbits, and loads of wildlife. I was at the park on an unusually warm Autumn day. The leaves were blazing with color and there was a good number of birds, squirrels and even a small snake out and about. I cannot recommend visiting this park enough and I would say that one should plan on spending at least 4 hours there just to check out the visitor center, watch the short film on Washington's army, and drive around the park.

A short drive down a paved road brings visitors to the Entrance. Use your Annual America the Beautiful Pass to enter. Parking is next to Visitors Centre which has restrooms a small visitors centre and has stairs and a lift down one level so less able visitors can go outside. We were unable to go down the steep stairs but had a good view of the cliff dwellings in the canyon from the lookouts at the top. Others took the stairs 350ft down to the canyon floor and said it was fantastic.

We visited this place on a day just before the thunder and rain started - that is maybe the reason for the few people who were present. This was a very peaceful and interesting place to be. We walked the island trial, the 1,5 km roundtrip, which was nothing compared to the Grand Canyon hike we did two days ago. With lots of photoshoots and breaks we used approximately 1 hour. The lady who greeted us when we and the car paid the fee for the entrance to the park was very kind and helpful. The fee itself was not too bad 8 $ for adults and nothing to pay for our 14 year old son. This is a short trip from Flagstaff and is highly recommended!

We arrived early into Flagstaff and couldn't check into our room so we went to the Walnut Canyon monument. The ranger station was shut so we didn't have to pay. We followed the rim trail which was flat and gave us amazing views down into the canyon and of the cave dwellings. It was a nice little stop off with great views but if we'd had to pay then it would have been too expensive at $32 for a family of four, hence only three stars.

Walnut canyon is 20 km east of Wagstaff,we had National parks year pass for 80 dollars ,which was very good .We have visited 5 national monuments and and pass was paid off.Park has scenic walking loop,it takes 50 min to walk.Views are amazing.

An easy drive from Flagstaff and free with the Annual Pass. The Island Trail is a must because it takes you down amongst the caves. The way back up is a bit more challenging if it's hot and not used to climbing at 6,690ft. But there are stopping places where you can rest and drink the water you MUST carry. The quality water supply at the visitor center is from a well. Typical Arizona late afternoon thunderstorms threatened but we were safely in our car on the I40 when the storm hit the mountains to our right. An excellent day out when combined with a visit to the immense Meteor Crater.

This is a national park so free if you have a pass ($80 pa per couple) or $5 each. The visitors centre at the top gives information on the cave dwellings but you walk down the canyon to see them. It is an extremely hard walk back up! When you set off there are steps on the edge of the cliff face with a nice metal rail but as you get going there are considerable lengths of path with nice tarmac flat sections and no rail at all. I wish we'd been warned about that rather than just the difficult walk as I found myself unable to continue due to vertigo. I'm sure its safe as there were lots of families going and it was a lovely smooth path but if you need a rail alongside the edge then this might not be the attraction for you!

Our family of 2 older adults and 3 20+ young adults visited Walnut Canyon mainly because it was close to our accommodation. It turned out to be an amazing choice. The cliff dwellings are incredible and well preserved considering they are over 900 years old. It was fascinating to imagine how these people lived in this large cliff side community when the river flowed through it. Going down is easy, most of the paths are wide and all of the stairs have hand rails, however, there are some places with drop offs. The day we were there 2 grade 4 classes were visiting. I thought the teachers were brave souls but they had no issues. I am uncomfortable with heights but was able to negotiate the trails with minimal problem and thoroughly enjoyed it. For those who prefer not to hike down into the canyon, there is a paved trail on the rim with 2 railed lookouts to view the caves.Thanks to previous reviews we were prepared with hiking shoes, sun screen, hats and plenty of water. We took our time, did both trails, looked at the storehouse ruins and spent 3 hours. All for $5 per person - admission also covers other Nation Monuments in the vicinity. We all highly recommend this monument.

We popped in to Walnut Canyon and didn't know what to expect. It's a very picturesque canyon with great photo opportunities. There are a couple of walks, one along the top of the canyon and one that is more strenuous into the canyon itself, we didn't do either as we were a little pressed for time. For $5 admission it should be on your list.

Wow, an amazing historical location and a must for those wanting to see the entire Grand Canyon area. Did not get to take a hike on the amazing trails as we travel with our dog but even just seeing it from the top and visiting the Visitors Centre. Its worth while. Suggest you pay the $5 fee per person and that is good for 2 other historic sites in the area - Sunset Crater and Wupatki

This is the most wonderful National park. What a walk back through history this is. I went here with my son and his wife as I am on holiday in Arizona and we walked many steps to see the little rooms in the rocks where some Native Americans lived. It was a beautiful day and the sun shone down on us. The fascinating experience is worth every step....bring water with you...and make sure you are fit and healthy as it is quite a trek but worth every step. There were lots of people on the steps and many benches in which you can stop and rest. My son brought an annual pass for 80 dollars and this gets you into every national park for a year for up to four people. Its a real saver. I enjoyed the experience very much. It had a lovely little shop and a video going on while we were there and some interesting facts all over the room which were very well presented. It did have a lift but obviously it is not a place where a disabled person could go but could watch the video. I would go again.

Walnut canyon almost stumbles upon you. You arrive at the information centre and suddenly its there. You can almost not wait to get there and then you pay your $5 per person and suddenly you can start snapping away. But wait. There is a stiff climb before you can really see it all. And what a stiff climb it is. But take your time. You have all day. Then you see where Honi Indians made their homes and storage areas and you think: they must have been crazy. A definite must see when you are in the area.

Good walk down and up the loop track with an informative commentary from a park guide. It was hot but we came prepared with water bottles, hats, sunscreen etc. Lots of steps so you need to be fairly fit. $5.00 per person entry. The canyon was very quiet and, although there were a lot of other visitors, it didn't feel crowded and we were able to get a sense of how things were for the inhabitants some 1,000 years ago.

$10 to get in is a little pricey as we did the walk and read all the literature on offer in less than two hours but the view is nice and the history is worth reading about...just don't expect to spend all day there

Staff very helpful and informative. A lot of steps to village so might not be suitable for everyone. But well worth the effort. If you plan to do a lot of nation parks, consider buying a national parks annual pass $ 80 dollars.Check up entrance prices before you travel. Also allowed us into some state parks in Arizona but not all states parks accept these.

Don't miss this marvel, just east of Flagstaff off the I-40, it's well worth the detour. Good visitors Center and again I would recommend taking time out to watch the video, it explains very well the caves and dwellings you are going to see, and a portrait of how the cave dwellers lived their lives. There is a trail a trail down to the canyon base, but don't worry there is a really good view point just a few steps down (lift also available), and an easy rim trail which is also suitable for wheel chairs from where you get excellent views of the caves. It is very spectacular and much bigger than I had anticipated. NOT TO BE MISSED. I would mention that if you are over 62, buy a National Parks Pass for $10 and it gets you and a friend in all the National Parks for ever, including The Grand Canyon, the Painted desert, Petrified Forest, Walnut Canyon and so much more

Our grandchildren loved working on their Jr. Ranger books here. They had to search for small boxes containing clues to find their next "letter" box. They also liked searching for the painted bison statues which blended in with their surroundings. The adults liked the beautiful well-kept grounds of wild flowers and the secret garden. Docents were well informed, interesting and willing to answer any question. There were art supplies available on loan in case you became inspired to paint on your visit! We even found the least expensive postcards on our trip - 10 for a dollar!

Yes, this monument is definitely worth visiting. Here are some tips to make your visit as easy as possible. We arrived at 10:30 am on a Saturday, which was fine, but earlier would have been better. The parking lot was already pretty crazy. By the time we left, the Visitor's Center and Gift Shop were unbearably crowded. Because we arrived in the morning, there were no "used" sleds, so we had to pay full-price $17 ($5 is refunded afterwards). Probably there are more used sleds available in the afternoon, but you'll have to fight to crowds. If you want to slide fast, get the wax. Also, if you want to go fast, lean back, almost horizontal, when you slide. Once you are in the park itself, there is lots of space, so it really can't get too crowded. Definitely take a change of shoes and socks, because you can't really get it all out of your shoes right away. Also don't forget sunscreen and sunglasses, even in the winter, the sun is intense. Do visit, this place is incredible.

My husband and I visited the sands in November which was a perfect time to be there. The temperature was about 70-75 so our 2 mile walk across the sand dunes was a very pleasant experience. A family with small children could do a short hike, people who wanted a brief but adventurous experience like ourselves could do the 2.2 mile hike, the more experienced hiker could do a 5 miler and there was even boardwalk for persons with a physical disability or mobility issues to take part. Or, if you wanted to, you could bike around the roadways! Either way, it provides ample opportunities for everyone! The views were amazing and it only cost $5 pp to get in. We did not buy any souvenirs as the prices were exorbitant! I think this is a must see!
Not really worth the time to drive there or a $5 fee. If you are travelling from Las Cruces, you will have to stop at a border patrol checkpoint to be able to get to this useless attraction.

How often do you get to walk across white sand dunes? Sled down sand dunes? Go for it. You won't need more than a few hours and it is something truly unique. We got our disc sleds at a Lowe's on sale for $1.50 each or you can just use a cardboard box like we did when we were kids. there's also a great fireworks store coming in from Ruidoso to check out. The sand was nice and cool and we walked barefoot the entire time (summer might be different). Walking up the steeper parts of the dunes was tiring, but part of the experience.

We went about 4.30pm and stayed to see the sunset which was great. When you arrive the dunes you see at the start are a little underwhelming until you get to the heart of the dunes! Wow! Think it was $5 each.

Great cheap family outing. The sleds were $10 if used or 16.99 new. They will buy back for a little less than what you initially bought it for (it's better than nothing) the kids enjoy it. The wax for sleds was $1.99. The views are amazing. They have a 15 minute video that explain the locations. There are ranger guided tours.
I come from Canada. A land that sees a lot of snow. Visiting thr White Sands reminded me of our winter but without the cold. $5 per person to enter the park. Well worth it if you are in the area.
$5 entry per person. There is a video presentation in the visitors center and information about the national park.

Costs $5 to get in, but they did not charge anything when I stopped by at 4:30. They sell sleds at the gift shop, but sometimes have used ones for reduced price or better yet several hotels in Alamogordo have ones you can borrow for free. I would go in the spring, morning, or late in the day for better temps and pictures. Can get severe winds in March. Make sure you bring water as none is available inside the park. Thought the gift store was awesome. Sunset tour was a pleasant surprise - learned alot. Not terribly exiting but neat to see and experience.

Wear sun protection even on a cool day. Went trekking off over 2 very windy days and didn't realise that I was catching the rays. Spend the day, bring a picnic and surf the dunes. Ticket lasts for 7 days. Would recommend the ranger walk at sunset, brilliant.

Visited White Sands with our teenage daughters. Watched the short film in the Visitor Centre and bought a sledge before driving out to the boardwalks. The sledges are quite expensive ($18 each - with $5 back if you return it when you're finished). The white dunes are an amazing site, especially set against the deep blue sky. We enjoyed a short talk by a ranger before driving on to the picnic spots. I would definitely recommend taking a picnic to enjoy at one of the shaded tables provided. (There are also toilets at each picnic area). We found a spot to sledge down the dunes, which everyone enjoyed. Spent about two and a half hours there in total.

We went back twice to visit this area. The dunes are as white as snow and are so beautiful. Our grandchildren enjoyed the fact that they could rent disks and actually slide down some of the larger dunes. We loved it and would highly recommend it as a much see place in New Mexico. Be sure that you drive deep into the area - the beginning of the drive is a little boring but when you actually reach the dunes it is breathtaking. Price was also very reasonable $5 for adult and children were free.

We planned on visiting only once during our stay in Alamogordo. We arrived earlier than expected on our first day so we decided to catch the sunset and free up our second day for swimming. We started by going to the information center at the park to get their advice on the best way to enjoy the dunes and they suggested we start with a guided sunset ranger tour. We took the guided tour and got some great sunset pictures. The next day all four of our children wanted to return to the park instead of swimming at the hotel (This has never happened before!!??!) so we went back again later in the day when it's not so hot and just let the kids run and play in the sand. On our second visit we did our own thing as we were now more familiar with the park. I took more pictures and we stayed until dark. Because we have younger children we just went to play in the sand and take pictures. We did not take any of the longer hikes so I can't comment on the trails. We didn't have to go far from the parking lots for the kids to play. Definitely bring your camera, water bottle(s) and bare feet. The sand does not get hot. Of all the stops we had on our road trip this was unanimously everyone's favorite. The park passes cost us $6.00 (our kids were all free) and was valid for seven days so we went multiple times and with every visit we went deeper into the park. (The kids asked to go back for a bit on the third day when we were on our way out of town to say "goodbye" to the sand). Adults will enjoy the beauty and kids will have a blast rolling and sliding down the dunes.
Great place to visit, lots of fun with the sledges, mother nature at her best with amazing views, only $3 to go in and can spend as long as you like there

The site was not hard to find, but I wish we had got there better prepared. The 1 gallon of water per person is no exaggeration if you plan on taking a long (more than a mile) tour, and it is also a good idea to have some snacks on you. All these could be purchased in the gift store, but cost more than in a grocery store...They also sell sand slides, which you can re-sell after use. I thought this was a good deal, but the slides cost about $20 each and could add up for a big family. Climbing up to the top of these sandhills is quite an exercise in the heat, but then the slide downhill on those plastic things is kind of fun. Good walking shoes are also recommended. We managed the sand barefooted, but some of the flat areas connecting the sand hills are crusted and full of thorny plants. Not for the unseasoned farefood walker.

This place is incredible, specially at the end of the day. One of the most beautiful sunsets I've ever seen. We bought used sand disks for $10 at the gift shop to slide on the dunes and that was really fun. I would say that one day or even half of day there is enough, but watching the sunset from the top of the dunes is a MUST!
This is a wonderful experience of nature. The loop drive and the walking paths are wonderful. The $3.00 per person pass well worth it.

While this park was not on my bucket list it certainly should have been. Admission is very cheap ($3) and admits you to a life event of walking and exploring a true desert. The dune life nature trail and the Alkali Flats trail are a most for adventurers. Be sure to bring plenty of water and sun protection with you as the hike is approximately 6 miles in total but offers spectacular views and experiences of waling in an alien world. I would not recommend this for children. The visitors center does offer snow sled rentals that you can use to go sledding on the sand dunes. Walking though the desert and finishing our trek as the sun set behind the mountains is surely a life event not to be forgotten. (The hike is perhaps not so highly recommended at the height of summer)

This is a remarkable place - miles of sparkling white gypsum sand that looks more like snow - except for the yuccas! For a cost of $3 each, it is well worth a visit! We did the sunset walk, which was gorgeous as we were rewarded with a fabulous sunset against the sands. The ranger was also knowledgeable and explained how the sands formed and about the wildlife and plants. The next day we hied to the 'lake' (now dried) which is about a 5-mile round trip. Do this in the morning before it gets warm - we set off at around 8.00 am and it took a couple of hours (including taking plenty of photos). You may want to take water with you too - especially if it's hot. We also wore proper hiking boots/footwear, which helped us keep going. The visitor centre is also worth a look and we'd recommend the short film. Watch out for white lizards, which have adapted over time to be camouflaged against the surroundings.

Heaven on Earth, beautiful, beautiful place!!!!!! The sand is so White you Think it's show, and the endeløs viet is breathtaking!!! You Can buy a sled for 16 dollars, at the visiter center, and get 5 dollars back When you take it back.

White Sands has a lot to offer. There are nature trails, picnic areas, ranger programs and so on. But the most exhilarating thing to do is sliding down the dunes on a plastic saucer. Fun for everyone from 3 to 80 years of age. 'Buy' a saucer at the gift shop for 10$ and receive a 3$ refund when you return it (keep your receipt!). So it's basically a 7$ rent. Also buy a piece of wax to keep the pace of sliding. Don't miss to walk one of the trails, it's just such an incredible environment and trail posts provide some information what's going on regarding plants, animals and geology.

What an unexpectedly beautiful place! The entrance fee is well worth the trip thru the park. You can buy sleds for sand sledding at the gift shop ... $16.99 each (or $10 for a used one) but get a $5 ($3 used) refund when you bring it back. Tip: If it works out ... watch for someone returning their sleds and grab them before they get into the gift shop - offer even $1 more than they'll get and you're still ahead of the game!)

Only $3 per person to see this amazing world wonder. You can drive an RV (we have a 30' 5th wheel) in and around the loop. There are lots of pull outs more than big enough for an RV so you can get out and feel the sand for yourself. This sand is amazing - it's not hot! It's actually quite cool and doesn't stick to your bare feet. In shaded areas the sand is actually cold. There are sunset walks, overnight back country tenting, bugs and so on for different interests. There is a 15+ minute video (free) to watch first - it is well worth the time as it explains so much. Lots of locals go there for weekend picnics like others would go to the beach or the lake. If you have children, take a plastic sled - you can slide down the sand like snow !!

We visited the monument on the Labor Day weekend. Very nice and attractive place. We reached Alamogordo around 3pm so got a chance to visit the monument for sunset. Entrance fee was $3 per person good for next seven days visit. The sunset stroll was very good and informative. After sunset they had a Music show at the amphitheater, it was very good especially listening to the music under full moon. Next day we started early in the morning, it was too hot to do any activities. Had to wait till it cooled of a bit to enjoying sledding. Picnic tables were very nice and attractive.

We were traveling with a one yr old so visited about two hours before the sunset. This place is gorgeous! It is about an 8 mile loop so you can drive through the whole thing to pick a spot that works for you. We wanted to take pictures of the sunset so we picked a spot that was facing sacramento mountains. We were expecting the sand to be hot but it was kind of cool, so our one yr old was crawling around easily. There were not too many visitors so we could pick an area where it was just us. We absolutely loved it, the sunset was beautiful! Take some water with you because there is none available once you are past the gift shop. Entry to the monument is $3 per adult and no charge for kids. The gift shop is quite nice and the prices are reasonable.
We got in an hour early with the $50 photographers fee which was very worthwhile. Lots to see at the beginning and end of the day for photography.

We visited the White Sands park on a road trip as we made a way back from Roswell. On the approach to the park our first view was spectacular! Everything was so green and then we went over a hill and in front of us was this huge stretch of white. After making our way to the park we went into the visitors centre and paid the hire charge for the sledge and bought a cube of wax. The sledges can be hired or bought and on return of a hired sledge you get back about $5 of the $8 you originally pay.

Nothing I can say here can prepare you for Yellowstone. We paid $50 at the South Gate (from Jackson) for our car with two adults to enter two parks - Grand Teton and Yellowstone, and spent the day there. That ticket is good for seven days.

As the 'Beautiful America' pass was only $20 more than the entrance fee for Yellowstone and Grand Teton, we bought the pass allowing us access to all National Parks and Forests for a year. It was totally worth it. The drives around the park are stunning, and you really need a minimum of two days and possibly three to see all of the major features.
Went there for a day and the views there are amazing. You need to be in ok shape to make it to the top of some of the sites. The prize is 30$ to get into the nationalpark.

The highlight for us was driving into the park and being confronted with stunning scenery - cliffs that went up forever - after driving through fairly flat terrain. Passing through the historic tunnel was a fascinating experience and the whole scale of the area is overwhelming. Wonderful sights were everywhere. We were less impressed by Emerald Pool, that seemed little more than a dirty puddle at the end of a crowded walk. Weeping Rock was OK, as was the walk into the canyon before wading was necessary, but it seems that new walks are needed to spread out the crowds. We also enjoyed the mule deer that took over the grassy area in front of the lodge once the tour buses had gone. Our best advice is to stop at every available parking space on the way into the park to make the most of the beautiful scenery.

The scene is impressive but the organization of the park is likely the worst of any NP and frankly surprising. Entering the park from the East they referred us to the visitor center at the West entrance. Only to find out the parking lot was completely full with loads of cars circulating and all courtesy gone with people quickly driving in an odd open space. The alternative was just outside the park for 20 $/ day. You ate not allowed to drive to the narrows yourself and the queues for the busses are enormous. No one informed us at the entrance. So if you have to choose pick any other park in the vicinity. I can only imagine what it must have been like into the scenic drive with these masses of people and it is not even high season yet! Time to redesign the admission system?

My wife and I spent 2 days walking around various trails in Zion National Park. The free shuttle bus from Springdale was excellent and allowed us to leave our car at the hotel. The shuttle took us to the visitor centre where we bought passes for $15 each. Together they also served as a car entry pass the day we left Springdale and drove through the park on our way to the Grand Canyon.

Wonderful rock formations, fantastic colours of reds and pinks, a variety of plant species, deep canyons and high plateaus make this a great place to visit. You can just drive through and marvel or get out and explore. If you are in the region to do the big 5 national parks I recommend buying a parks pass which covers all the States parks for a year for about $80 or $10 for a pensioner, well worth it.

We had done all the other parks and were delighted BUT then we hit here. We had the park pass and were pleased with that so we presented this at the gate.
