Only to be told that's nice but we had to pay $17.00 !? Why? We had a park pass? Apparently you now have to pay on top for some tunnel? We got no explanation just told we had to pay.

Whilst touring a number of national parks we visited Zion. It turned out to be our favourite park. For a start its manageable in terms of its size. You can see a lot of the park by taking the shuttle, or walking or if you are able by hiking. There is a beautiful simplicity to this place. Rock outcrops, trees and a river all add to its majestic feel. You can park your car in the ZNP Village which costs $10 per day. In the village there are shops, a coffee house, a pub and places were you can hire such things as hiking boots if you want to tackle the trails. You can walk into the park or catch the shuttle. There is an entry fee and if you have the America the Beautiful pass the fee is all ready covered. The park adjoins the town of Springdale which is a really nice town with all that you would require. Having enjoyed the park dont miss out on driving the Mount Carmel highway which is simply jaw dropping for its beauty.
Zion is one of the most incredible National Park in the US. The views from Angel's Landing cannot be missed. Feel humble between the towering walls of the Narrows.

We got there on a friday about 2pm to check out the location before our next day all day hike. Luckily we did check it out first. First off, getting into the park is 30 dollars a car, more for r.v.'s. Since I used my seniors pass, I got in for free. My wife and I walked around the visitors center and drove around till 4pm and then left. The tram that takes you from the visitors center begins at 6am. The conductor said be there before 8am , or you will have a 1 hrs wait in line. We got there at 730am and waited 1/2hr in line for the tram. No cars are allowed past the "Junction" where everyone wants to hike. The Narrows. When we left the park at 3pm, the line was about 300 yards long. Unreal.

Book in early if you're camping, even out of high season/holidays it fills up quickly. We went in May and it was booked out by March (ish). We ended up in a KOA in St. George/Hurricane, and about 40 clicks to Zion. If you are camping and you can get in early, stay at the Red Cliff Campground. $15 instead of $42 at the KOA and its up in the Red Cliffs. Really nice at sunset. If you like the desert, open spaces, gaping chasms and wild rock formations, you will love Zion, Bryce, Monument and of course the Grand Canyon. If you're not camping, park outside the National Park entrance up away from the shops for easy parking for the day (not time limited), it's an easy walk to the park entrance and the free shuttle service that will take you to all stops up to the famous Narrows walk (about 40 minutes away). If the water is running then some of these walks will be spectacular (emerald pools and weeping cliffs), if the water is low definitely consider the Narrows. It's a easy days worth. Really cool rock formations both in and on the way out of Zion. Definitely take the route 9 exit (to Bryce Canyon) if you can, more sensational rock formations, and a couple of really nice camping grounds that aren't well advertised if you want an early start to get to Bryce. Oh and if you are doing a National Park crawl, make sure you get the Annual Pass for $80, it's approx $30 for entry at most National Parks, so it pays off pretty quickly.

We did a roadtrip to several parks (bryce, zyon, rocky mountains, yellowstone,...) in may 2016 and stopped at Zion National Park for one day. The park is too crowdy! It took about 1 hour to find a parking space and as we decided to go lease we found a PAYABLE parking lot (10 dollars per day), so we decided to give it a try. Once in the park you only understand why you could'nt find a parking space : TOO MUCH VISITORS! Luckily you have to take a shuttle into the park otherwiste it would be impossible to visit the few points of interests.Of all the NP we've did this one was the least interesting exept when you are into hiking (and we're not)!

First the entrance fees; $30 for vehicles, $15 for individual walk ins including bikers, good for 7 days. Seniors, well of course, your senior passes. Camping is available. We chose to do hotel because it is not fun to camp where it’s raining and if you are here for a week, who would want to deal with cooking after a long hard days hike? We chose to have hot showers and nice warm bed with clean sheets.

Visited Zion in November 2016 for one day. Hiked the Riverside Walk and the Canyon Overlook Trail -- that was a nice mix, as the Riverside Walk takes you along the river at the bottom of one of the canyons (i.e., mostly flat), and the Canyon Overlook takes you up to the top of some of the cliffs (i.e., fairly steep elevation change). When we got to the end of the dry area on the Riverside Walk, we took off our shoes and socks to cross the river (really cold!) so we could hike a little farther into the Narrows -- we didn't get very far, as pretty soon the river fills the canyon from wall to wall, but we met a few people who had been able to hike much farther up-river because they were wearing special boots (which apparently you can buy/rent in Springdale). Well worth the visit (and the $30 entry fee, good for 7 days).

This National Park is quite large with many different hiking paths and other places to picnic and such. I was particularly looking for the Visitor Center. (I collect National Park Pass Stamps). I was disappointed that I could not locate it! I didn't have much time to find it, but the signage was not evident. Pretty park, though!
